827<article>

829 <div class="resize-content">

830

831 <h1>

832Genetics of Skin Cancer (PDQ)Health Professional Version</h1>

833

834 <div id="cgvBody">

835

836 <div class="summary-sections">

837

838 <nav class="on-this-page" role="navigation">

839

840 <h6>

841On This Page</h6>

842

843 <ul>

844

845 <li>

846<a href="#_1004">

847Executive Summary</a>

848</li>

849

850 <li>

851<a href="#_1">

852Introduction</a>

853</li>

854

855 <li>

856<a href="#_9">

857Basal Cell Carcinoma</a>

858</li>

859

860 <li>

861<a href="#_20">

862Squamous Cell Carcinoma</a>

863</li>

864

865 <li>

866<a href="#_38">

867Melanoma</a>

868</li>

869

870 <li>

871<a href="#_58">

872Syndromes Associated With Rare Types of Skin Cancer</a>

873</li>

874

875 <li>

876<a href="#_423">

877Psychosocial Issues in Familial Melanoma</a>

878</li>

879

880 <li>

881<a href="#_4">

882Changes to This Summary (08/23/2023)</a>

883</li>

884

885 <li>

886<a href="#_AboutThis_1">

887About This PDQ Summary</a>

888</li>

889

890 </ul>

891

892</nav>

893

894

895 <div class="accordion">

896

897

898

899 <section id="_1004">

900

901 <h2>

902Executive Summary</h2>

903

904 <div id="_section_1004" class="pdq-sections">

905<p id="_1005" tabindex="-1">

906This executive summary reviews the topics covered in this PDQ summary on the genetics of skin cancer, with hyperlinks to detailed sections below that describe the evidence on each topic.</p>

907<div class="pdq-content-list">

908<ul id="_1006">

909<li>

910<strong>

911Inheritance and Risk</strong>

912<p id="_1007" tabindex="-1">

913More than 100 types of tumors are clinically apparent on the skin. Many are known to have <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460148&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460148&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

914familial</a>

915 and/or <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=809371&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000809371&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

916inherited</a>

917 components, either in isolation or as part of a syndrome with other features. <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_9">

918Basal cell carcinoma (BCC)</a>

919 and <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_20">

920squamous cell carcinoma (SCC)</a>

921 are two of the most common malignancies in the United States and are often caused by sun exposure, although several <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=754220&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000754220&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

922hereditary syndromes</a>

923 and <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45693&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045693&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

924genes</a>

925 are also associated with an increased risk of developing these cancers. <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_38">

926Melanoma</a>

927 (which is sometimes referred to as cutaneous melanoma) is a less common type of skin cancer, but 5% to 10% of all melanomas arise in multiple-case families and can be inherited in an <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=793860&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000793860&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

928autosomal dominant</a>

929 fashion. Melanoma is the most lethal of the common skin cancers.</p>

930</li>

931<li>

932<strong>

933Associated Genes and Syndromes</strong>

934<p id="_1314" tabindex="-1">

935Several genes and hereditary syndromes are associated with the development of skin cancer:</p>

936<div class="pdq-content-list">

937<ol id="_1313">

938<li>

939<strong>

940Basal cell carcinoma</strong>

941 - <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_16">

942Basal cell nevus syndrome</a>

943 (BCNS, caused by <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=783960&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000783960&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

944pathogenic variants</a>

945 in <em class="gene-name">

946<a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_209">

947PTCH1</a>

948</em>

949 and <em class="gene-name">

950<a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_213">

951PTCH2</a>

952</em>

953) is associated with increased BCC risk. </li>

954<li>

955<strong>

956Squamous cell carcinoma</strong>

957 - Syndromes such as <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_131">

958oculocutaneous albinism</a>

959, <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_856">

960epidermolysis bullosa</a>

961, and <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_146">

962Fanconi anemia</a>

963 are associated with increased SCC risk.</li>

964<li>

965<strong>

966Melanoma</strong>

967 - <em class="gene-name">

968CDKN2A</em>

969 is a major <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460154&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460154&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

970germline</a>

971 <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46657&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046657&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

972tumor suppressor gene</a>

973 that is associated with increased melanoma risk. Pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

974CDKN2A</em>

975 may account for 35% to 40% of all familial melanomas. Germline pathogenic variants in several other genes (i.e., <em class="gene-name">

976<a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_168">

977CDK4</a>

978</em>

979, <em class="gene-name">

980<a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_645">

981MITF</a>

982</em>

983, and <em class="gene-name">

984<a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_786">

985BAP1</a>

986</em>

987) are also associated with increased melanoma risk.</li>

988</ol>

989</div>

990<p id="_1315" tabindex="-1">

991An <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=339339&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000339339&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

992autosomal recessive</a>

993 disease, called <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_126">

994xeroderma pigmentosum (XP)</a>

995, is associated with increased BCC, SCC, and melanoma risks.</p>

996<p id="_1009" tabindex="-1">

997<a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_801">

998Genome-wide association studies</a>

999 show promise for identifying common, low-<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=339344&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000339344&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1000penetrance</a>

1001 susceptibility <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=339337&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000339337&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1002alleles</a>

1003 for many complex diseases, including melanoma, but the <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=803523&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000803523&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1004clinical utility</a>

1005 of these findings remains uncertain.</p>

1006</li>

1007<li>

1008<strong>

1009Clinical Management</strong>

1010<p id="_1010" tabindex="-1">

1011Risk-reducing strategies for individuals with an increased <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=809370&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000809370&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1012hereditary predispositions</a>

1013 to skin cancer are similar to recommendations for those in the general population. These recommendations include sun avoidance, use of sunscreen, use of sun-protective clothing, and avoidance of tanning beds. Chemopreventive agents such as <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_272">

1014isotretinoin and acitretin</a>

1015 have been studied for the treatment of BCCs in patients with BCNS and XP and are associated with a significant decrease in the number of tumors per year. <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_701">

1016Vismodegib</a>

1017 has also shown promise in reducing the per-patient annual rate of new BCCs requiring surgery among patients with BCNS. <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_257">

1018Isotretinoin</a>

1019 has also been shown to reduce SCC incidence among patients with XP.</p>

1020<p id="_1011" tabindex="-1">

1021Treatment of hereditary skin cancers is similar to the treatment of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=339347&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000339347&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1022sporadic skin cancers</a>

1023. One study in an XP population found therapeutic use of <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_259">

1024fluorouracil</a>

1025 (5-FU) to be efficacious, particularly in the treatment of extensive lesions. In addition to its role as a therapeutic and potential chemopreventive agent, <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_821">

1026vismodegib</a>

1027 is also being studied for potential palliative effects for keratocystic odontogenic tumors in patients with BCNS.</p>

1028</li>

1029<li>

1030<strong>

1031Psychosocial and Behavioral Issues</strong>

1032<p id="_1012" tabindex="-1">

1033Most of the psychosocial literature about hereditary skin cancers has focused on patients with familial melanoma. In individuals at risk of familial melanoma, <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_423">

1034psychosocial factors</a>

1035 influence decisions about genetic testing for inherited cancer risk and risk-management strategies. <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_425">

1036Interest in genetic testing</a>

1037 for pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

1038CDKN2A</em>

1039 is generally high. Perceived benefits among individuals with a strong family history of melanoma include information about the risk of melanoma for themselves and their children and increased motivation for sun-protective behavior. A number of studies have examined <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_432">

1040risk-reducing and early-detection behaviors</a>

1041 in individuals with a family history of melanoma. Overall, these studies indicate inconsistent adoption and maintenance of these behaviors. Intervention studies have targeted knowledge about melanoma, sun protection, and screening behaviors in family members of patients with melanoma, with mixed results. Research is ongoing to better understand and address psychosocial and behavioral issues in high-risk families.</p>

1042</li>

1043</ul>

1044</div>

1045</div>

1046

1047 </section>

1048

1049

1050

1051 <section id="_1">

1052

1053 <h2>

1054Introduction</h2>

1055

1056 <div id="_section_1" class="pdq-sections">

1057<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

1058<h6>

1059In This Section</h6>

1060<ul>

1061<li>

1062<a href="#_81_toc">

1063Structure of the Skin</a>

1064</li>

1065<li>

1066<a href="#_90_toc">

1067Function of the Skin</a>

1068</li>

1069<li>

1070<a href="#_680_toc">

1071Clinical Presentation of Skin Cancers<ul>

1072<li>

1073<a href="#_681_toc">

1074Basal cell carcinomas</a>

1075</li>

1076<li>

1077<a href="#_682_toc">

1078Squamous cell carcinomas</a>

1079</li>

1080<li>

1081<a href="#_683_toc">

1082Melanomas</a>

1083</li>

1084</ul>

1085</a>

1086</li>

1087</ul>

1088</nav>

1089<p id="_231" tabindex="-1">

1090[<em>

1091Note: Many of the medical and scientific terms used in this summary are found in the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/dictionaries/genetics-dictionary" title="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/dictionaries/genetics-dictionary">

1092NCI Dictionary of Genetics Terms</a>

1093. When a linked term is clicked, the definition will appear in a separate window.</em>

1094]</p>

1095<p id="_1003" tabindex="-1">

1096[<em>

1097Note: A concerted effort is being made within the genetics community to shift terminology used to describe genetic variation. The shift is to use the term &#8220;<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=776887&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000776887&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1098variant</a>

1099&#8221; rather than the term &#8220;<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46063&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046063&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1100mutation</a>

1101&#8221; to describe a difference that exists between the person or group being studied and the reference sequence, particularly for differences that exist in the <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460154&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460154&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1102germline</a>

1103. Variants can then be further classified as benign (harmless), likely benign, of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=556495&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000556495&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1104uncertain significance</a>

1105, likely pathogenic, or <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=783960&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000783960&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1106pathogenic</a>

1107 (disease causing). Throughout this summary, we will use the term pathogenic variant to describe a disease-causing mutation. For more information about variant classification, see <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/overview-pdq#_2676">

1108Cancer Genetics Overview</a>

1109.</em>

1110]</p>

1111<p id="_411" tabindex="-1">

1112[<em>

1113Note: Many of the <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45693&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045693&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1114genes</a>

1115 and conditions described in this summary are found in the Online Mendelian Inheritance in Man (OMIM) catalog. For more information, see <a href="https://www.omim.org/" title="https://www.omim.org/">

1116OMIM</a>

1117.</em>

1118]</p>

1119<section id="_81">

1120<h3 id="_81_toc">

1121Structure of the Skin</h3>

1122<p id="_82" tabindex="-1">

1123The genetics of skin cancer is an extremely broad topic. More than 100 types of tumors are clinically apparent on the skin; many of them have <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460148&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460148&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1124familial</a>

1125 components, either in isolation or as part of a <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=754220&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000754220&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1126syndrome</a>

1127 with other features. This is, in part, because the skin itself is a complex organ made up of multiple cell types. Furthermore, many of these cell types can undergo malignant transformation at various points in their differentiation, leading to tumors with distinct histology and dramatically different biological behaviors, such as squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) and basal cell cancer (BCC). These have been called nonmelanoma skin cancers or keratinocyte cancers.</p>

1128<p id="_83" tabindex="-1">

1129<a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_250">

1130Figure 1</a>

1131 is a simple diagram of normal skin structure. It also indicates the major cell types that are normally found in each compartment. Broadly speaking, there are two large compartments&#8212;the avascular epidermis and the vascular dermis&#8212;with many cell types distributed in a connective tissue matrix, largely created by fibroblasts.[<a href="#cit/section_2.1">

11321</a>

1133]</p>

1134<figure id="figure_250" class="image-center">

1135<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/624959.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

1136Enlarge</a>

1137<img id="_250" alt="Schematic representation of normal skin; drawing shows normal skin anatomy, including the epidermis, dermis, hair follicles, sweat glands, hair shafts, veins, arteries, fatty tissue, nerves, lymph vessels, oil glands, and subcutaneous tissue. The pullout shows a close-up of the squamous cell and basal cell layers of the epidermis, the basement membrane in between the epidermis and dermis, and the dermis with blood vessels. Melanin is shown in the cells. A melanocyte is shown in the layer of basal cells at the deepest part of the epidermis." title="Schematic representation of normal skin; drawing shows normal skin anatomy, including the epidermis, dermis, hair follicles, sweat glands, hair shafts, veins, arteries, fatty tissue, nerves, lymph vessels, oil glands, and subcutaneous tissue. The pullout shows a close-up of the squamous cell and basal cell layers of the epidermis, the basement membrane in between the epidermis and dermis, and the dermis with blood vessels. Melanin is shown in the cells. A melanocyte is shown in the layer of basal cells at the deepest part of the epidermis." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/624959-750.jpg">

1138<figcaption class="caption-container">

1139Figure 1. Schematic representation of normal skin. The relatively avascular epidermis houses basal cell keratinocytes and squamous epithelial keratinocytes, the source cells for BCC and SCC, respectively. Melanocytes are also present in normal skin and serve as the source cell for melanoma. The separation between epidermis and dermis occurs at the basement membrane zone, located just inferior to the basal cell keratinocytes.</figcaption>

1140</figure>

1141<p id="_84" tabindex="-1">

1142The outer layer or epidermis is made primarily of keratinocytes but has several other minor cell populations. The bottom layer is formed of basal keratinocytes abutting the basement membrane, along with interspersed melanocytes. The basement membrane is formed from products of keratinocytes and dermal fibroblasts, such as collagen and laminin, and is an important anatomical and functional structure. Basal keratinocytes lose contact with the basement membrane as they divide. As basal keratinocytes migrate toward the skin's surface, they progressively differentiate, lose their nuclei, and form the spinous cell layer; the granular cell layer; and the keratinized outer layer, or stratum corneum, which serves as a protective covering of the body.</p>

1143<p id="_232" tabindex="-1">

1144The true cytologic origin of BCC is unclear. BCC and basal cell keratinocytes share many histological similarities, as is reflected in the name. Alternatively, the outer root sheath cells of the hair follicle have also been proposed as the cell of origin for BCC.[<a href="#cit/section_2.2">

11452</a>

1146] This is suggested by the fact that BCCs occur predominantly on hair-bearing skin. BCCs rarely metastasize but can invade tissue locally or regionally, sometimes traveling along nerves.[<a href="#cit/section_2.3">

11473</a>

1148]</p>

1149<p id="_233" tabindex="-1">

1150Some debate remains about the origin of SCC; however, these cancers are likely derived from epidermal stem cells associated with the hair follicle.[<a href="#cit/section_2.4">

11514</a>

1152] A variety of tissues, such as the lung and the uterine cervix, can give rise to SCCs. This cancer has somewhat differing behavior depending on its tissue source. Even in cancer derived from the skin, SCC from different anatomic locations can have differing levels of aggressiveness; for example, SCC from glabrous (smooth, hairless) sun-exposed skin has a lower metastatic rate than SCC arising from the vermillion border of the lip or from scars.[<a href="#cit/section_2.3">

11533</a>

1154]</p>

1155<p id="_85" tabindex="-1">

1156Additionally, in the epidermal compartment, melanocytes distribute singly along the basement membrane and can undergo malignant transformation into melanoma. Melanocytes are derived from neural crest cells and migrate to the epidermal compartment near the eighth week of gestational age. Melanocytes contain melanin, which is packaged into melanosomes and transported to nearby keratinocytes to induce pigmentation of the skin. Melanin provides a barrier for the nuclei of keratinocytes against ultraviolet radiation and also plays a role in the immune system.[<a href="#cit/section_2.5">

11575</a>

1158] </p>

1159<p id="_1177" tabindex="-1">

1160Langerhans cells, or dendritic cells, are another cell type in the epidermis and have a primary function of antigen presentation. These cells reside in the skin for an extended period of time and respond to different stimuli, such as ultraviolet radiation or topical steroids, which cause them to migrate out of the skin.[<a href="#cit/section_2.6">

11616</a>

1162]</p>

1163<p id="_86" tabindex="-1">

1164The dermis is largely composed of an extracellular matrix. Prominent cell types and organelles in this compartment are fibroblasts, endothelial cells, smooth muscle cells, transient immune system cells, blood vessels, and nerves. When malignant transformation occurs, fibroblasts form fibrosarcomas and endothelial cells form angiosarcomas, Kaposi sarcoma, or other vascular tumors. There are a number of immune cell types that move in and out of the skin to blood vessels and lymphatics; these include mast cells, lymphocytes, mononuclear cells, histiocytes, and granulocytes. These cells can increase in number in inflammatory diseases and can form tumors within the skin. For example, urticaria pigmentosa is a condition that arises from mast cells and is occasionally associated with mast cell leukemia; cutaneous T-cell lymphoma is often confined to the skin throughout its course. Overall, 10% of leukemias and lymphomas have prominent expression in the skin.[<a href="#cit/section_2.7">

11657</a>

1166]</p>

1167<p id="_87" tabindex="-1">

1168Epidermal appendages are also found in the dermal compartment. These are derivatives of the epidermal keratinocytes, such as hair follicles, sweat glands, and the sebaceous glands associated with the hair follicles. These structures are generally formed in the first and second trimesters of fetal development. These can form a large variety of benign or malignant tumors with diverse biological behaviors. Several of these tumors are associated with familial syndromes. Overall, there are dozens of different histological subtypes of these tumors associated with individual components of the adnexal structures.[<a href="#cit/section_2.8">

11698</a>

1170]</p>

1171<p id="_88" tabindex="-1">

1172Finally, the subcutis is a layer that extends below the dermis with varying depth, depending on the anatomic location. This deeper boundary can include muscle, fascia, bone, or cartilage. The subcutis can be affected by inflammatory conditions such as panniculitis and malignancies such as liposarcoma.[<a href="#cit/section_2.9">

11739</a>

1174]</p>

1175<p id="_89" tabindex="-1">

1176These compartments give rise to their own malignancies but are also the region of immediate adjacent spread of localized skin cancers from other compartments. The boundaries of each skin compartment are used to define the staging of skin cancers. For example, an <em>

1177in situ</em>

1178 melanoma is confined to the epidermis. Once the cancer crosses the basement membrane into the dermis, it is invasive. Internal malignancies also commonly metastasize to the skin. The dermis and subcutis are the most common locations, but the epidermis can also be involved in conditions such as Pagetoid breast cancer.</p>

1179</section>

1180<section id="_90">

1181<h3 id="_90_toc">

1182Function of the Skin</h3>

1183<p id="_91" tabindex="-1">

1184The skin has a wide variety of functions. First, the skin is an important barrier preventing extensive water and temperature loss and providing protection against minor abrasions. These functions can be aberrantly regulated in cancer. For example, in the erythroderma (extensive reddening of the skin) associated with severe sunburn, alterations in the regulations of body temperature can result in profound heat loss. </p>

1185<p id="_1205" tabindex="-1">

1186Second, the skin has important adaptive and innate immunity functions. In adaptive immunity, antigen-presenting cells engender T-cell responses consisting of increased levels of helper T cells (T<sub>

1187H</sub>

1188)1, T<sub>

1189H</sub>

11902, or T<sub>

1191H</sub>

119217.[<a href="#cit/section_2.10">

119310</a>

1194] In innate immunity, the immune system produces numerous peptides with antibacterial and antifungal capacity. Even small breaks in the skin can potentially lead to infection. The skin-associated lymphoid tissue is one of the largest arms of the immune system and has a role in the prevention of infection. It may also be important in immune surveillance against cancer. Immunosuppression, such as when it is induced intentionally after solid-organ transplantation to reduce the risk of transplanted organ rejection, is a significant risk factor for skin cancer. The skin is significant for communication through facial expression and hand movements. Unfortunately, areas of specialized function, such as the area around the eyes and ears, are common places for cancer to occur. Even small cancers in these areas can lead to reconstructive challenges and have significant cosmetic and social ramifications.[<a href="#cit/section_2.1">

11951</a>

1196]</p>

1197</section>

1198<section id="_680">

1199<h3 id="_680_toc">

1200Clinical Presentation of Skin Cancers</h3>

1201<p id="_636" tabindex="-1">

1202While the appearance of any one skin cancer can vary, there are general physical presentations that can be used in screening. BCCs most commonly have a pearly rim or can appear somewhat eczematous (for more information, see <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_854">

1203Figure 2</a>

1204 and <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_992">

1205Figure 3</a>

1206). They often ulcerate (for more information, see <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_854">

1207Figure 2</a>

1208). SCCs frequently have a thick keratin top layer (for more information, see <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_850">

1209Figure 4</a>

1210). Both BCCs and SCCs are associated with a history of sun-damaged skin. Melanomas are characterized by dark pigment with asymmetry, border irregularity, color variation, a diameter of more than 6 mm, and evolution (ABCDE criteria). For more information about ABCDE criteria, see <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/types/skin/melanoma-photos" title="https://www.cancer.gov/types/skin/melanoma-photos">

1211What Does Melanoma Look Like?</a>

1212 on NCI's website. Photographs representing typical clinical presentations of these cancers are shown below. </p>

1213<section id="_681">

1214<h4 id="_681_toc">

1215Basal cell carcinomas</h4>

1216<p id="_853" tabindex="-1">

1217<figure id="figure_854" class="image-center">

1218<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/765000.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

1219Enlarge</a>

1220<img id="_854" alt="Photographs showing a red, ulcerated lesion on the skin of the face (left panel) and a red, ulcerated lesion surrounded by a white border on the skin of the back of the right ear (right panel)." title="Photographs showing a red, ulcerated lesion on the skin of the face (left panel) and a red, ulcerated lesion surrounded by a white border on the skin of the back of the right ear (right panel)." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/765000-750.jpg">

1221<figcaption class="caption-container">

1222Figure 2. Ulcerated basal cell carcinoma (left panel) and ulcerated basal cell carcinoma with characteristic pearly rim (right panel).</figcaption>

1223</figure>

1224<figure id="figure_992" class="image-center">

1225<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/764584.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

1226Enlarge</a>

1227<img id="_992" alt="Photographs showing a pink, scaly lesion on the skin (left panel) and flesh-colored nodules on the skin (right panel)." title="Photographs showing a pink, scaly lesion on the skin (left panel) and flesh-colored nodules on the skin (right panel)." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/764584-750.jpg">

1228<figcaption class="caption-container">

1229Figure 3. Superficial basal cell carcinoma (left panel) and nodular basal cell carcinoma (right panel).</figcaption>

1230</figure>

1231</p>

1232</section>

1233<section id="_682">

1239Enlarge</a>

1241<figcaption class="caption-container">

1242Figure 4. Squamous cell carcinoma on the face with thick keratin top layer (left panel) and squamous cell carcinoma on the leg (right panel).</figcaption>

1243</figure>

1244</p>

1245</section>

1246<section id="_683">

1247<h4 id="_683_toc">

1252Enlarge</a>

1253<img id="_852" alt="Photographs showing a brown lesion with a large and irregular border on the skin (panel 1); large, asymmetrical, red and brown lesions on the skin (panels 2 and 3); and an asymmetrical, brown lesion on the skin on the bottom of the foot (panel 4)." title="Photographs showing a brown lesion with a large and irregular border on the skin (panel 1); large, asymmetrical, red and brown lesions on the skin (panels 2 and 3); and an asymmetrical, brown lesion on the skin on the bottom of the foot (panel 4)." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/765029-750.jpg">

1254<figcaption class="caption-container">

1256</figure>

1258</section>

1259</section>

1297

1298 <section id="_9">

1299

1300 <h2>

1301Basal Cell Carcinoma</h2>

1302

1303 <div id="_section_9" class="pdq-sections">

1304<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

1305<h6>

1306In This Section</h6>

1307<ul>

1308<li>

1311</li>

1312<li>

1332</a>

1333</li>

1334<li>

1335<a href="#_12_toc">

1337<li>

1350</a>

1351</li>

1355<li>

1358BAP1</em>

1359)</a>

1360</li>

1361<li>

1362<a href="#_1283_toc">

1363<em class="gene-name">

1364MC1R</em>

1365</a>

1366</li>

1367</ul>

1368</a>

1369</li>

1370<li>

1371<a href="#_14_toc">

1373<li>

1390</a>

1415</nav>

1416<section id="_10">

1417<h3 id="_10_toc">

1418Introduction</h3>

1419<p id="_234" tabindex="-1">

1420Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is the most common malignancy in people of European descent, with an associated lifetime risk of 30%.[<a href="#cit/section_3.1">

14211</a>

1422] While exposure to ultraviolet (UV) radiation is the risk factor most closely linked to the development of BCC, other environmental factors (such as ionizing radiation, chronic arsenic ingestion, and immunosuppression) and genetic factors

1423 (such as family history, skin type, and genetic syndromes) also potentially contribute to carcinogenesis. In contrast to melanoma, metastatic spread of BCC is very rare and typically arises from large tumors that have evaded medical treatment for extended periods of time. BCCs can invade tissue locally or regionally, sometimes following along nerves. With early detection, the prognosis for BCC is excellent.

1424</p>

1425</section>

1426<section id="_279">

1427<h3 id="_279_toc">

1428Risk Factors for Basal Cell Carcinoma</h3>

1429<p id="_1001" tabindex="-1">

1430This section focuses on risk factors in individuals at increased hereditary risk of developing BCC. For more information about risk factors for BCC in the general population, see <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-prevention-pdq">

1431Skin Cancer Prevention</a>

1432.</p>

1433<section id="_324">

1434<h4 id="_324_toc">

1435Sun exposure</h4>

1436<p id="_325" tabindex="-1">

1437Sun exposure is the major known environmental factor associated with the development of skin cancer of all types. There are different patterns of sun exposure associated with each major type of skin cancer (BCC, squamous cell carcinoma [SCC], and melanoma). For more information, see <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-prevention-pdq">

1438Skin Cancer Prevention</a>

1439.</p>

1440</section>

1441<section id="_367">

1442<h4 id="_367_toc">

1443Pigmentary characteristics</h4>

1444<p id="_368" tabindex="-1">

1445The high-risk <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460203&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460203&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1446phenotype</a>

1447 consists of individuals with the following physical characteristics:</p>

1448<div class="pdq-content-list">

1449<ul id="_373">

1450<li>

1451Fair skin that sunburns easily.</li>

1452<li>

1453Lightly pigmented irides (blue and green eye color).</li>

1454<li>

1455Presence of freckles in sun-exposed skin.</li>

1456<li>

1457Poor ability to tan.</li>

1458<li>

1459Blond or red hair color.</li>

1460</ul>

1461</div>

1462<p id="_374" tabindex="-1">

1463Specifically, people with more highly pigmented skin demonstrate lower incidence of BCC than do people with lighter pigmented skin. Individuals with Fitzpatrick type I or II skin (lighter skin) were shown to have a twofold increased risk of BCC in a small case-control study.[<a href="#cit/section_3.2">

14642</a>

1465] Blond or red hair color was associated with increased risk of BCC in two large cohorts: the Nurses&#8217; Health Study and the Health Professionals&#8217; Follow-Up Study.[<a href="#cit/section_3.3">

14663</a>

1467] In women from the Nurses&#8217; Health Study, there was an increased risk of BCC in women with red hair relative to those with light brown hair (adjusted relative risk [RR], 1.30; 95% confidence interval [CI], 1.20&#8211;1.40). In men from the Health Professionals Follow-Up Study, the risk of BCC associated with red hair was not as large (RR, 1.17; 95% CI, 1.02&#8211;1.34) and was not significant after adjustment for melanoma family history and sunburn history.[<a href="#cit/section_3.3">

14683</a>

1469] Risk associated with blond hair was also increased for both men and women (RR, pooled analysis, 1.09; 95% CI, 1.02&#8211;1.18), and dark brown hair was protective against BCC (RR, pooled analysis, 0.89; 95% CI, 0.87&#8211;0.92). For more information, see the section on<a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_304">

1470 Pigmentary characteristics</a>

1471 in the Melanoma section.</p>

1472</section>

1473<section id="_333">

1474<h4 id="_333_toc">

1475Family history</h4>

1476<p id="_334" tabindex="-1">

1477Individuals with BCCs and/or SCCs report a higher frequency of these cancers in their family members than do controls. The importance of this finding is unclear. Apart from defined genetic disorders with an increased risk of BCC, a positive family history of any skin cancer is a strong predictor of the development of BCC. Data from the Nurses&#8217; Health Study and the Health Professionals Follow-Up Study indicate that the family history of melanoma in a <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460150&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460150&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1478first-degree relative</a>

1479 (FDR) is associated with an increased risk of BCC in both men and women (RR, 1.31; 95% CI, 1.25&#8211;1.37; <em>

1480P</em>

1481 &lt; .0001).[<a href="#cit/section_3.3">

14823</a>

1483] A family history of melanoma in the same cohorts, plus the Nurses&#8217; Health Study 2, showed a similar increased risk (hazard ratio [HR], 1.27; 95% CI, 1.12&#8211;1.44).[<a href="#cit/section_3.4">

14844</a>

1485] A study of 376 early-onset BCC cases and 383 controls found that a family history of any type of skin cancer increased the risk of early-onset BCC (odds ratio [OR], 2.49; 95% CI, 1.80&#8211;3.45). This risk increased when an FDR was diagnosed with skin cancer before age 50 years (OR, 4.79; 95% CI, 2.90&#8211;7.90). Individuals who had a family history of both melanoma and nonmelanoma skin cancer (NMSC) had the highest risk (OR, 3.65; 95% CI, 1.79&#8211;7.47).[<a href="#cit/section_3.5">

14865</a>

1487]</p>

1488<p id="_982" tabindex="-1">

1489A study on the <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=781848&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000781848&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1490heritability</a>

1491 of cancer among 80,309 monozygotic and 123,382 dizygotic twins showed that NMSCs have a heritability of 43% (95% CI, 26%&#8211;59%), suggesting that almost half of the risk of NMSC is caused by inherited factors.[<a href="#cit/section_3.6">

14926</a>

1493] Additionally, the cumulative risk of NMSC was 1.9-fold higher for monozygotic than for dizygotic twins (95% CI, 1.8&#8211;2.0).[<a href="#cit/section_3.6">

14946</a>

1495]</p>

1496</section>

1497<section id="_335">

1498<h4 id="_335_toc">

1499Previous personal history of BCC or SCC</h4>

1500<p id="_336" tabindex="-1">

1501A personal history of BCC or SCC is strongly associated with subsequent BCC or SCC. There is an approximate 20% increased risk of a subsequent lesion within the first year after a skin cancer has been diagnosed. The mean age of occurrence for these cancers is the mid-60s.[<a href="#cit/section_3.7">

15027</a>

1503-<a href="#cit/section_3.12">

150412</a>

1505] In addition, several studies have found that individuals with a history of BCC or SCC have an increased risk (range, 9%&#8211;61%) of a subsequent diagnosis of a noncutaneous cancer;[<a href="#cit/section_3.13">

150613</a>

1507-<a href="#cit/section_3.18">

150818</a>

1509] however, other studies have contradicted this finding.[<a href="#cit/section_3.19">

151019</a>

1511-<a href="#cit/section_3.22">

151222</a>

1513] In the absence of other risk factors or evidence of a defined cancer susceptibility syndrome, as discussed below, skin cancer patients are encouraged to follow screening recommendations for the general population for sites other than the skin.</p>

1514</section>

1515</section>

1516<section id="_12">

1517<h3 id="_12_toc">

1518Major Genes for Basal Cell Carcinoma</h3>

1519<section id="_209">

1520<h4 id="_209_toc">

1521<em class="gene-name">

1522PTCH1</em>

1523</h4>

1524<p id="_210" tabindex="-1">

1525Inherited <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=783960&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000783960&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1526pathogenic variants</a>

1527 in the <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45693&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045693&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1528gene</a>

1529 coding for the transmembrane receptor protein PTCH1, or PTCH, are associated with basal cell nevus syndrome (BCNS), and somatic <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46063&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046063&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1530mutations</a>

1531 are associated with <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=339347&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000339347&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1532sporadic</a>

1533 cutaneous BCCs. <em class="gene-name">

1534PTCH1</em>

1535, the human homolog of the <em>

1536Drosophila</em>

1537 segment polarity gene patched (<em class="gene-name">

1538ptc</em>

1539), is an integral component of the hedgehog signaling pathway, which has many developmental (appendage development, embryonic segmentation, neural tube differentiation) and regulatory (maintenance of stem cells) roles. For more information, see the <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_16">

1540Basal cell nevus syndrome</a>

1541 section.</p>

1542<p id="_211" tabindex="-1">

1543In the resting state, the transmembrane receptor protein PTCH1 acts catalytically to suppress the seven-transmembrane protein Smoothened (Smo), preventing further downstream signal transduction.[<a href="#cit/section_3.23">

154423</a>

1545] Binding of the hedgehog ligand to PTCH1 releases inhibition of Smo, with resultant activation of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=390290&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000390290&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1546transcription</a>

1547 factors (GLI1, GLI2), cell proliferation genes (<em class="gene-name">

1548cyclin D</em>

1549, <em class="gene-name">

1550cyclin E</em>

1551, <em class="gene-name">

1552myc</em>

1553), and regulators of angiogenesis.[<a href="#cit/section_3.24">

155424</a>

1555,<a href="#cit/section_3.25">

155625</a>

1557] Thus, the balance of PTCH1 (inhibition) and Smo (activation) manages the essential regulatory downstream hedgehog signal transduction pathway. Loss-of-function pathogenic variants of PTCH1 or gain-of-function variants of Smo tip this balance toward activation, a key event in potential neoplastic transformation.</p>

1558<p id="_212" tabindex="-1">

1559Demonstration of allelic loss on <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46470&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046470&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1560chromosome</a>

1561 9q22 in both sporadic and <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460148&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460148&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1562familial</a>

1563 BCCs suggested the potential presence of an associated <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46657&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046657&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1564tumor suppressor gene</a>

1565.[<a href="#cit/section_3.26">

156626</a>

1567,<a href="#cit/section_3.27">

156827</a>

1569] Further investigation identified a pathogenic variant in <em class="gene-name">

1570PTCH1</em>

1571 that localized to the area of allelic loss.[<a href="#cit/section_3.28">

157228</a>

1573] Up to 30% of sporadic BCCs demonstrate <em class="gene-name">

1574PTCH1</em>

1575 pathogenic variants.[<a href="#cit/section_3.29">

157629</a>

1577] In addition to BCC, medulloblastoma and rhabdomyosarcoma, along with other tumors, have been associated with <em class="gene-name">

1578PTCH1</em>

1579 pathogenic variants. All three malignancies are associated with BCNS, and most people with clinical features of BCNS demonstrate <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460154&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460154&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1580germline</a>

1581 <em class="gene-name">

1582PTCH1</em>

1583 pathogenic variants, predominantly truncation in type.[<a href="#cit/section_3.30">

158430</a>

1585]</p>

1586</section>

1587<section id="_213">

1588<h4 id="_213_toc">

1589<em class="gene-name">

1590PTCH2</em>

1591</h4>

1592<p id="_214" tabindex="-1">

1593Truncating pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

1594PTCH2</em>

1595, a homolog of <em class="gene-name">

1596PTCH1</em>

1597 mapping to chromosome 1p32.1-32.3, have been seen in both BCC and medulloblastoma.[<a href="#cit/section_3.31">

159831</a>

1599,<a href="#cit/section_3.32">

160032</a>

1601] <em class="gene-name">

1602PTCH2</em>

1603 displays 57% homology to <em class="gene-name">

1604PTCH1</em>

1605.[<a href="#cit/section_3.33">

160633</a>

1607] While the exact role of <em class="gene-name">

1608PTCH2</em>

1609 remains unclear, there is evidence to support its involvement in the hedgehog signaling pathway.[<a href="#cit/section_3.31">

161031</a>

1611,<a href="#cit/section_3.34">

161234</a>

1613] However, the role of this gene in BCNS has been contested.[<a href="#cit/section_3.35">

161435</a>

1615]</p>

1616</section>

1617</section>

1618<section id="_1030">

1619<h3 id="_1030_toc">

1620Putative Genes for Basal Cell Carcinoma</h3>

1621<section id="_1028">

1622<h4 id="_1028_toc">

1623BRCA1-associated protein 1 (<em class="gene-name">

1624BAP1</em>

1625)</h4>

1626<p id="_1029" tabindex="-1">

1627Pathogenic variants in the <em class="gene-name">

1628BAP1</em>

1629 gene are associated with an increased risk of a variety of cancers, including cutaneous melanoma and uveal melanoma. Although the BCC <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=339344&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000339344&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1630penetrance</a>

1631 in individuals with pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

1632BAP1</em>

1633 is not known, there are several <em class="gene-name">

1634BAP1</em>

1635 families that report diagnoses of BCC.[<a href="#cit/section_3.36">

163636</a>

1637,<a href="#cit/section_3.37">

163837</a>

1639] In one study, pathogenic variant <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460132&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460132&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1640carriers</a>

1641 from four families reported diagnoses of BCC. Tumor evaluation of <em class="gene-name">

1642BAP1</em>

1643 showed loss of BAP1 protein expression by immunohistochemistry in BCCs of two germline <em class="gene-name">

1644BAP1</em>

1645 pathogenic variant carriers but not in 53 sporadic BCCs.[<a href="#cit/section_3.36">

164636</a>

1647] A second report noted that four individuals from families with <em class="gene-name">

1648BAP1</em>

1649 germline pathogenic variants were diagnosed with a total of 19 BCCs. Complete loss of BAP1 nuclear expression was observed in 17 of 19 BCCs from these individuals but none of 22 control BCC specimens.[<a href="#cit/section_3.38">

165038</a>

1651] Loss of BAP1 nuclear expression was also reported in a series of 7 BCCs from individuals with loss of function <em class="gene-name">

1652BAP1</em>

1653 variants, but only in 1 of 31 sporadic BCCs.[<a href="#cit/section_3.39">

165439</a>

1655] For more information, see the section on <em class="gene-name">

1656<a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_786">

1657BAP1</a>

1658</em>

1659 in the Melanoma section.</p>

1660</section>

1661<section id="_1283">

1662<h4 id="_1283_toc">

1663<em class="gene-name">

1664MC1R</em>

1665</h4>

1666<p id="_1034" tabindex="-1">

1667A meta-analysis showed that the more <em class="gene-name">

1668MC1R</em>

1669 pathogenic variants an individual carried, the higher his/her risk was to develop SCC and BCC. Individuals with two or more <em class="gene-name">

1670MC1R</em>

1671 pathogenic variants had a summary OR of 2.48 (95% CI, 1.96&#8211;3.15) for BCC and a summary OR of 2.80 (95% CI, 1.71&#8211;4.57) for SCC; these risks increased when individuals had red hair.[<a href="#cit/section_3.40">

167240</a>

1673] A study of individuals diagnosed with BCC before age 40 years also found a stronger association between BCC and <em class="gene-name">

1674MC1R</em>

1675 pathogenic variants in those with phenotypic characteristics that are not traditionally considered high risk. For more information, see the section on <em class="gene-name">

1676<a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_359">

1677MC1R</a>

1678</em>

1679 in the Melanoma section.[<a href="#cit/section_3.41">

168041</a>

1681] </p>

1682</section>

1683</section>

1684<section id="_14">

1685<h3 id="_14_toc">

1686Syndromes Associated With a Predisposition to Basal Cell Carcinoma</h3>

1687<section id="_16">

1688<h4 id="_16_toc">

1689Basal cell nevus syndrome</h4>

1690<p id="_218" tabindex="-1">

1691 BCNS, also known as Gorlin Syndrome, Gorlin-Goltz syndrome, and nevoid BCC syndrome, is an <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=793860&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000793860&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1692autosomal dominant</a>

1693 disorder with an estimated prevalence of 1 in 57,000 individuals.[<a href="#cit/section_3.42">

169442</a>

1695] The syndrome is notable for complete penetrance and high levels of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=339331&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000339331&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1696variable expressivity</a>

1697, as evidenced by evaluation of individuals with identical <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=660739&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000660739&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1698genotypes</a>

1699 but widely varying phenotypes.[<a href="#cit/section_3.30">

170030</a>

1701,<a href="#cit/section_3.43">

170243</a>

1703] The clinical features of BCNS differ more among families than within families.[<a href="#cit/section_3.44">

170444</a>

1705] BCNS is primarily associated with <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=781852&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000781852&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1706germline pathogenic variants</a>

1707 in <em class="gene-name">

1708PTCH1</em>

1709, but families with this phenotype have also been associated with alterations in <em class="gene-name">

1710PTCH2</em>

1711 and <em class="gene-name">

1712SUFU</em>

1713.[<a href="#cit/section_3.45">

171445</a>

1715-<a href="#cit/section_3.47">

171647</a>

1717]</p>

1718<p id="_219" tabindex="-1">

1719As detailed above, <em class="gene-name">

1720PTCH1</em>

1721 provides both developmental and regulatory guidance; spontaneous or inherited germline pathogenic variants of <em class="gene-name">

1722PTCH1</em>

1723 in BCNS may result in a wide spectrum of potentially diagnostic physical findings. The BCNS pathogenic variant has been localized to chromosome 9q22.3-q31, with a maximum <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=415709&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000415709&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1724logarithm of the odd (LOD) score</a>

1725 of 3.597 and 6.457 at markers D9S12 and D9S53.[<a href="#cit/section_3.42">

172642</a>

1727] The resulting <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=781846&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000781846&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1728haploinsufficiency</a>

1729 of <em class="gene-name">

1730PTCH1</em>

1731 in BCNS has been associated with structural anomalies such as odontogenic keratocysts, with evaluation of the cyst lining revealing <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=464169&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000464169&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1732loss of heterozygosity</a>

1733 (LOH) for <em class="gene-name">

1734PTCH1</em>

1735.[<a href="#cit/section_3.48">

173648</a>

1737] The development of BCC and other BCNS-associated malignancies is thought to arise from the classic two-hit suppressor gene model: baseline heterozygosity secondary to germline <em class="gene-name">

1738PTCH1</em>

1739 pathogenic variant as the first hit, with the second hit due to mutagen exposure such as UV or ionizing radiation.[<a href="#cit/section_3.49">

174049</a>

1741-<a href="#cit/section_3.53">

174253</a>

1743] However, haploinsufficiency or dominant negative isoforms have also been implicated for the inactivation of <em class="gene-name">

1744PTCH1</em>

1745.[<a href="#cit/section_3.54">

174654</a>

1747]</p>

1748<p id="_220" tabindex="-1">

1749The diagnosis of BCNS is typically based upon characteristic clinical and radiological examination findings. Several sets of clinical diagnostic criteria for BCNS are in use (for more information, see <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_726">

1750Table 1</a>

1751).[<a href="#cit/section_3.55">

175255</a>

1753-<a href="#cit/section_3.58">

175458</a>

1755] Although each set of criteria has advantages and disadvantages, none of the sets have a clearly superior balance of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=322883&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000322883&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1756sensitivity</a>

1757 and <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=322884&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000322884&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1758specificity</a>

1759 for identifying carriers of pathogenic variants. The BCNS Colloquium Group proposed criteria in 2011 that required 1 major criterion with molecular diagnosis, two major criteria without molecular diagnosis, or one major and two minor criteria without molecular diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_3.58">

176058</a>

1761] <em class="gene-name">

1762PTCH1</em>

1763 pathogenic variants are found in 60% to 85% of patients who meet clinical criteria.[<a href="#cit/section_3.59">

176459</a>

1765,<a href="#cit/section_3.60">

176660</a>

1767] Most notably, BCNS is associated with the formation of both benign and malignant neoplasms. The strongest benign neoplasm association is with ovarian fibromas, diagnosed in 14% to 24% of females <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460124&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460124&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1768affected</a>

1769 by BCNS.[<a href="#cit/section_3.52">

177052</a>

1771,<a href="#cit/section_3.56">

177256</a>

1773,<a href="#cit/section_3.61">

177461</a>

1775] BCNS-associated ovarian fibromas are more likely to be bilateral and calcified than sporadic ovarian fibromas.[<a href="#cit/section_3.62">

177662</a>

1777] Ameloblastomas, aggressive tumors of the odontogenic epithelium in the jaw, have also been proposed as a diagnostic criterion for BCNS, but most groups do not include it at this time.[<a href="#cit/section_3.63">

177863</a>

1779]</p>

1780<p id="_221" tabindex="-1">

1781Other associated benign neoplasms include gastric hamartomatous polyps,[<a href="#cit/section_3.64">

178264</a>

1783] <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460137&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460137&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

1784congenital</a>

1785 pulmonary cysts,[<a href="#cit/section_3.65">

178665</a>

1787] cardiac fibromas,[<a href="#cit/section_3.66">

178866</a>

1789] meningiomas,[<a href="#cit/section_3.67">

179067</a>

1791-<a href="#cit/section_3.69">

179269</a>

1793] craniopharyngiomas,[<a href="#cit/section_3.70">

179470</a>

1795] fetal rhabdomyomas,[<a href="#cit/section_3.71">

179671</a>

1797] leiomyomas,[<a href="#cit/section_3.72">

179872</a>

1799] mesenchymomas,[<a href="#cit/section_3.73">

180073</a>

1801] basaloid follicular hamartomas,[<a href="#cit/section_3.74">

180274</a>

1803] and nasal dermoid tumors. Development of meningiomas and

1804ependymomas occurring postradiation therapy has been documented in the general pediatric population; radiation therapy for syndrome-associated intracranial processes may be partially responsible for a subset of these benign tumors in individuals with BCNS.[<a href="#cit/section_3.75">

180575</a>

1806-<a href="#cit/section_3.77">

180777</a>

1808] In addition, radiation therapy of malignant medulloblastomas in the BCNS population may result in many cutaneous BCCs in the radiation ports. Similarly, treatment of BCC of the skin with radiation therapy may result in induction of large numbers of additional BCCs.[<a href="#cit/section_3.51">

180951</a>

1810,<a href="#cit/section_3.52">

181152</a>

1812,<a href="#cit/section_3.72">

181372</a>

1814]</p>

1815<p id="_456" tabindex="-1">

1816The diagnostic criteria for BCNS are described

1817in <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_726">

1818Table 1</a>

1819 below.</p>

1820<table id="_726" class="table-default expandable-container">

1823<colgroup>

183355</a>

1834]</th>

183756</a>

1909plantar pits</a>

1910</td>

1911<td>

1913<td>

1914&#8805;3 palmar or plantar pits</td>

1933First-degree relative</a>

1934 with BCNS</td>

1935<td>

2073</tr>

2074</tbody>

2075</table>

2076<p id="_222" tabindex="-1">

2077Of greatest concern with BCNS are associated malignant neoplasms, the most common of which is BCC. BCC in individuals with BCNS may appear during childhood as small <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=781843&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000781843&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2078acrochordon</a>

2079-like lesions, while larger lesions demonstrate more classic cutaneous features.[<a href="#cit/section_3.78">

208078</a>

2081] Nonpigmented BCCs are more common than pigmented lesions.[<a href="#cit/section_3.79">

208279</a>

2083] The age at first BCC diagnosis associated with BCNS ranges from 3 to 53 years, with a mean age of 21.4 years; the vast majority of individuals are diagnosed with their first BCC before age 20 years.[<a href="#cit/section_3.56">

208456</a>

2085,<a href="#cit/section_3.61">

208661</a>

2087] Most BCCs are located on sun-exposed sites, but individuals with greater than 100 BCCs have a more uniform distribution of BCCs over the body.[<a href="#cit/section_3.79">

208879</a>

2089] Case series have suggested that

2090up to 1 in 200 individuals with BCC demonstrate findings supportive of a diagnosis of BCNS.[<a href="#cit/section_3.42">

209142</a>

2092] BCNS has rarely been reported in individuals with darker skin pigmentation; however, significantly fewer BCCs are found in individuals of African or Mediterranean ancestry.[<a href="#cit/section_3.56">

209356</a>

2094,<a href="#cit/section_3.80">

209580</a>

2096,<a href="#cit/section_3.81">

209781</a>

2098] Despite the rarity of BCC in this population, reported cases document full expression of the noncutaneous manifestations of BCNS.[<a href="#cit/section_3.81">

209981</a>

2100] However, in individuals of African ancestry who have received radiation therapy, significant basal cell tumor burden has been reported within the radiation port distribution.[<a href="#cit/section_3.56">

210156</a>

2102,<a href="#cit/section_3.72">

210372</a>

2104] Thus, cutaneous pigmentation may protect against the mutagenic effects of UV but not against ionizing radiation.</p>

2105<p id="_906" tabindex="-1">

2106<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=776887&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000776887&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2107Variants</a>

2108 in other genes associated with an increased risk of BCC in the general population appear to modify the age of BCC onset in individuals with BCNS. A study of 125 individuals with BCNS found that a variant in <em class="gene-name">

2109MC1R</em>

2110 (Arg151Cys) was associated with an early median age of onset of 27 years (95% CI, 20&#8211;34), compared with individuals who did not carry the risk <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=339337&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000339337&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2111allele</a>

2112 and had a median age of BCC of 34 years (95% CI, 30&#8211;40) (HR, 1.64; 95% CI, 1.04&#8211;2.58, <em>

2113P</em>

2114 = .034). A variant in the <em class="gene-name">

2115TERT-CLPTM1L</em>

2116 gene showed a similar effect, with individuals with the risk allele having a median age of BCC of 31 years (95% CI, 28&#8211;37) relative to a median onset of 41 years (95% CI, 32&#8211;48) in individuals who did not carry a risk allele (HR, 1.44; 95% CI, 1.08&#8211;1.93, <em>

2117P</em>

2118 = .014).[<a href="#cit/section_3.82">

211982</a>

2120]</p>

2121<p id="_223" tabindex="-1">

2122Many other malignancies have been associated with BCNS. Medulloblastoma carries the strongest association with BCNS and is diagnosed in 1% to 5% of BCNS cases. While BCNS-associated medulloblastoma is typically diagnosed between ages 2 and 3 years, sporadic medulloblastoma is usually diagnosed later in childhood, between the ages of 6 and 10 years.[<a href="#cit/section_3.52">

212352</a>

2124,<a href="#cit/section_3.56">

212556</a>

2126,<a href="#cit/section_3.61">

212761</a>

2128,<a href="#cit/section_3.83">

212983</a>

2130] A desmoplastic phenotype occurring around age 2 years is very strongly associated with BCNS and carries a more favorable prognosis than sporadic classic medulloblastoma.[<a href="#cit/section_3.84">

213184</a>

2132,<a href="#cit/section_3.85">

213385</a>

2134] Up to three times more males than females with BCNS are diagnosed with medulloblastoma.[<a href="#cit/section_3.86">

213586</a>

2136] As with other malignancies, treatment of medulloblastoma with ionizing radiation has resulted in numerous BCCs within the radiation field.[<a href="#cit/section_3.52">

213752</a>

2138,<a href="#cit/section_3.67">

213967</a>

2140] Other reported malignancies include ovarian carcinoma,[<a href="#cit/section_3.87">

214187</a>

2142] ovarian fibrosarcoma,[<a href="#cit/section_3.88">

214388</a>

2144,<a href="#cit/section_3.89">

214589</a>

2146] astrocytoma,[<a href="#cit/section_3.90">

214790</a>

2148] melanoma,[<a href="#cit/section_3.91">

214991</a>

2150] Hodgkin disease,[<a href="#cit/section_3.92">

215192</a>

2152,<a href="#cit/section_3.93">

215393</a>

2154] rhabdomyosarcoma,[<a href="#cit/section_3.94">

215594</a>

2156] and undifferentiated sinonasal carcinoma.[<a href="#cit/section_3.95">

215795</a>

2158]</p>

2159<p id="_224" tabindex="-1">

2160Odontogenic keratocysts&#8211;or keratocystic odontogenic tumors (KCOTs), as renamed by the World Health Organization working group&#8211;are one of the major features of BCNS.[<a href="#cit/section_3.96">

216196</a>

2162] Demonstration of clonal LOH of common tumor suppressor genes, including <em class="gene-name">

2163PTCH1</em>

2164, supports the transition of terminology to reflect a neoplastic process.[<a href="#cit/section_3.48">

216548</a>

2166] Less than one-half of KCOTs from individuals with BCNS show LOH of <em class="gene-name">

2167PTCH1</em>

2168.[<a href="#cit/section_3.54">

216954</a>

2170,<a href="#cit/section_3.97">

217197</a>

2172] The tumors are lined with a thin squamous epithelium and a thin corrugated layer of parakeratin. Increased mitotic activity in the tumor epithelium and potential budding of the basal layer with formation of daughter cysts within the tumor wall may be responsible for the high rates of recurrence post simple enucleation.[<a href="#cit/section_3.96">

217396</a>

2174,<a href="#cit/section_3.98">

217598</a>

2176] In a recent case series of 183 consecutively excised KCOTs, 6% of individuals demonstrated an association with BCNS.[<a href="#cit/section_3.96">

217796</a>

2178] A study that analyzed the rate of <em class="gene-name">

2179PTCH1</em>

2180 pathogenic variants in BCNS-associated KCOTs found that 11 of 17 individuals carried a germline <em class="gene-name">

2181PTCH1</em>

2182 pathogenic variant and an additional 3 individuals had somatic mutations in this gene.[<a href="#cit/section_3.99">

218399</a>

2184] Individuals with germline <em class="gene-name">

2185PTCH1</em>

2186 pathogenic variants had an early age of KCOT presentation. KCOTs occur in 65% to 100% of individuals with BCNS,[<a href="#cit/section_3.56">

218756</a>

2188,<a href="#cit/section_3.100">

2189100</a>

2190] with higher rates of occurrence in young females.[<a href="#cit/section_3.101">

2191101</a>

2192]</p>

2193<p id="_740" tabindex="-1">

2194Palmoplantar pits are another major finding in BCC and occur in 70% to 80% of individuals with BCNS.[<a href="#cit/section_3.61">

219561</a>

2196] When these pits occur together with early-onset BCC and/or KCOTs, they are considered diagnostic for BCNS.[<a href="#cit/section_3.102">

2197102</a>

2198]</p>

2199<p id="_225" tabindex="-1">

2200Several characteristic radiological findings have been associated with BCNS, including lamellar calcification of falx cerebri in the brain;[<a href="#cit/section_3.103">

2201103</a>

2202,<a href="#cit/section_3.104">

2203104</a>

2204] fused, splayed or bifid ribs;[<a href="#cit/section_3.105">

2205105</a>

2206] and flame-shaped lucencies or pseudocystic bone lesions of

2207the phalanges, carpal, tarsal, long bones, pelvis, and calvaria by diagnostic x-ray imaging.[<a href="#cit/section_3.60">

220860</a>

2209] Imaging for rib abnormalities may be useful when establishing a BCNS diagnosis in young children, who may not have fully manifested BCNS features that are detected during physical examination. The presence of skeletal abnormalities appears to affect BCC number and severity in affected individuals. In one study, individuals with BCNS and skeletal findings had a mean of 120 more BCCs than those who had BCNS without skeletal findings. Individuals with two or more skeletal changes also had an increased risk of advanced or metastatic BCC (OR, 2.45; 95% CI, 1.01&#8211;5.91).[<a href="#cit/section_3.106">

2210106</a>

2211]</p>

2212<p id="_924" tabindex="-1">

2213<a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_925">

2214Table 2</a>

2215 summarizes the frequency and median age of onset of nonmalignant findings associated with BCNS.</p>

2216<table id="_925" class="table-default expandable-container">

2217<caption>

2218Table 2. Frequency of Nonmalignant Findings in Basal Cell Nevus Syndrome (BCNS)</caption>

2219<colgroup>

2220<col width="33.33%">

2221<col width="33.33%">

2222<col width="33.33%">

2223</colgroup>

2224<THead>

2225<tr>

2226<th>

2227Finding</th>

2228<th>

2229Frequency (%)</th>

2230<th>

2231Median Age of Onset</th>

2232</tr>

2233</THead>

2234<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

2235<tr>

2236<td colspan="3">

2237Adapted from a report by Kimonis et al. [<a href="#cit/section_3.56">

223856</a>

2239] about 105 individuals with BCNS seen at the National Institutes of Health between 1985 and 1997.</td>

2240</tr>

2241</TFoot>

2242<tbody>

2243<tr>

2244<td>

2245Palmar/plantar pits</td>

2246<td>

224787</td>

2248<td>

2249Usually by age 10 y</td>

2250</tr>

2251<tr>

2252<td>

2253Keratogenic jaw cysts</td>

2254<td>

225574</td>

2256<td>

2257Usually by age 20 y</td>

2258</tr>

2259<tr>

2260<td>

2261Bridged sella</td>

2262<td>

226368</td>

2264<td>

2265Congenital</td>

2266</tr>

2267<tr>

2268<td>

2269Calcification of falx cerebri</td>

2270<td>

227165</td>

2272<td>

2273Usually by age 40 y</td>

2274</tr>

2275<tr>

2276<td>

2277Macrocephaly</td>

2278<td>

227950</td>

2280<td>

2281Congenital</td>

2282</tr>
