2285Hypertelorism</td>

2286<td>

228742</td>

2288<td>

2289Congenital</td>

2290</tr>

2291<tr>

2292<td>

2293Osseous lucencies in the hands</td>

2294<td>

229530</td>

2296<td>

2297Congenital</td>

2298</tr>

2299<tr>

2300<td>

2301Frontal bossing</td>

2302<td>

230327</td>

2304<td>

2305Congenital</td>

2306</tr>

2307<tr>

2308<td>

2309Bifid ribs</td>

2310<td>

231126</td>

2312<td>

2313Congenital</td>

2314</tr>

2315<tr>

2316<td>

2317Calcification of tentorium cerebelli</td>

2318<td>

231920</td>

2320<td>

2321Not reported</td>

2322</tr>

2323<tr>

2324<td>

2325Ovarian fibromas</td>

2326<td>

232717</td>

2328<td>

232930 y</td>

2330</tr>

2331<tr>

2332<td>

2333Hemivertebra</td>

2334<td>

233515</td>

2336<td>

2337Congenital</td>

2338</tr>

2339<tr>

2340<td>

2341Pectus deformity</td>

2342<td>

234311</td>

2344<td>

2345Congenital</td>

2346</tr>

2347<tr>

2348<td>

2349Fusion of vertebral bodies</td>

2350<td>

235110</td>

2352<td>

2353Congenital</td>

2354</tr>

2355<tr>

2356<td>

2357Cleft lip/palate</td>

2358<td>

23593</td>

2360<td>

2361Congenital</td>

2362</tr>

2363</tbody>

2364</table>

2365<p id="_897" tabindex="-1">

2366Individuals with <em class="gene-name">

2367PTCH2</em>

2368 pathogenic variants may have a milder phenotype of BCNS than those with <em class="gene-name">

2369PTCH1</em>

2370 variants. Characteristic features such as palmar/plantar pits, macrocephaly, falx calcification, hypertelorism, and coarse face may be absent in these individuals.[<a href="#cit/section_3.107">

2371107</a>

2372]</p>

2373<p id="_724" tabindex="-1">

2374A 9p22.3 microdeletion syndrome that includes the <em class="gene-name">

2375PTCH1</em>

2376 <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460162&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460162&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2377locus</a>

2378 has been described in ten children.[<a href="#cit/section_3.108">

2379108</a>

2380] All patients had facial features typical of BCNS, including a broad forehead, but they had other features variably including craniosynostosis, hydrocephalus, macrosomia, and developmental delay. At the time of the report, none had basal cell skin cancer. On the basis of their <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=778725&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000778725&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2381hemizygosity</a>

2382 of the <em class="gene-name">

2383PTCH1</em>

2384 gene, these patients are presumably at an increased risk of basal cell skin cancer.</p>

2385<p id="_883" tabindex="-1">

2386Germline pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

2387SUFU</em>

2388, a major negative regulator of the hedgehog pathway, have been identified in a small number of individuals with a clinical phenotype resembling that of BCNS.[<a href="#cit/section_3.46">

238946</a>

2390,<a href="#cit/section_3.47">

239147</a>

2392,<a href="#cit/section_3.109">

2393109</a>

2394] These pathogenic variants were first identified in individuals with childhood medulloblastoma,[<a href="#cit/section_3.110">

2395110</a>

2396] and the incidence of medulloblastoma appears to be much higher in individuals with BCNS associated with <em class="gene-name">

2397SUFU</em>

2398 pathogenic variants than in those with <em class="gene-name">

2399PTCH1</em>

2400 variants.[<a href="#cit/section_3.46">

240146</a>

2402] <em class="gene-name">

2403SUFU</em>

2404 pathogenic variants may also be associated with an increased predisposition to meningioma.[<a href="#cit/section_3.69">

240569</a>

2406,<a href="#cit/section_3.109">

2407109</a>

2408,<a href="#cit/section_3.111">

2409111</a>

2410] Conversely, odontogenic jaw keratocysts appear less frequently in this population. Some clinical laboratories offer genetic testing for <em class="gene-name">

2411SUFU</em>

2412 pathogenic variants for individuals with BCNS who do not have an identifiable <em class="gene-name">

2413PTCH1</em>

2414 variant.</p>

2415</section>

2416<section id="_1202">

2417<h4 id="_1202_toc">

2418DNA repair genes</h4>

2419<p id="_1203" tabindex="-1">

2420In addition to pathogenic variants in genes primarily associated with BCC, other cancer-associated genes may confer an increased risk for BCC. A study of 61 individuals with a high number of BCCs (mean, 11 BCCs; range, 6&#8211;65) underwent genetic testing for 29 high-penetrance cancer <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=256553&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000256553&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2421susceptibility</a>

2422 genes. Thirteen pathogenic variants were found in 12 of 61 individuals (19.7%). This was higher than expected compared with individuals in the Exome Aggregation Consortium (ExAC) database (3%). All of the genes with pathogenic variants were involved in <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45671&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045671&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2423DNA</a>

2424 repair, suggesting that defects in DNA repair pathways may increase the risk of BCC. Of these 61 individuals, 21 (34.4%) had a previous diagnosis of another cancer including melanoma, breast, colon, and prostate cancers. </p>

2425</section>

2426<section id="_1178">

2427<h4 id="_1178_toc">

2428Xeroderma pigmentosum</h4>

2429<p id="_1265" tabindex="-1">

2430Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP) is a <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=754220&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000754220&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2431hereditary disorder</a>

2432 of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460201&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460201&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2433nucleotide</a>

2434 excision repair that results in cutaneous malignancies in the first decade of life.[<a href="#cit/section_3.112">

2435112</a>

2436] <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460124&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460124&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2437Affected</a>

2438 individuals have an increased sensitivity to sunlight, resulting in a markedly increased risk of SCCs, BCCs, and melanomas. For more information, see the section on <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_126">

2439Xeroderma pigmentosum</a>

2440 in the Squamous Cell Carcinoma section.</p>

2441</section>

2442<section id="_18">

2443<h4 id="_18_toc">

2444Rare syndromes</h4>

2445<section id="_226">

2446<h5 id="_226_toc">

2447Rombo syndrome</h5>

2448<p id="_227" tabindex="-1">

2449Rombo syndrome is a very rare genodermatosis or genetic disorder associated with BCC. It is thought to have an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern, and it has been outlined in three case series in the literature.[<a href="#cit/section_3.113">

2450113</a>

2451-<a href="#cit/section_3.115">

2452115</a>

2453] The cutaneous examination is within normal limits until age 7 to 10 years, with the development of distinctive <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44019&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000044019&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

2454cyanotic</a>

2455 <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44589&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000044589&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

2456erythema</a>

2457 of the lips, hands, and feet and early atrophoderma vermiculatum of the cheeks, with variable involvement of the elbows and dorsal hands and feet.[<a href="#cit/section_3.113">

2458113</a>

2459] Development of BCC occurs in the fourth decade.[<a href="#cit/section_3.113">

2460113</a>

2461] A distinctive grainy texture to the skin, secondary to interspersed small, yellowish, follicular-based papules and follicular atrophy, has been described.[<a href="#cit/section_3.113">

2462113</a>

2463,<a href="#cit/section_3.115">

2464115</a>

2465] Missing, irregularly distributed, and/or misdirected eyelashes and eyebrows are another associated finding.[<a href="#cit/section_3.113">

2466113</a>

2467,<a href="#cit/section_3.114">

2468114</a>

2469] The genetic basis of Rombo syndrome is not known.</p>

2470</section>

2471<section id="_228">

2472<h5 id="_228_toc">

2473Bazex-Dupr&#233;-Christol syndrome</h5>

2474<p id="_229" tabindex="-1">

2475Bazex-Dupr&#233;-Christol syndrome, another rare <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=695591&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000695591&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2476genodermatosis</a>

2477 associated with development of BCC, has more thorough documentation in the literature than Rombo syndrome. Inheritance is accomplished in an <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=781206&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000781206&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2478X-linked dominant</a>

2479 fashion, with no reported male-to-male transmission.[<a href="#cit/section_3.116">

2480116</a>

2481-<a href="#cit/section_3.118">

2482118</a>

2483] Regional assignment of the locus of interest to chromosome Xq24-q27 is associated with a maximum LOD score of 5.26 with the DXS1192 locus.[<a href="#cit/section_3.119">

2484119</a>

2485] Further work has narrowed the potential location to an 11.4-Mb interval on chromosome Xq25-27; however, the causative gene remains unknown.[<a href="#cit/section_3.120">

2486120</a>

2487]</p>

2488<p id="_230" tabindex="-1">

2489Characteristic physical findings include <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=789006&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000789006&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

2490hypotrichosis</a>

2491, <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=789008&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000789008&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

2492hypohidrosis</a>

2493, milia, follicular atrophoderma of the cheeks, and multiple BCC, which manifest in the late second decade to early third decade.[<a href="#cit/section_3.116">

2494116</a>

2495] Documented hair changes with Bazex-Dupr&#233;-Christol syndrome include reduced density of scalp and body hair, decreased melanization,[<a href="#cit/section_3.121">

2496121</a>

2497] a twisted/flattened appearance of the hair shaft on electron microscopy,[<a href="#cit/section_3.122">

2498122</a>

2499] and increased hair shaft diameter on polarizing light microscopy.[<a href="#cit/section_3.118">

2500118</a>

2501] The milia, which may be quite distinctive in childhood, have been reported to regress or diminish substantially at puberty.[<a href="#cit/section_3.118">

2502118</a>

2503] Other reported findings in association with this syndrome include trichoepitheliomas; hidradenitis suppurativa; hypoplastic alae; and a prominent columella, the fleshy terminal portion of the nasal septum.[<a href="#cit/section_3.123">

2504123</a>

2505,<a href="#cit/section_3.124">

2506124</a>

2507]</p>

2508</section>

2509<section id="_529">

2510<h5 id="_529_toc">

2511Epidermolysis bullosa simplex</h5>

2512<p id="_530" tabindex="-1">

2513A rare, severe subtype of epidermolysis bullosa simplex (EBS), previously known as Dowling-Meara (EBS-DM), is primarily inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion and is associated with pathogenic variants in either keratin-5 (<em class="gene-name">

2514KRT5</em>

2515) or keratin-14 (<em class="gene-name">

2516KRT14</em>

2517).[<a href="#cit/section_3.125">

2518125</a>

2519,<a href="#cit/section_3.126">

2520126</a>

2521] This severe subtype of EBS occasionally results in mortality in early childhood.[<a href="#cit/section_3.127">

2522127</a>

2523] It has an estimated prevalence of 0.02 per million individuals in the United States and an incidence of 1.16 per million live births.[<a href="#cit/section_3.128">

2524128</a>

2525] One report cites an incidence of BCC of 44% by age 55 years in this population.[<a href="#cit/section_3.129">

2526129</a>

2527] Individuals who inherit two EBS pathogenic variants may present with a more severe phenotype.[<a href="#cit/section_3.130">

2528130</a>

2529] Other less phenotypically severe subtypes of EBS can also be caused by pathogenic variants in either <em class="gene-name">

2530KRT5</em>

2531 or <em class="gene-name">

2532KRT14</em>

2533.[<a href="#cit/section_3.125">

2534125</a>

2535] Approximately 75% of individuals with a clinical diagnosis of EBS (regardless of subtype) have <em class="gene-name">

2536KRT5</em>

2537 or <em class="gene-name">

2538KRT14</em>

2539 pathogenic variants.[<a href="#cit/section_3.131">

2540131</a>

2541] </p>

2542</section>

2543</section>

2544<p id="_457" tabindex="-1">

2545Characteristics of hereditary syndromes associated with a predisposition to BCC are described in <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_276">

2546Table 3</a>

2547 below.</p>

2548<table id="_276" class="table-default expandable-container">

2549<caption>

2550Table 3. Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC) Syndromes</caption>

2551<colgroup>

2552<col width="35.78%">

2553<col width="5.56%">

2554<col width="32.22%">

2555<col width="26.43%">

2556</colgroup>

2557<THead>

2558<tr>

2559<th>

2560Syndrome</th>

2561<th>

2562Inheritance</th>

2563<th>

2564Gene or Chromosomal Loci</th>

2565<th>

2566Clinical Findings</th>

2567</tr>

2568</THead>

2569<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

2570<tr>

2571<td colspan="4">

2572AD = autosomal dominant;

2573AR = <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=339339&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000339339&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2574autosomal recessive</a>

2575; SCC = squamous cell carcinoma; XD = X-linked dominant.</td>

2576</tr>

2577</TFoot>

2578<tbody>

2579<tr>

2580<td>

2581Basal cell nevus syndrome,

2582Gorlin syndrome

2583

2584</td>

2585<td>

2586AD</td>

2587<td>

2588<em class="gene-name">

2589PTCH1</em>

2590,[<a href="#cit/section_3.132">

2591132</a>

2592,<a href="#cit/section_3.133">

2593133</a>

2594] <em class="gene-name">

2595PTCH2</em>

2596,[<a href="#cit/section_3.45">

259745</a>

2598] <em class="gene-name">

2599SUFU</em>

2600 [<a href="#cit/section_3.69">

260169</a>

2602]</td>

2603<td>

2604BCC (before age 20 y)</td>

2605</tr>

2606<tr>

2607<td>

2608Rombo syndrome

2609</td>

2610<td>

2611AD</td>

2612<td>

2613Unknown</td>

2614<td>

2615Milia,

2616atrophoderma vermiculatum,

2617acrocyanosis,

2618trichoepitheliomas, and

2619BCC (age 30&#8211;40 y)</td>

2620</tr>

2621<tr>

2622<td>

2623Bazex-Dupr&#233;-Christol syndrome

2624</td>

2625<td>

2626XD &gt; AD</td>

2627<td>

2628Xq24-27 [<a href="#cit/section_3.119">

2629119</a>

2630]</td>

2631<td>

2632Hypotrichosis (variable),[<a href="#cit/section_3.116">

2633116</a>

2634]

2635hypohidrosis,

2636milia,

2637follicular atrophoderma (dorsal hands), and

2638multiple BCCs (aged teens to early 20s) [<a href="#cit/section_3.116">

2639116</a>

2640]

2641</td>

2642</tr>

2643<tr>

2644<td>

2645Brooke-Spiegler syndrome</td>

2646<td>

2647AD</td>

2648<td>

2649<em class="gene-name">

2650CYLD</em>

2651 [<a href="#cit/section_3.134">

2652134</a>

2653,<a href="#cit/section_3.135">

2654135</a>

2655] </td>

2656<td>

2657Cylindroma (forehead, scalp, trunk, and pubic area),[<a href="#cit/section_3.136">

2658136</a>

2659,<a href="#cit/section_3.137">

2660137</a>

2661]

2662trichoepithelioma (around nose),

2663spiradenoma, and

2664BCC

2665</td>

2666</tr>

2667<tr>

2668<td>

2669Multiple hereditary infundibulocystic BCC</td>

2670<td>

2671AD [<a href="#cit/section_3.138">

2672138</a>

2673] </td>

2674<td>

2675Unknown</td>

2676<td>

2677Multiple BCC (infundibulocystic type)</td>

2678</tr>

2679<tr>

2680<td>

2681Schopf-Schultz-Passarge syndrome</td>

2682<td>

2683AR &gt; AD</td>

2684<td>

2685Unknown</td>

2686<td>

2687Ectodermal dysplasia (hypotrichosis,

2688hypodontia, and

2689<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=800270&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000800270&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2690nail dystrophy</a>

2691 [anonychia and trachyonychia]), hidrocystomas of eyelids, palmoplantar keratosis and hyperhidrosis, and BCC [<a href="#cit/section_3.139">

2692139</a>

2693]</td>

2694</tr>

2695<tr>

2696<td>

2697Xeroderma pigmentosum</td>

2698<td>

2699AR</td>

2700<td>

2701<em class="gene-name">

2702XPA</em>

2703, <em class="gene-name">

2704XPB</em>

2705/<em class="gene-name">

2706ERCC3</em>

2707, <em class="gene-name">

2708XPC</em>

2709, <em class="gene-name">

2710XPD</em>

2711/<em class="gene-name">

2712ERCC2</em>

2713, <em class="gene-name">

2714XPE</em>

2715/<em class="gene-name">

2716DDB2</em>

2717, <em class="gene-name">

2718XPF</em>

2719/<em class="gene-name">

2720ERCC4</em>

2721, <em class="gene-name">

2722XPG</em>

2723/<em class="gene-name">

2724ERCC5</em>

2725</td>

2726<td>

2727SCC, BCC, melanoma, severe sun sensitivity, ophthalmologic and neurologic abnormalities</td>

2728</tr>

2729<tr>

2730<td>

2731Xeroderma pigmentosum variant</td>

2732<td>

2733AR</td>

2734<td>

2735<em class="gene-name">

2736POLH</em>

2737</td>

2738<td>

2739SCC, BCC, melanoma, severe sun sensitivity, ophthalmologic abnormalities</td>

2740</tr>

2741</tbody>

2742</table>

2743<p id="_502" tabindex="-1">

2744For more information, see the <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_65">

2745Brooke-Spiegler Syndrome, Multiple Familial Trichoepithelioma, and Familial Cylindromatosis</a>

2746 section.</p>

2747</section>

2748<section id="_266">

2749<h3 id="_266_toc">

2750Interventions</h3>

2751<section id="_267">

2752<h4 id="_267_toc">

2753Screening</h4>

2754<p id="_268" tabindex="-1">

2755As detailed further below, the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force does not recommend regular screening for the early detection of any cutaneous malignancies, including BCC. However, once a BCC is detected on the skin of an individual, the National Comprehensive Cancer Network recommends that he/she have a complete skin examination biannually or annually for the first 5 years after the BCC is detected. After 5 years, skin examinations are recommended at least once a year for life.[<a href="#cit/section_3.140">

2756140</a>

2757]</p>

2758<p id="_898" tabindex="-1">

2759<a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_900">

2760Table 4</a>

2761 summarizes available clinical practice guidelines for the <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=496506&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000496506&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2762surveillance</a>

2763 of individuals with BCNS.</p>

2764<table id="_900" class="table-default expandable-container">

2765<caption>

2766Table 4. Available Recommendations for Surveillance in BCNS</caption>

2767<colgroup>

2768<col width="5.11%">

2769<col width="94.88%">

2770</colgroup>

2771<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

2772<tr>

2773<td colspan="2">

2774MRI = magnetic resonance imaging.</td>

2775</tr>

2776<tr>

2777<td colspan="2">

2778Adapted from Bree et al.[<a href="#cit/section_3.58">

277958</a>

2780] and Foulkes et al.[<a href="#cit/section_3.141">

2781141</a>

2782]</td>

2783</tr>

2784</TFoot>

2785<tbody>

2786<tr>

2787<td colspan="2">

2788<strong>

2789For Adults:</strong>

2790</td>

2791</tr>

2792<tr>

2793<td colspan="2">

2794&#8226; MRI of brain (baseline)</td>

2795</tr>

2796<tr>

2797<td colspan="2">

2798&#8226; Skin examination every 4 months</td>

2799</tr>

2800<tr>

2801<td colspan="2">

2802&#8226; Panorex of jaw every year</td>

2803</tr>

2804<tr>

2805<td colspan="2">

2806&#8226; Neurological evaluation (if previous medulloblastoma)</td>

2807</tr>

2808<tr>

2809<td colspan="2">

2810&#8226; Pelvic ultrasound (baseline)</td>

2811</tr>

2812<tr>

2813<td colspan="2">

2814&#8226; Gynecologic examination every year</td>

2815</tr>

2816<tr>

2817<td colspan="2">

2818&#8226; Nutritional assessment </td>

2819</tr>

2820<tr>

2821<td colspan="2">

2822&#8226; Fetal assessment for hydrocephalus, macrocephaly, and cardiac fibromas in pregnancy</td>

2823</tr>

2824<tr>

2825<td colspan="2">

2826&#8226; Minimization of diagnostic radiation exposure when feasible</td>

2827</tr>

2828<tr>

2829<td colspan="2">

2830<strong>

2831For Children:</strong>

2832</td>

2833</tr>

2834<tr>

2835<td colspan="2">

2836&#8226; MRI of brain (annually until age 8 years) [<a href="#cit/section_3.58">

283758</a>

2838]</td>

2839</tr>

2840<tr>

2841<td>

2842&#160;</td>

2843<td>

2844&#8226; Low risk (<em class="gene-name">

2845PTCH1</em>

2846): No radiographic screening unless concerning neurological exam, head circumference change, or other unusual signs/symptoms [<a href="#cit/section_3.141">

2847141</a>

2848]</td>

2849</tr>

2850<tr>

2851<td>

2852&#160;</td>

2853<td>

2854&#8226; High risk (<em class="gene-name">

2855SUFU</em>

2856): Brain MRI every 4 months through age 3 years, then every 6 months until age 5 years [<a href="#cit/section_3.141">

2857141</a>

2858]</td>

2859</tr>

2860<tr>

2861<td colspan="2">

2862&#8226; Cardiac ultrasound (baseline)</td>

2863</tr>

2864<tr>

2865<td colspan="2">

2866&#8226; Dermatologic examination (baseline)</td>

2867</tr>

2868<tr>

2869<td>

2870&#160;</td>

2871<td>

2872&#8226; Annual by age 10 years, increased frequency after first basal cell carcinoma is diagnosed [<a href="#cit/section_3.141">

2873141</a>

2874]</td>

2875</tr>

2876<tr>

2877<td colspan="2">

2878&#8226; Panorex of jaw (baseline, then annually if no cysts apparent; after the first cyst is diagnosed, every 6 months until age 21 years or until no cysts are noted for two years)</td>

2879</tr>

2880<tr>

2881<td>

2882&#160;</td>

2883<td>

2884&#8226; Beginning at age 8 years, then every 12&#8211;18 months [<a href="#cit/section_3.141">

2885141</a>

2886]</td>

2887</tr>

2888<tr>

2889<td>

2890&#160;</td>

2891<td>

2892&#8226; Some dermatologists recommend waiting until symptomatic to begin Panorex in order to limit radiation exposure [<a href="#cit/section_3.141">

2893141</a>

2894]</td>

2895</tr>

2896<tr>

2897<td colspan="2">

2898&#8226; Spine film at age 1 year or time of diagnosis (if abnormal, follow scoliosis protocol)</td>

2899</tr>

2900<tr>

2901<td colspan="2">

2902&#8226; Pelvic ultrasound at menarche or age 18 years</td>

2903</tr>

2904<tr>

2905<td colspan="2">

2906&#8226; Hearing, speech, and ophthalmologic evaluation</td>

2907</tr>

2908<tr>

2909<td colspan="2">

2910&#8226; Minimization of diagnostic radiation exposure when feasible</td>

2911</tr>

2912</tbody>

2913</table>

2914<p id="_816" tabindex="-1">

2915<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=526280&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000526280&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

2916Level of evidence: 5</a>

2917</p>

2918</section>

2919<section id="_269">

2920<h4 id="_269_toc">

2921Primary prevention</h4>

2922<p id="_270" tabindex="-1">

2923Avoidance of excessive cumulative and sporadic sun exposure is important in reducing the risk of BCC, along with other cutaneous malignancies. Scheduling activities outside of the peak hours of UV radiation, utilizing sun-protective clothing and hats, using sunscreen liberally, and strictly avoiding tanning beds are all reasonable steps towards minimizing future risk of skin cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_3.142">

2924142</a>

2925] For patients with particular <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=256553&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000256553&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

2926genetic susceptibility</a>

2927 (such as BCNS), avoidance or minimization of ionizing radiation is essential to reducing future tumor burden.</p>

2928<p id="_817" tabindex="-1">

2929<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=531812&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000531812&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

2930Level of evidence: 2aii</a>

2931</p>

2932</section>

2933<section id="_271">

2934<h4 id="_271_toc">

2935Chemoprevention</h4>

2936<p id="_272" tabindex="-1">

2937The role of various systemic retinoids, including isotretinoin and acitretin, has been explored in the chemoprevention and treatment of multiple BCCs, particularly in BCNS patients. In one study of isotretinoin use in 12 patients with multiple BCCs, including 5 patients with BCNS, tumor regression was noted, with decreasing efficacy as the tumor diameter increased.[<a href="#cit/section_3.143">

2938143</a>

2939] However, the results were insufficient to recommend use of systemic retinoids for treatment of BCC. Three additional patients, including one with BCNS, were followed long-term for evaluation of chemoprevention with isotretinoin, demonstrating significant decrease in the number of tumors per year during treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_3.143">

2940143</a>

2941] Although the rate of tumor development tends to increase sharply upon discontinuation of systemic retinoid therapy, in some patients the rate remains lower than their pretreatment rate, allowing better management and control of their cutaneous malignancies.[<a href="#cit/section_3.143">

2942143</a>

2943-<a href="#cit/section_3.145">

2944145</a>

2945] In summary, the use of systemic retinoids for chemoprevention of BCC is reasonable in high-risk patients, including patients with xeroderma pigmentosum. For more information, see the <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_20">

2946Squamous Cell Carcinoma</a>

2947 section.</p>

2948<p id="_274" tabindex="-1">

2949A patient&#8217;s cumulative and evolving tumor load should be evaluated carefully in light of the potential long-term use of a medication class with cumulative and idiosyncratic side effects. Given the possible side-effect profile, systemic retinoid use is best managed by a practitioner with particular expertise and comfort with the medication class. However, for all potentially childbearing women, strict avoidance of pregnancy during the systemic retinoid course&#8212;and for 1 month after completion of isotretinoin and 3 years after completion of acitretin&#8212;is essential to avoid potentially fatal and devastating fetal malformations. In the United States, isotretinoin can only be prescribed through the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA)-mandated <a href="https://ipledgeprogram.com/#Main" title="https://ipledgeprogram.com/#Main">

2950iPledge</a>

2951 program.</p>

2952<p id="_818" tabindex="-1">

2953<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=531812&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000531812&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

2954Level of evidence (retinoids): 2aii</a>

2955</p>

2956<p id="_701" tabindex="-1">

2957In a phase II study of 41 patients with BCNS, vismodegib (an inhibitor of the hedgehog pathway) has been shown to reduce the per-patient annual rate of new BCCs requiring surgery.[<a href="#cit/section_3.146">

2958146</a>

2959] Existing BCCs also regressed for these patients during daily treatment with 150 mg of oral vismodegib. While patients treated had visible regression of their tumors, biopsy demonstrated residual microscopic malignancies at the site, and tumors progressed after the discontinuation of the therapy. Adverse effects included taste disturbance, muscle cramps, hair loss, and weight loss and led to discontinuation of the medication in 54% of subjects. A subsequent, open-label, phase II study included 37 patients from the same cohort who continued vismodegib for up to a total of 36 months.[<a href="#cit/section_3.147">

2960147</a>

2961] Patients treated with vismodegib had a lower mean incidence of new, surgically eligible BCCs than did placebo-treated patients (<em>

2962P</em>

2963 &lt; .0001). However, only 17% of patients tolerated continuous vismodegib for the full 36 months. Tumors reappeared after treatment was stopped, but patients who resumed treatment again experienced tumor response. The duration of benefit after stopping vismodegib appeared to be proportional to the duration and compliance of taking the drug during treatment. Intermittent dosing schedules of vismodegib (8 weeks on/8 weeks off after an initial schedule of daily dosing for 24 weeks or 12 weeks on/8 weeks off) have also been shown to be effective in the reduction of BCCs in the BCNS population, although there has been no direct comparison between continuous dosing and intermittent dosing schedules.[<a href="#cit/section_3.148">

2964148</a>

2965] On the basis of the side-effect profile and rate of disease recurrence after discontinuation of the medication, additional study regarding optimal dosing of vismodegib is ongoing.</p>

2966<p id="_702" tabindex="-1">

2967<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=526277&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000526277&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

2968Level of evidence (vismodegib): 1aii</a>

2969</p>

2970<p id="_955" tabindex="-1">

2971A phase III, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial evaluated the effects of oral nicotinamide (vitamin B<sub>

29723</sub>

2973) in 386 individuals with a history of at least two keratinocyte carcinomas (BCC or SCC) within 5 years before study enrollment.[<a href="#cit/section_3.149">

2974149</a>

2975] After 12 months of treatment, those taking nicotinamide 500 mg twice daily had a 20% reduction in the incidence of new BCCs (95% CI, 6%&#8211;39%; <em>

2976P</em>

2977 = .12). The rate of new keratinocyte carcinomas was 23% lower in the nicotinamide group (95% CI, 4%&#8211;38%; <em>

2978P</em>

2979 = .02) than in the placebo group. No clinically significant differences in adverse events were observed between the two groups, and there was no evidence of benefit after discontinuation of nicotinamide. Of note, this study was not conducted in a population with an identified genetic predisposition to BCC.</p>

2980<p id="_956" tabindex="-1">

2981<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=526277&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000526277&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

2982Level of evidence (nicotinamide): 1aii</a>

2983</p>

2984</section>

2985<section id="_466">

2986<h4 id="_466_toc">

2987Treatment</h4>

2988<p id="_467" tabindex="-1">

2989Treatment of individual BCCs in BCNS is generally the same as for sporadic basal cell cancers. Due to the large number of lesions on some patients, this can present a surgical challenge. Field therapy with imiquimod or photodynamic therapy are attractive options, as they can treat multiple tumors simultaneously.[<a href="#cit/section_3.150">

2990150</a>

2991,<a href="#cit/section_3.151">

2992151</a>

2993] However, given the radiosensitivity of patients with BCNS, radiation as a therapeutic option for large tumors should be avoided.[<a href="#cit/section_3.56">

299456</a>

2995] There are no randomized trials, but the isolated case reports suggest that field therapy has similar results as in sporadic basal cell cancer, with higher success rates for superficial cancers than for nodular cancers.[<a href="#cit/section_3.150">

2996150</a>

2997,<a href="#cit/section_3.151">

2998151</a>

2999]</p>

3000<p id="_899" tabindex="-1">

3001Consensus guidelines for the use of methylaminolevulinate photodynamic therapy in BCNS recommend that this modality may best be used for superficial BCC of all sizes and for nodular BCC less than 2 mm thick.[<a href="#cit/section_3.152">

3002152</a>

3003] Monthly therapy with photodynamic therapy may be considered for these patients as clinically indicated. </p>

3004<p id="_492" tabindex="-1">

3005<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=531845&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000531845&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3006Level of evidence (imiquimod and photodynamic therapy): 4</a>

3007</p>

3008<p id="_957" tabindex="-1">

3009Topical treatment with LDE225, a Smoothened agonist, has also been investigated for the treatment of BCC in a small number of patients with BCNS with promising results;[<a href="#cit/section_3.153">

3010153</a>

3011] however, this medication is not approved in this formulation by the FDA.

3012</p>

3013<p id="_958" tabindex="-1">

3014<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=531829&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000531829&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3015Level of evidence (LDE225): 1</a>

3016</p>

3017<p id="_821" tabindex="-1">

3018In addition to its effects on the prevention of BCCs in patients with BCNS, vismodegib may also have a palliative effect on KCOTs found in this population. An initial report indicated that the use of GDC-0449, the hedgehog pathway inhibitor now known as vismodegib, resulted in resolution of KCOTs in one patient with BCNS.[<a href="#cit/section_3.154">

3019154</a>

3020] Another small study found that four of six patients who took 150 mg of vismodegib daily had a reduction in the size of KCOTs.[<a href="#cit/section_3.155">

3021155</a>

3022] None of the six patients in this study had new KCOTs or an increase in the size of existing KCOTs while being treated, and one patient had a sustained response that lasted 9 months after treatment was discontinued.</p>

3023<p id="_822" tabindex="-1">

3024<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=531844&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000531844&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3025Level of evidence (vismodegib): 3diii</a>

3026</p>

3027</section>

3028</section>

Am J Dermatopathol 15 (2): 156-61, 1993.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=7684205&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=7684205&amp;dopt=Abstract">

3574[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

3575</li>

3576<li id="section_3.137">

3577Rajan N, Langtry JA, Ashworth A, et al.: Tumor mapping in 2 large multigenerational families with CYLD mutations: implications for disease management and tumor induction. Arch Dermatol 145 (11): 1277-84, 2009.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19917957&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19917957&amp;dopt=Abstract">

3578[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

3579</li>

3580<li id="section_3.138">

3581Requena L, Fari&#241;a MC, Robledo M, et al.: Multiple hereditary infundibulocystic basal cell carcinomas: a genodermatosis different from nevoid basal cell carcinoma syndrome. Arch Dermatol 135 (10): 1227-35, 1999.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10522671&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10522671&amp;dopt=Abstract">

3582[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

3583</li>

3584<li id="section_3.139">

3585Nordin H, M&#229;nsson T, Svensson A: Familial occurrence of eccrine tumours in a family with ectodermal dysplasia. Acta Derm Venereol 68 (6): 523-30, 1988.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=2467492&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=2467492&amp;dopt=Abstract">

3586[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

3587</li>

3588<li id="section_3.140">

3589National Comprehensive Cancer Network: NCCN Clinical Practice Guidelines in Oncology: Basal Cell Skin Cancer. Version 2.2022. Plymouth Meeting, Pa: National Comprehensive Cancer Network, 2022. <a href="https://www.nccn.org/professionals/physician_gls/pdf/nmsc.pdf" title="https://www.nccn.org/professionals/physician_gls/pdf/nmsc.pdf">

3590Available online with free subscription</a>

3591 Last accessed August 22, 2023.</li>

3592<li id="section_3.141">

3593Foulkes WD, Kamihara J, Evans DGR, et al.: Cancer Surveillance in Gorlin Syndrome and Rhabdoid Tumor Predisposition Syndrome. Clin Cancer Res 23 (12): e62-e67, 2017.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28620006&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28620006&amp;dopt=Abstract">

3594[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

3595</li>

3596<li id="section_3.142">

3597Lin JS, Eder M, Weinmann S, et al.: Behavioral Counseling to Prevent Skin Cancer: Systematic Evidence Review to Update the 2003 U.S. Preventive Services Task Force Recommendation. Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality, 2011. Report No.: 11-05152-EF-1. <a href="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmedhealth/PMH0009693/pdf/PubMedHealth_PMH0009693.pdf" title="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmedhealth/PMH0009693/pdf/PubMedHealth_PMH0009693.pdf">

3598Also available online</a>

3599. Last accessed May 22, 2023.</li>

3600<li id="section_3.143">

3601Peck GL, DiGiovanna JJ, Sarnoff DS, et al.: Treatment and prevention of basal cell carcinoma with oral isotretinoin. J Am Acad Dermatol 19 (1 Pt 2): 176-85, 1988.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=3165982&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=3165982&amp;dopt=Abstract">

3602[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

3603</li>

3604<li id="section_3.144">

3605Goldberg LH, Hsu SH, Alcalay J: Effectiveness of isotretinoin in preventing the appearance of basal cell carcinomas in basal cell nevus syndrome. J Am Acad Dermatol 21 (1): 144-5, 1989.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=2745766&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=2745766&amp;dopt=Abstract">

3606[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

3607</li>

3608<li id="section_3.145">

3609Cristofolini M, Zumiani G, Scappini P, et al.: Aromatic retinoid in the chemoprevention of the progression of nevoid basal-cell carcinoma syndrome. J Dermatol Surg Oncol 10 (10): 778-81, 1984.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=6491017&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=6491017&amp;dopt=Abstract">

3611</li>

N Engl J Med 366 (23): 2180-8, 2012.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=22670904&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=22670904&amp;dopt=Abstract">

3614[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

3615</li>

3616<li id="section_3.147">

3617Tang JY, Ally MS, Chanana AM, et al.: Inhibition of the hedgehog pathway in patients with basal-cell nevus syndrome: final results from the multicentre, randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled, phase 2 trial. Lancet Oncol 17 (12): 1720-1731, 2016.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=27838224&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=27838224&amp;dopt=Abstract">

3618[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

3619</li>

3620<li id="section_3.148">

3621Dr&#233;no B, Kunstfeld R, Hauschild A, et al.: Two intermittent vismodegib dosing regimens in patients with multiple basal-cell carcinomas (MIKIE): a randomised, regimen-controlled, double-blind, phase 2 trial. Lancet Oncol 18 (3): 404-412, 2017.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28188086&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28188086&amp;dopt=Abstract">

3622[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

3623</li>

N Engl J Med 373 (17): 1618-26, 2015.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26488693&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26488693&amp;dopt=Abstract">

3626[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

3627</li>

3628<li id="section_3.150">

3629Stockfleth E, Ulrich C, Hauschild A, et al.: Successful treatment of basal cell carcinomas in a nevoid basal cell carcinoma syndrome with topical 5% imiquimod. Eur J Dermatol 12 (6): 569-72, 2002 Nov-Dec.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=12459530&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=12459530&amp;dopt=Abstract">

3631</li>

Dermatology 219 (2): 138-42, 2009.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19590166&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19590166&amp;dopt=Abstract">

3635</li>

3639</li>

3647</li>

3651</li>

3652</ol>

3653</div>

3654

3655 </section>

3656

3657

3658

3659 <section id="_20">

3660

3661 <h2>

3662Squamous Cell Carcinoma</h2>

3663

3664 <div id="_section_20" class="pdq-sections">

3665<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

3666<h6>

3667In This Section</h6>

3668<ul>

3669<li>

3670<a href="#_21_toc">

3671Introduction</a>

3672</li>

3673<li>

3674<a href="#_284_toc">

3675Risk Factors for Squamous Cell Carcinoma<ul>

3676<li>

3677<a href="#_337_toc">

3679</li>

3697</a>

3698</li>

3699<li>

3700<a href="#_23_toc">

3701Syndromes and Genes Associated With a Predisposition for Squamous Cell Carcinoma<ul>

3747</a>

3752MC1R</em>

3753</a>

3754</li>

3769</ul>

3770</nav>

3771<section id="_21">

3772<h3 id="_21_toc">

3773Introduction</h3>

3774<p id="_22" tabindex="-1">

3775Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is the second most common type of skin cancer and accounts for approximately 20% of cutaneous malignancies. Although most cancer registries do not include information on the incidence of keratinocyte carcinomas (basal cell carcinoma [BCC] and SCC), annual incidence estimates range from 1 million to 5.4 million cases in the United States.[<a href="#cit/section_4.1">

37761</a>

3777-<a href="#cit/section_4.3">

37783</a>

3779] Multiple studies indicate an increased risk of SCC after a first keratinocyte carcinoma; a meta-analysis and review of 45 studies estimated that after a primary SCC diagnosis, 13.3% of individuals would develop a second SCC (95% confidence interval [CI], 7.4%&#8211;22.8%).[<a href="#cit/section_4.4">

37804</a>

3781]</p>

3782<p id="_416" tabindex="-1">

3783 Mortality is rare from this cancer; however, the morbidity and costs associated with its treatment are considerable.</p>

3784</section>

3785<section id="_284">

3786<h3 id="_284_toc">

3787Risk Factors for Squamous Cell Carcinoma</h3>

3788<section id="_337">

3789<h4 id="_337_toc">

3790Sun exposure and other risk factors</h4>

3791<p id="_338" tabindex="-1">

3792Sun exposure is the major known environmental factor associated with the development of skin cancer of all types; however, different patterns of sun exposure are associated with each major type of skin cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_4.5">

37935</a>

3794-<a href="#cit/section_4.7">

37957</a>

3796] Unlike BCC, SCC is associated with chronic exposure, rather than intermittent, intense exposure to ultraviolet (UV) radiation. Occupational exposure is the characteristic pattern of sun exposure that is associated with SCC.[<a href="#cit/section_4.5">

37975</a>

3798] Other agents and factors associated with SCC risk include tanning beds, arsenic, therapeutic radiation (such as psoralen and UVA therapy for psoriasis), chronic skin ulceration, and immunosuppression.[<a href="#cit/section_4.8">

37998</a>

3800-<a href="#cit/section_4.16">

380116</a>

3802] For more information about exposures that can cause skin cancer in the general population, see <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-prevention-pdq">

3803Skin Cancer Prevention</a>

3804.</p>

3805</section>

3806<section id="_384">

3807<h4 id="_384_toc">

3808Characteristics of the skin</h4>

3809<p id="_385" tabindex="-1">

3810Like melanoma and BCC, SCC occurs more frequently in individuals with lighter skin than in those with darker skin.[<a href="#cit/section_4.5">

38115</a>

3812,<a href="#cit/section_4.17">

381317</a>

3814] A case-control study of 415 cases and 415 controls showed similar findings; relative to Fitzpatrick type I skin, individuals with increasingly darker skin had decreased risks of skin cancer (odds ratios [ORs], 0.6, 0.3, and 0.1, for Fitzpatrick types II, III, and IV, respectively).[<a href="#cit/section_4.18">

381518</a>

3816] The same study found that blue eyes and blond/red hair were also associated with increased risks of SCC, with crude ORs of 1.7 (95% CI, 1.2&#8211;2.3) for blue eyes, 1.5 (95% CI, 1.1&#8211;2.1) for blond hair, and 2.2 (95% CI, 1.5&#8211;3.3) for red hair. For more information, see the section on <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_304">

3817Pigmentary characteristics</a>

3818 in the Melanoma section.</p>

3819<p id="_943" tabindex="-1">

3820However, SCC can also occur in individuals with darker skin. An Asian registry based in Singapore reported an increase in skin cancer in that geographic area, with an incidence rate of 8.9 per 100,000 person-years. Incidence of SCC, however, was shown to be on the decline.[<a href="#cit/section_4.17">

382117</a>

3822] SCC is the most common form of skin cancer in Black individuals in the United States and in certain parts of Africa; the mortality rate for this disease is relatively high in these populations.[<a href="#cit/section_4.19">

382319</a>

3824,<a href="#cit/section_4.20">

382520</a>

3826] Epidemiologic characteristics of, and prevention strategies for, SCC in those individuals with darker skin remain areas of investigation.</p>

3827<p id="_386" tabindex="-1">

3828Freckling of the skin and reaction of the skin to sun exposure have been identified as other risk factors for SCC.[<a href="#cit/section_4.21">

382921</a>

3830] Individuals with heavy freckling on the forearm were found to have about a fourfold increase in SCC risk if moderate or heavy freckling was present in childhood or as an adult.[<a href="#cit/section_4.22">

383122</a>

3832] The degree of SCC risk corresponded to the amount of freckling. In this study, the inability of the skin to tan and its propensity to burn were also significantly associated with risk of SCC (OR of 1.54 for <em>

3833burn/blisters</em>

3834 and 12.44 for <em>

3835freckles/no tan</em>

3836).</p>

3837<p id="_387" tabindex="-1">

3838The presence of scars on the skin can also increase the risk of SCC, although the process of carcinogenesis in this setting may take years or even decades. SCCs arising in chronic wounds are referred to as Marjolin&#8217;s ulcers. The mean time for development of carcinoma in these wounds is estimated at 26 years.[<a href="#cit/section_4.23">

383923</a>

3840] One case report documents the occurrence of cancer in a wound that was incurred 59 years earlier.[<a href="#cit/section_4.24">

384124</a>

3842]</p>

3843</section>

3844<section id="_341">

3845<h4 id="_341_toc">

3846Immunosuppression</h4>

3847<p id="_342" tabindex="-1">

3848Immunosuppression also contributes to the formation of BCCs and SCCs. Among solid-organ transplant recipients, the risk of SCC is 65 to 250 times higher, and the risk of BCC is 10 times higher than that observed in the general population, although the risks vary with transplant type and with the immunosuppressive agent used.[<a href="#cit/section_4.25">

384925</a>

3850-<a href="#cit/section_4.28">

385128</a>

3852] BCCs and SCCs in high-risk patients (solid-organ transplant recipients and chronic lymphocytic leukemia patients) occur at a younger age, are more common and more aggressive, and have a higher risk of recurrence and metastatic spread than these cancers do in the general population.[<a href="#cit/section_4.29">

385329</a>

3854,<a href="#cit/section_4.30">

385530</a>

3856] Additionally, there is a high risk of second SCCs.[<a href="#cit/section_4.31">

385731</a>

3858,<a href="#cit/section_4.32">

385932</a>

3860] In one study, more than 65% of kidney transplant recipients developed subsequent SCCs after their first diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_4.31">

386131</a>

3862] Among Medicare patients with an intact immune system, BCCs occur as frequently as SCCs;[<a href="#cit/section_4.3">

38633</a>

3864] in transplant patients, SCCs outnumber BCCs by a 2:1 ratio.</p>

3865</section>

3866<section id="_345">

3867<h4 id="_345_toc">

3868Personal history of BCC, SCC, and melanoma skin cancers</h4>

3869<p id="_346" tabindex="-1">

3870A personal history of BCC or SCC is strongly associated with subsequent SCC. A study from Ireland showed that individuals with a history of BCC had a 14% higher incidence of subsequent SCC; for men with a history of BCC, the subsequent SCC risk was 27% higher.[<a href="#cit/section_4.33">

387133</a>

3872] In the same report, individuals with melanoma were also 2.5 times more likely to report a subsequent SCC. There is an approximate 20% increased risk of a subsequent lesion within the first year after a skin cancer has been diagnosed. The mean age of occurrence for these cancers is the middle of the sixth decade of life.[<a href="#cit/section_4.34">

387334</a>

3874-<a href="#cit/section_4.39">

387539</a>

3876]</p>

3877<p id="_981" tabindex="-1">

3878A Swedish study of 224 melanoma <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460211&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460211&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3879probands</a>

3880 and 944 of their <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460150&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460150&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3881first-degree relatives</a>

3882 (FDRs) from 154 <em class="gene-name">

3883CDKN2A</em>

3884 wild-type families and 11,680 matched controls showed that personal and family histories of melanoma increased the risk of SCC, with relative risks (RRs) of 9.1 (95% CI, 6.0&#8211;13.7) for personal history and 3.4 (95% CI, 2.2&#8211;5.2) for family history.[<a href="#cit/section_4.40">

388540</a>

3886] Another study of 216,115 individuals from the Nurses&#8217; Health Study, the Nurses&#8217; Health Study 2, and the Health Professionals Follow-Up Study found that individuals with a family history of melanoma showed a 22% increased risk of SCC (hazard ratio,1.22; 95% CI, 1.06&#8211;1.40).[<a href="#cit/section_4.41">

388741</a>

3888]</p>

3889</section>

3890<section id="_461">

3891<h4 id="_461_toc">

3892Family history of squamous cell carcinoma or associated premalignant lesions</h4>

3893<p id="_462" tabindex="-1">

3894Although the literature is scant on this subject, a family history of SCC may increase the risk of SCC in FDRs. In an independent survey-based study of 415 SCC cases and 415 controls, SCC risk was increased in individuals with a family history of SCC (adjusted OR, 3.4; 95% CI, 1.0&#8211;11.6), even after adjustment for skin type, hair color, and eye color.[<a href="#cit/section_4.18">

389518</a>

3896] This risk was elevated to an OR of 5.6 in those with a family history of melanoma (95% CI, 1.6&#8211;19.7), 9.8 in those with a family history of BCC (95% CI, 2.6&#8211;36.8), and 10.5 in those with a family history of multiple types of skin cancer (95% CI, 2.7&#8211;29.6). Review of the Swedish Family Center Database showed that individuals with at least one sibling or parent <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460124&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460124&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3897affected</a>

3898 with SCC, <em>

3899in situ</em>

3900 SCC (Bowen disease), or actinic keratosis had a twofold to threefold increased risk of invasive and <em>

3901in situ</em>

3902 SCC relative to the general population.[<a href="#cit/section_4.42">

390342</a>

3904,<a href="#cit/section_4.43">

390543</a>

3906] Increased number of tumors in parents was associated with increased risk to the offspring. Of note, diagnosis of the proband at an earlier age was not consistently associated with a trend of increased incidence of SCC in the FDR, as would be expected in most hereditary syndromes because of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460154&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460154&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3907germline</a>

3908 <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=783960&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000783960&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3909pathogenic variants</a>

3910. Further analysis of the Swedish population-based data estimates genetic risk effects of 8% and <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460148&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460148&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3911familial</a>

3912 shared-environmental effects of 18%.[<a href="#cit/section_4.44">

391344</a>

3914] Thus, shared environmental and behavioral factors likely account for some of the observed familial clustering of SCC.</p>

3915<p id="_991" tabindex="-1">

3916A study on the <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=781848&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000781848&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3917heritability</a>

3918 of cancer among 80,309 monozygotic and 123,382 dizygotic twins showed that NMSCs have a heritability of 43% (95% CI, 26%&#8211;59%), suggesting that almost half of the risk of NMSC is caused by inherited factors.[<a href="#cit/section_4.45">

391945</a>

3920] Additionally, the cumulative risk of NMSC was 1.9-fold higher for monozygotic than for dizygotic twins (95% CI, 1.8&#8211;2.0).[<a href="#cit/section_4.45">

392145</a>

3922]</p>

3923</section>

3924</section>

3925<section id="_23">

3926<h3 id="_23_toc">

3927Syndromes and Genes Associated With a Predisposition for Squamous Cell Carcinoma</h3>

3928<p id="_117" tabindex="-1">

3929Major <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45693&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045693&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3930genes</a>

3931 have been defined elsewhere in this summary as genes that are necessary and sufficient for disease, with important pathogenic variants of the gene as causal. The disorders resulting from single-gene pathogenic variants within families lead to a very high risk of disease and are relatively rare. The influence of the environment on the development of disease in individuals with these single-gene disorders is often very difficult to determine because of the rarity of the <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=776887&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000776887&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3932genetic variant</a>

3933.</p>

3934<p id="_118" tabindex="-1">

3935Identification of a strong environmental risk factor&#8212;chronic exposure to UV radiation&#8212;makes it difficult to apply genetic causation for SCC of the skin. Although the risk of UV exposure is well known, quantifying its <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=485393&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000485393&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

3936attributable risk</a>

3937 to cancer development has proven challenging. In addition, ascertainment of cases of SCC of the skin is not always straightforward. Many registries and other epidemiologic studies do not fully assess the incidence of SCC of the skin owing to: (1) the common practice of treating lesions suspicious for SCC without a diagnostic biopsy, and (2) the relatively low potential for metastasis. Moreover, NMSC is routinely excluded from the major cancer registries such as the Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results registry.</p>

3938<p id="_119" tabindex="-1">

3939With these considerations in mind, the discussion below will address genes associated with disorders that have an increased incidence of skin cancer. </p>

3940<p id="_458" tabindex="-1">

3941Characteristics of the major hereditary syndromes associated with a predisposition to SCC are described in <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_468">

3942Table 5</a>

3943 below.</p>

3944<table id="_468" class="table-default expandable-container">

3951</colgroup>
