4313<section id="_126">

4314<h4 id="_126_toc">

4315Xeroderma pigmentosum</h4>

4316<p id="_127" tabindex="-1">

4317Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP) is a hereditary disorder of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460201&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460201&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

4318nucleotide</a>

4319 excision repair that results in cutaneous malignancies in the first decade of life.[<a href="#cit/section_4.47">

432047</a>

4321] <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460124&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460124&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

4322Affected</a>

4323 individuals have an increased sensitivity to sunlight, resulting in a markedly increased risk of SCCs, BCCs, and melanomas. One report found that keratinocyte carcinomas (BCC and SCC) were increased 150-fold in individuals with XP; for those younger than 20 years, the prevalence has been estimated to be 5,000 to 10,000 times what would be expected in the general population.[<a href="#cit/section_4.48">

432448</a>

4325,<a href="#cit/section_4.49">

432649</a>

4327]</p>

4328<p id="_191" tabindex="-1">

4329The natural history of this disease begins in the first year of life, when sun sensitivity becomes apparent, and xerosis (dry skin) and pigmentary changes may occur in the sun-exposed skin. About one-half of XP patients have a history of severe burning on minimal sun exposure. Other XP patients do not have this reaction but develop freckle-like pigmentation before age 2 years on sun-exposed sites. These manifestations progress to skin atrophy and formation of telangiectasias. Approximately one-half of people with this disorder will develop BCC or SCC, and approximately one-quarter of these individuals will develop melanoma.[<a href="#cit/section_4.48">

433048</a>

4331] In the absence of sun avoidance, the median age of diagnosis for any skin cancer is 8 to 9 years.[<a href="#cit/section_4.48">

433248</a>

4333-<a href="#cit/section_4.50">

433450</a>

4335] On average, BCCs and SCCs occur at a younger age than melanoma in the XP population.[<a href="#cit/section_4.49">

433649</a>

4337]</p>

4338<p id="_192" tabindex="-1">

4339Noncutaneous manifestations of XP can include ophthalmologic, neurological, and aging abnormalities. Cornea and eyelids abnormalities in XP can be linked to UV radiation exposure. Examples of ophthalmologic abnormalities can include the following: keratitis, corneal opacification, ectropion, entropion, hyperpigmentation of the eyelids, loss of eyelashes, and cancer (including conjunctival and corneal cancers).[<a href="#cit/section_4.51">

434051</a>

4341] About 25% of the patients with XP examined at the National Institutes of Health (NIH) between 1971 and 2009 had progressive neurological degeneration.[<a href="#cit/section_4.49">

434249</a>

4343] Features of neurological degeneration can include the following: microcephaly, progressive sensorineural hearing loss, diminished deep tendon reflexes, seizures, and cognitive impairment. Neurological degeneration, which is most commonly observed in individuals with complementation groups XPA and XPD, was associated with a shorter lifespan (median age of death was 29 years in individuals with neurological degeneration and 37 years in individuals without neurological degeneration).[<a href="#cit/section_4.49">

434449</a>

4345] A subset of patients who have the skin and eye manifestations associated with XP also exhibit severe neurological manifestations, dwarfism, and delayed development. This severe form of XP is known as De Sanctis-Cacchione syndrome. Individuals with XP may also experience differences with aging. In a small study, 18 postmenopausal women with XP had a high frequency of premature aging, with a median age of menopause occurring at 29.5 years in the XP group (range, 18.0&#8211;49.5 y) and 52.9 years in the U.S. general population.[<a href="#cit/section_4.52">

434652</a>

4347]</p>

4348<p id="_1312" tabindex="-1">

4349A variety of noncutaneous neoplasms&#8211;most notably SCC on the tip of the tongue, central nervous system cancers, hematologic cancers, thyroid cancers, gynecologic cancers, and lung cancers in smokers&#8211;have been reported in people with XP.[<a href="#cit/section_4.48">

435048</a>

4351,<a href="#cit/section_4.53">

435253</a>

4353,<a href="#cit/section_4.54">

435454</a>

4355] The RR for internal cancers is estimated to be 34- to 50-fold higher in individuals with XP than in individuals in the general population.[<a href="#cit/section_4.48">

435648</a>

4357,<a href="#cit/section_4.54">

435854</a>

4359] A report on 434 patients with XP in four international cohorts (United States, United Kingdom, France, and Brazil) found an internal cancers rate of 11.3% in individuals with XP, with the average age of diagnosis occurring 50 years earlier than that of individuals in the general U.S. population. Patients with pathogenic variants in the <em class="gene-name">

4360XPC</em>

4361 gene (especially those from North Africa with a pathogenic delTG founder variant) had higher cancer risks than patients with pathogenic variants in other XP genes.[<a href="#cit/section_4.54">

436254</a>

4363]</p>

4364<p id="_193" tabindex="-1">

4365The inheritance for XP is autosomal recessive. Seven complementation groups have been associated with this disorder. About 40% of the XP cases seen at the NIH were XPC. <em class="gene-name">

4366ERCC2</em>

4367 (<em class="gene-name">

4368XPD</em>

4369) pathogenic variants were present in about 20%. Complementation group A, due to a pathogenic variant in <em class="gene-name">

4370XPA</em>

4371, accounts for approximately 10% of cases.[<a href="#cit/section_4.49">

437249</a>

4373] Other variant genes in this disorder include <em class="gene-name">

4374ERCC3</em>

4375 (<em class="gene-name">

4376XPB</em>

4377), <em class="gene-name">

4378DDB2</em>

4379 (<em class="gene-name">

4380XPE</em>

4381), <em class="gene-name">

4382ERCC4</em>

4383 (<em class="gene-name">

4384XPF</em>

4385), and <em class="gene-name">

4386ERCC5</em>

4387 (<em class="gene-name">

4388XPG</em>

4389). An XPH group had been described but is now considered to be a subgroup of the XPD group.[<a href="#cit/section_4.55">

439055</a>

4391] <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=339341&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000339341&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

4392Heterozygotes</a>

4393 for pathogenic variants in XP genes are generally asymptomatic.[<a href="#cit/section_4.56">

439456</a>

4395] However, one study reported a threefold increase in BCC in Japanese individuals who were heterozygous for <em class="gene-name">

4396XPA</em>

4397 pathogenic variants.[<a href="#cit/section_4.57">

439857</a>

4399] <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=783962&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000783962&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

4400Founder pathogenic variants</a>

4401 in <em class="gene-name">

4402XPA</em>

4403 (R228A) and <em class="gene-name">

4404XPC</em>

4405 (V548A fs X572) have been identified in North African populations, and a founder pathogenic variant in <em class="gene-name">

4406XPC</em>

4407 resulting in a <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=766216&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000766216&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

4408splice alteration</a>

4409 (IVS 12-1G&gt;C) has been found in an East African (Mahori) population. It has been proposed that direct screening for these pathogenic variants would be appropriate in these populations.[<a href="#cit/section_4.58">

441058</a>

4411-<a href="#cit/section_4.61">

441261</a>

4413] A founder pathogenic variant at the 3&#8217; splice acceptor site of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=660737&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000660737&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

4414intron</a>

4415 3 in the <em class="gene-name">

4416XPA</em>

4417 gene is present in approximately 1% of the population in Japan representing nearly 1 million people.[<a href="#cit/section_4.62">

441862</a>

4419] </p>

4420<p id="_194" tabindex="-1">

4421The function of the XP genes is to recognize and repair photoproducts from UV radiation. The main photoproducts are formed at adjacent pyrimidines and consist of cyclobutane dimers and pyrimidine-pyrimidone (6-4) photoproducts. The product of <em class="gene-name">

4422XPC</em>

4423 is involved in the initial identification of DNA damage; it binds to the lesion to act as a marker for further repair. The DDB2 (XPE) protein is also part of this process and works with XPC. The <em class="gene-name">

4424XPA</em>

4425 gene product maintains single-strand regions during repair and works with the TFIIH <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=390290&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000390290&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

4426transcription</a>

4427 factor complex. The TFIIH complex includes the gene products of both <em class="gene-name">

4428ERCC3</em>

4429 (<em class="gene-name">

4430XPB</em>

4431) and <em class="gene-name">

4432ERCC2</em>

4433 (<em class="gene-name">

4434XPD</em>

4435), which function as DNA helicases in the unwinding of the DNA. The ERCC4 (XPF) and ERCC5 (XPG) proteins act as DNA endonucleases to create single-strand nicks in the 5&#8217; and 3&#8217; sides of the damaged DNA with resulting

4436excision of about 28 to 30 nucleotides, including the

4437photoproduct. DNA polymerases replace the lesion with the correct sequence, and a DNA ligase completes the repair.[<a href="#cit/section_4.47">

443847</a>

4439,<a href="#cit/section_4.63">

444063</a>

4441]</p>

4442<p id="_505" tabindex="-1">

4443An XP variant that is associated with pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

4444POLH</em>

4445 (XPV) is responsible for approximately 10% of reported cases.[<a href="#cit/section_4.64">

444664</a>

4447] This gene encodes for the error-prone bypass polymerase (polymerase eta) which, unlike other genes associated with XP, is not involved in nucleotide excision repair. People with polymerase eta pathogenic variants have the same cutaneous and ocular findings as other XP patients but do not have progressive neurologic degeneration.[<a href="#cit/section_4.65">

444865</a>

4449] A founder pathogenic variant resulting in a <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460141&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460141&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

4450deletion</a>

4451 of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460146&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460146&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

4452exon</a>

4453 10 was seen in 16 of 16 individuals from ten Tunisian consanguineous families.[<a href="#cit/section_4.66">

445466</a>

4455]</p>

4456<p id="_195" tabindex="-1">

4457Work on <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=660739&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000660739&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

4458genotype</a>

4459-phenotype correlations among the XP complementation groups continues; however, evidence suggests that the specific pathogenic variant may have more influence on the phenotype than the complementation group.[<a href="#cit/section_4.47">

446047</a>

4461,<a href="#cit/section_4.67">

446267</a>

4463] The main distinguishing features appear to be the presence or absence of burning on minimal sun exposure, skin cancer, and progressive neurologic abnormalities. All complementation groups are characterized by the presence of cutaneous neoplasias, but skin cancers may be more common in XPC, XPE, and XPV groups.[<a href="#cit/section_4.67">

446467</a>

4465]. There is additional clinical variation within each complementation group. Mild to severe neurologic impairment has been described in individuals with <em class="gene-name">

4466XPA</em>

4467 pathogenic variants. Individuals with <em class="gene-name">

4468XPA</em>

4469 pathogenic variants in the DNA binding region (amino acids 98&#8211;219) may have a more severe presentation that includes neurological findings.[<a href="#cit/section_4.68">

447068</a>

4471] Individuals within the XPC complementation group have higher incidences of ocular damage.[<a href="#cit/section_4.67">

447267</a>

4473] A very small number of people in the XPB, XPD, and XPG complementation groups have been identified as having xeroderma pigmentosum-Cockayne syndrome (XP-CS) complex. These individuals have characteristics of both disorders, including an increased predisposition to cutaneous neoplasms and developmental delay, visual and hearing impairment, and central and peripheral nervous system dysfunction. It should be noted that people with Cockayne syndrome without XP do not appear to have an increased cancer risk.[<a href="#cit/section_4.69">

447469</a>

4475] Similarly, trichothiodystrophy (TTD) is another genetic disorder that can occur in combination with XP. Individuals affected solely with TTD do not appear to have an increased cancer incidence, but some affected with XP/TTD have an increased risk of cutaneous neoplasia. The complementation groups connected with XP/TTD (XPD and XPB) and XP-CS (XPB, XPD, and XPG) are associated with defects in both transcription-coupled nucleotide excision repair and global genomic nucleotide excision repair. In contrast, XP complementation groups C and E have defects only in global genomic nucleotide excision repair.[<a href="#cit/section_4.47">

447647</a>

4477,<a href="#cit/section_4.70">

447870</a>

4479] In addition, individuals in the XPA, XPD and XPG groups may exhibit severe neurologic abnormalities without symptoms of Cockayne syndrome or TTD. Cerebro-oculo-facio-skeletal syndrome, which has been described with some <em class="gene-name">

4480ERCC2</em>

4481 (<em class="gene-name">

4482XPD</em>

4483) or XP-CS pathogenic variants, does not appear to confer an increased risk of skin cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_4.71">

448471</a>

4485-<a href="#cit/section_4.74">

448674</a>

4487]</p>

4488<p id="_198" tabindex="-1">

4489The diagnosis of XP is made on the basis of clinical findings and family history. Functional assays to assess DNA repair capabilities after exposure to radiation have been developed, but these tests are currently not clinically available in the United States. Clinical genetic testing using sequence analysis to identify pathogenic variants is available for multiple XP-associated genes; the list can be found at the <a href="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/gtr/" title="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/gtr/">

4490NIH Genetic Testing Registry</a>

4491.</p>

4492</section>

4493<section id="_128">

4494<h4 id="_128_toc">

4495Multiple self-healing squamous epitheliomata (Ferguson-Smith syndrome)</h4>

4496<p id="_129" tabindex="-1">

4497Multiple self-healing squamous epitheliomata (MSSE), or Ferguson-Smith syndrome, first described in 1934, is characterized by invasive skin tumors that are histologically identical to <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=339347&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000339347&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

4498sporadic</a>

4499 cutaneous SCC, but they resolve spontaneously without intervention. <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=425374&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000425374&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

4500Linkage analysis</a>

4501 of affected families showed association with the long arm of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46470&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046470&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

4502chromosome</a>

4503 9, and <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=485392&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000485392&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

4504haplotype</a>

4505 analysis localized the gene to 9q22.3 between D9S197 and D9S1809.[<a href="#cit/section_4.75">

450675</a>

4507] Transforming growth factor beta-receptor 1 (<em class="gene-name">

4508TGFBR1</em>

4509) was identified through <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=763024&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000763024&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

4510next-generation sequencing</a>

4511 as the gene responsible for MSSE. Loss-of-function pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

4512TGFBR1</em>

4513 have been identified in 18 of 22 affected families.[<a href="#cit/section_4.76">

451476</a>

4515] Gain-of-function variants in <em class="gene-name">

4516TGFBR1</em>

4517 are associated with unrelated Marfan-like syndromes, such as Loeys-Dietz syndrome, which have no described increase in skin cancer risk.</p>

4518<p id="_130" tabindex="-1">

4519Somatic <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=464169&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000464169&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

4520loss of heterozygosity</a>

4521 in Ferguson-Smith&#8211;related SCC has been demonstrated at this genomic location, suggesting that <em class="gene-name">

4522TGFBR1</em>

4523 can act as a <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46657&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046657&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

4524tumor suppressor gene</a>

4525.[<a href="#cit/section_4.77">

452677</a>

4527] The long arm of chromosome 9 has also been a site of interest in sporadic SCC. Up to 65% of sporadic SCCs have been found to have loss of heterozygosity at 9q22.3 between D9S162 and D9S165.[<a href="#cit/section_4.77">

452877</a>

4529]</p>

4530</section>

4531<section id="_131">

4532<h4 id="_131_toc">

4533Oculocutaneous albinism</h4>

4534<p id="_582" tabindex="-1">

4535Albinism is a major risk factor for skin cancer in individuals of African ancestry.[<a href="#cit/section_4.20">

453620</a>

4537,<a href="#cit/section_4.78">

453878</a>

4539] One report describing a cohort of 350 albinos in Tanzania found 104 cutaneous cancers; of these, 100 were SCCs, three were BCCs, and one was melanoma.[<a href="#cit/section_4.79">

454079</a>

4541] The median age for this population was 10 years. Similar proportions of skin cancer diagnoses were observed in a Nigerian population, with 62% of dermatological malignancies diagnosed as SCC, 16% as melanoma, and 8% as BCC.[<a href="#cit/section_4.20">

454220</a>

4543] Of note, some melanomas found in individuals with albinism do contain melanin.[<a href="#cit/section_4.80">

454480</a>

4545]</p>

4546<p id="_1129" tabindex="-1">

4547SCC occurring at extremely early ages is a hallmark of oculocutaneous albinism. In a cohort of nearly 1,000 Nigerian patients with albinism, all had malignant or premalignant cutaneous lesions by age 20 years.[<a href="#cit/section_4.81">

454881</a>

4549]</p>

4550<p id="_132" tabindex="-1">

4551Two types of oculocutaneous albinism are known to be associated with increased risk of SCC of the skin. Oculocutaneous albinism type 1, or tyrosinase-related albinism, is caused by pathogenic variants in the tyrosinase gene, <em class="gene-name">

4552TYR</em>

4553, located on the long arm of chromosome 11. This type of albinism accounts for about one-half of cases in individuals of European ancestry.[<a href="#cit/section_4.82">

455482</a>

4555] The <em class="gene-name">

4556OCA2</em>

4557 gene, also known as the <em class="gene-name">

4558P</em>

4559 gene, is altered in oculocutaneous albinism type 2, or tyrosinase-positive albinism. Both disorders are autosomal recessive, with frequent <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=766214&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000766214&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

4560compound heterozygosity</a>

4561. A 2.7 kb intragenic deletion in the <em class="gene-name">

4562OCA2</em>

4563 gene is a common founder pathogenic variant in sub-Saharan Africa and accounts for most <em class="gene-name">

4564OCA2</em>

4565-related albinism cases in this region.[<a href="#cit/section_4.83">

456683</a>

4567]</p>

4568<p id="_133" tabindex="-1">

4569Tyrosinase acts as the critical enzyme in the synthesis of melanin in melanocytes. A variant in this gene in oculocutaneous albinism type 1 produces proteins with minimal to no activity, corresponding to the OCA1B and OCA1A phenotypes, respectively. Individuals with OCA1B have light skin, hair, and eye coloring at birth but develop some pigment during their lifetimes, while the coloring of those with OCA1A does not darken with age.</p>

4570<p id="_134" tabindex="-1">

4571The gene product of <em class="gene-name">

4572OCA2</em>

4573 is a protein found in the membrane of melanosomes. Its function is unknown, but it may play a role in maintaining the structure or pH of this environment.[<a href="#cit/section_4.84">

457484</a>

4575] Murine models with variants in this gene had significantly decreased melanin production compared with normal controls.[<a href="#cit/section_4.85">

457685</a>

4577] In one international study of individuals with albinism, <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=775789&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000775789&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

4578biallelic</a>

4579 variants in <em class="gene-name">

4580OCA2</em>

4581 were found in 17% of participants.[<a href="#cit/section_4.86">

458286</a>

4583]</p>

4584<p id="_823" tabindex="-1">

4585Genetic variants in <em class="gene-name">

4586SLC45A2</em>

4587 (<em class="gene-name">

4588MATP</em>

4589 associated with OCA4), <em class="gene-name">

4590SLC24A5</em>

4591 (associated with OCA6), and <em class="gene-name">

4592TYRP1</em>

4593 (tyrosinase-related

4594protein 1 associated with OCA3) are associated with less common types of oculocutaneous albinism.

4595Reported incidences for these genes in an international population of patients with albinism are 7% for <em class="gene-name">

4596SLC45A2</em>

4597, 1% for <em class="gene-name">

4598TYRP1</em>

4599, and less than 0.5% for <em class="gene-name">

4600SLC24A5</em>

4601.[<a href="#cit/section_4.86">

460286</a>

4603] <em class="gene-name">

4604SLC45A2</em>

4605 is found in 24% of oculocutaneous albinism cases in Japan, making it the most common type of albinism among Japanese individuals with identifiable

4606variants.[<a href="#cit/section_4.87">

460787</a>

4608] A study of 22 individuals of Italian ancestry without pathogenic variants in

4609<em class="gene-name">

4610TYR</em>

4611, <em class="gene-name">

4612OCA2</em>

4613, or <em class="gene-name">

4614TYRP1</em>

4615 found 5 individuals with biallelic variants in <em class="gene-name">

4616SLC45A2</em>

4617,

46184 of whom met clinical criteria for a diagnosis of oculocutaneous albinism.[<a href="#cit/section_4.88">

461988</a>

4620] Collectively, more than 600 unique ocular albinism&#8211;related genetic variants have been identified.[<a href="#cit/section_4.89">

462189</a>

4622]

4623The increased risk of SCC of the skin in people with these variants has not been

4624quantified. It is generally assumed to be similar to other types of albinism.

4625 Of note, a meta-analysis demonstrated that the <em class="gene-name">

4626SLC45A2</em>

4627 p.Phe374Leu variant was protective for melanoma, with an OR of 0.41 (95% CI, 0.33&#8211;0.50; <em>

4628P</em>

4629 = 3.50 x 10<span class="sup">

4630-17</span>

4631).[<a href="#cit/section_4.90">

463290</a>

4633] However, at this time, it should be noted that clinical testing is not routinely performed for protective variants.</p>

4634<p id="_1085" tabindex="-1">

4635Additional genes associated with oculocutaneous albinism have been found in small numbers of patients. <em class="gene-name">

4636OCA5</em>

4637, located on chromosome 4q24, has been identified in a Pakistani family, whereas OCA6 appears to be caused by pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

4638SLC24A5</em>

4639 on chromosome 15q21.[<a href="#cit/section_4.91">

464091</a>

4641-<a href="#cit/section_4.93">

464293</a>

4643] Pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

4644C10orf11</em>

4645 (<em class="gene-name">

4646LRMDA</em>

4647) cause OCA7, which has been found in patients from the Faroe Islands and Denmark.[<a href="#cit/section_4.94">

464894</a>

4649] Small numbers of pathogenic variant carriers have been reported to date. One woman with OCA6 had actinic keratosis, but the incidence of skin cancers in these populations is unknown.</p>

4650<p id="_1184" tabindex="-1">

4651Although oculocutaneous albinism is inherited as an autosomal recessive disorder in most instances, one study has found that heterozygous variants in genes such as <em class="gene-name">

4652TYR</em>

4653, <em class="gene-name">

4654OCA2</em>

4655, <em class="gene-name">

4656TYRP1</em>

4657, and <em class="gene-name">

4658SLC45A2</em>

4659 are overrepresented in families with multiple cases of melanoma. Further investigation is warranted to determine if these genes may be moderate <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=339344&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000339344&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

4660penetrance</a>

4661 melanoma susceptibility genes in heterozygotes.[<a href="#cit/section_4.95">

466295</a>

4663]</p>

4664<table id="_1134" class="table-default expandable-container">

4671<col width="31.88%">

4672<col width="17.39%">

4673</colgroup>

4678<th>

470096</a>

4701] Chinese,[<a href="#cit/section_4.97">

470297</a>

4703] White [<a href="#cit/section_4.98">

470498</a>

4705-<a href="#cit/section_4.102">

4706102</a>

4707]</td>

4708<td rowspan="2">

4709Yes</td>

4710</tr>

4711<tr>

4712<td>

47131B</td>

4714<td>

4715<em class="gene-name">

4716TYR</em>

4717</td>

4718</tr>

4719<tr>

4720<td>

4721OCA Type 2</td>

4722<td>

4723&#160;</td>

4724<td>

4725<em class="gene-name">

4726OCA2</em>

4727 (<em class="gene-name">

4728 Pgene</em>

4729)</td>

4730<td>

4731African,[<a href="#cit/section_4.103">

4732103</a>

4733,<a href="#cit/section_4.83">

473483</a>

4735,<a href="#cit/section_4.104">

4736104</a>

4737] African American,[<a href="#cit/section_4.105">

4738105</a>

4739] American Indian [<a href="#cit/section_4.106">

4740106</a>

4741]</td>

4742<td>

4743Yes</td>

4744</tr>

4745<tr>

4746<td>

4747OCA Type 3</td>

4748<td>

4749&#160;</td>

4750<td>

4751<em class="gene-name">

4752TYRP1</em>

4753</td>

4754<td>

4755African [<a href="#cit/section_4.107">

4756107</a>

4757]</td>

4758<td>

4759Yes</td>

4760</tr>

4761<tr>

4762<td>

4763OCA Type 4</td>

4764<td>

4765&#160;</td>

4766<td>

4767<em class="gene-name">

4768SLC45A2 </em>

4769(<em class="gene-name">

4770MATP</em>

4771)</td>

4772<td>

4773Japanese,[<a href="#cit/section_4.87">

477487</a>

4775] Italian,[<a href="#cit/section_4.88">

477688</a>

4777] German [<a href="#cit/section_4.108">

4778108</a>

4779]</td>

4780<td>

4781Yes</td>

4782</tr>

4783<tr>

4784<td>

4785OCA Type 5</td>

4786<td>

4787&#160;</td>

4788<td>

4789<em class="gene-name">

4790OCA5</em>

4791</td>

4792<td>

4793Pakistani [<a href="#cit/section_4.91">

479491</a>

4795]</td>

4796<td>

4797Not in the United States</td>

4798</tr>

4799<tr>

4800<td>

4801OCA Type 6</td>

4802<td>

4803&#160;</td>

4804<td>

4805<em class="gene-name">

4806SLC24A5</em>

4807</td>

4808<td>

4809Chinese,[<a href="#cit/section_4.92">

481092</a>

4811] African,[<a href="#cit/section_4.109">

4812109</a>

4813] European,[<a href="#cit/section_4.93">

481493</a>

4815] Indian [<a href="#cit/section_4.110">

4816110</a>

4817]</td>

4818<td>

4819Yes</td>

4820</tr>

4821<tr>

4822<td>

4823OCA Type 7</td>

4824<td>

4825&#160;</td>

4826<td>

4827<em class="gene-name">

4828C10orf11</em>

4829 (<em class="gene-name">

4830LRMDA</em>

4831)</td>

4832<td>

4833Faroe Islands,[<a href="#cit/section_4.94">

483494</a>

4835] Denmark [<a href="#cit/section_4.94">

483694</a>

4837]</td>

4838<td>

4839Yes</td>

4840</tr>

4841</tbody>

4842</table>

4843</section>

4844<section id="_546">

4845<h4 id="_546_toc">

4846Other albinism syndromes</h4>

4847<p id="_547" tabindex="-1">

4848A subgroup of albinism includes people who exhibit a triad of albinism, prolonged bleeding time, and deposition of a ceroid substance in organs such as the lungs and gastrointestinal tract. This syndrome, known as Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome, is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner but may have a pseudodominant inheritance in Puerto Rican families, owing to the high prevalence in this population.[<a href="#cit/section_4.111">

4849111</a>

4850] The underlying cause is believed to be a defect in melanosome and lysosome transport. A number of pathogenic variants at disparate <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460162&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460162&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

4851loci</a>

4852 have been associated with this syndrome, including <em class="gene-name">

4853HPS1</em>

4854, <em class="gene-name">

4855HPS3</em>

4856, <em class="gene-name">

4857HPS4</em>

4858, <em class="gene-name">

4859HPS5</em>

4860, <em class="gene-name">

4861HPS6</em>

4862, <em class="gene-name">

4863HPS7</em>

4864 (<em class="gene-name">

4865DTNBP1</em>

4866), <em class="gene-name">

4867HPS8</em>

4868 (<em class="gene-name">

4869BLOC1S3</em>

4870), and <em class="gene-name">

4871HPS9</em>

4872 (<em class="gene-name">

4873PLDN</em>

4874).[<a href="#cit/section_4.112">

4875112</a>

4876-<a href="#cit/section_4.119">

4877119</a>

4878] Pigmentation characteristics can vary significantly in this disorder, particularly among those with <em class="gene-name">

4879HPS1</em>

4880 pathogenic variants, and patients report darkening of the skin and hair as they age. In a small cohort of individuals with <em class="gene-name">

4881HPS1</em>

4882 variants, 3 out of 40 developed cutaneous SCCs, and an additional 3 had BCCs.[<a href="#cit/section_4.120">

4883120</a>

4884] Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome type 2, which includes increased susceptibility to infection resulting from <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460137&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460137&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

4885congenital</a>

4886 neutropenia, has been attributed to defects in <em class="gene-name">

4887AP3B1</em>

4888.[<a href="#cit/section_4.121">

4889121</a>

4890]</p>

4891<p id="_548" tabindex="-1">

4892Two additional syndromes are associated with decreased pigmentation of the skin and eyes. The autosomal recessive Chediak-Higashi syndrome is characterized by eosinophilic, peroxidase-positive inclusion bodies in early leukocyte precursors, hemophagocytosis, increased susceptibility to infection, and increased incidence of an accelerated phase lymphohistiocytosis. Pathogenic variants in the <em class="gene-name">

4893LYST</em>

4894 gene underlie this syndrome, which is often fatal in the first decade of life.[<a href="#cit/section_4.122">

4895122</a>

4896-<a href="#cit/section_4.124">

4897124</a>

4898] </p>

4899<p id="_549" tabindex="-1">

4900Griscelli syndrome, also inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, was originally described as decreased cutaneous pigmentation with <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=796064&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000796064&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

4901hypomelanosis</a>

4902 and neurologic deficits, but its clinical presentation is quite variable. This combination of symptoms is now designated Griscelli syndrome type 1 or Elejalde disease. It has been attributed to pathogenic variants in the <em class="gene-name">

4903MYO5A</em>

4904 gene, which affects melanosome transport.[<a href="#cit/section_4.125">

4905125</a>

4906] Individuals with Griscelli syndrome type 2 have decreased cutaneous pigmentation and immunodeficiency but lack neurological deficits. They also may have hemophagocytosis or lymphohistiocytosis that is often fatal, like that seen in Chediak-Higashi syndrome. Griscelli syndrome type 2 is caused by pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

4907RAB27A</em>

4908, which is part of the same melanosome transport pathway as <em class="gene-name">

4909MYO5A</em>

4910.[<a href="#cit/section_4.126">

4911126</a>

4912] Griscelli syndrome type 3 presents with hypomelanosis and does not include neurologic or immunologic disorders. Pathogenic variants in the melanophilin (<em class="gene-name">

4913MLPH</em>

4914) gene and <em class="gene-name">

4915MYO5A</em>

4916 have been associated with this variant of Griscelli syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_4.127">

4917127</a>

4918]</p>

4919</section>

4920<section id="_856">

4921<h4 id="_856_toc">

4922Epidermolysis bullosa</h4>

4923<p id="_857" tabindex="-1">

4924There are numerous forms of epidermolysis bullosa (EB), which is characterized by cleavage and blistering of the skin. An observational study of EB patients in the Netherlands, captured by the Dutch EB registry between 1988 and 2018, found an overall EB incidence of 41.3 per million live births and 22.4 per million population.[<a href="#cit/section_4.128">

4925128</a>

4926] In the most extreme cases, EB can result in the congenital absence of the skin.[<a href="#cit/section_4.129">

4927129</a>

4928] Dystrophic EB and junctional EB are associated with an increased risk of skin cancer, particularly SCC.[<a href="#cit/section_4.130">

4929130</a>

4930] While the type of EB can be difficult to determine clinically, next-generation sequencing can define the EB subtype in up to 90% of cases.[<a href="#cit/section_4.131">

4931131</a>

4932] Diagnosis of EB may be accomplished by immunofluorescence or electron microscopy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.132">

4933132</a>

4934] The types of EB, pathogenic variants involved, and phenotypic characteristics are detailed in the following review.[<a href="#cit/section_4.133">

4935133</a>

4936] For more information, see the <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_529">

4937EB simplex</a>

4938 section.</p>

4939<section id="_136">

4940<h5 id="_136_toc">

4941Dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa</h5>

4942<p id="_137" tabindex="-1">

4943Approximately 95% of individuals with the heritable disorder, dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa (DEB), have a detectable <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=781852&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000781852&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

4944germline pathogenic variant</a>

4945 in the <em class="gene-name">

4946COL7A1</em>

4947 gene. This gene (located at 3p21.3) is expressed in basal keratinocytes of the epidermis and encodes type VII collagen. This collagen forms a part of the fibrils that anchor the basement membrane to the dermis, thereby providing structural stability and resistance to mild skin trauma.[<a href="#cit/section_4.134">

4948134</a>

4949] A lack of type VII collagen often results in generalized skin blistering (starting at birth), skin atrophy, and scarring.[<a href="#cit/section_4.134">

4950134</a>

4951] A registry of DEB pathogenic variants, <a href="https://www.deb-central.org/" title="https://www.deb-central.org/">

4952The International DEB Patient Registry</a>

4953, is accessible on the internet.[<a href="#cit/section_4.135">

4954135</a>

4955] An observational study analyzed individuals in the Dutch EB registry over a 30-year period. Results found that DEB comprises 34.7% of all EB diagnoses, has an incidence of 14.1 per million live births, and has a point-prevalence of 8.3 per million population.[<a href="#cit/section_4.128">

4956128</a>

4957]</p>

4958<p id="_138" tabindex="-1">

4959There are two recessively inherited subtypes of DEB: severe generalized (RDEB-sev gen; previously named Hallopeau-Siemens type) and generalized other or generalized intermediate (RDEB-O; previously named non&#8211;Hallopeau-Siemens type); and a dominantly inherited form, dominant dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa (DDEB).[<a href="#cit/section_4.136">

4960136</a>

4961] These syndromes are rare. The prevalence per million individuals in the United States and incidence per million live births are 0.36 and 0.57 for RDEB-sev gen, 0.14 and 0.30 for RDEB-O, and 1.49 and 2.12 for DDEB, respectively.[<a href="#cit/section_4.137">

4962137</a>

4963] The clinical manifestations demonstrate a continuum of severity that complicates definitive diagnosis, especially early in life. The severe generalized subtype, associated with formation of pseudosyndactyly (a mitten-like deformity secondary to fusion of interdigital webbing) in early childhood, carries an SCC risk of up to 85% by age 45 years.[<a href="#cit/section_4.138">

4964138</a>

4965,<a href="#cit/section_4.139">

4966139</a>

4967] These cancers arise in nonhealing wounds and usually metastasize to cause death within 5 years of the diagnosis of SCC.[<a href="#cit/section_4.140">

4968140</a>

4969] In one case series, SCC was the leading cause of death for the 15 patients with the severe generalized subtype.[<a href="#cit/section_4.141">

4970141</a>

4971] The incidence of SCC appears to be highest in the RDEB subtype. In a review of 69 articles that included all types of EB, 117 individuals with SCC were identified; 81 of these cases (69.2%) were in individuals with RDEB.[<a href="#cit/section_4.130">

4972130</a>

4973] In this group, the median age of diagnosis was 36 years (range, 6&#8211;71 y). A cohort study found that 18 of 283 (6.4%) individuals with RDEB had a diagnosis of SCC with a median age of diagnosis of 22.6 years (interquartile range, 20&#8211;27.7 y).[<a href="#cit/section_4.142">

4974142</a>

4975] Early mortality also has been observed in this disorder, with a mortality rate of up to 40% by age 30 years.[<a href="#cit/section_4.143">

4976143</a>

4977] Extracutaneous manifestations of RDEB-sev gen include short stature, anemia, strictures of the gastrointestinal and genitourinary tracts, and corneal scarring that may result in blindness. </p>

4978<p id="_139" tabindex="-1">

4979The rate of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=783882&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000783882&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

4980de novo pathogenic variants</a>

4981 for DDEB is approximately 30%; maternal germline <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460197&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460197&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

4982mosaicism</a>

4983 has also been reported.[<a href="#cit/section_4.144">

4984144</a>

4985,<a href="#cit/section_4.145">

4986145</a>

4987] Glycine substitutions in exons 73 to 75 are the most common pathogenic variants in DDEB. G2034R and G2043R account for half of these variants. Less frequently, <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=783968&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000783968&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

4988splice junction pathogenic variants</a>

4989 and substitutions of glycine and other amino acids may cause the dominant form of DEB. In contrast, more than 400 pathogenic variants have been described for the two types of recessive EB. The recessive form of the disease is caused primarily by null variants, although amino acid substitutions, splice junction variants, and <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=783964&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000783964&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

4990missense variants</a>

4991 have also been reported. In-frame exon skipping may generate a partially functional protein in recessive disease. A founder pathogenic variant, c.6527insC (p.R525X), has been observed in 27 of 49 Spanish individuals with recessive DEB.[<a href="#cit/section_4.146">

4992146</a>

4993] A founder pathogenic variant in <em class="gene-name">

4994COL7A1</em>

4995, pVal769LeuFsXI, was identified in 11 of 15 families in Sfax, Southern Tunisia.[<a href="#cit/section_4.147">

4996147</a>

4997] Three of 12 individuals carrying at least one copy of this variant developed SCC, including two young-onset cases at ages 16 and 29 years. Genotype-phenotype correlations suggest an inverse correlation between the amount of functional protein and severity.</p>

4998<p id="_140" tabindex="-1">

4999Pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

5000COL7A1</em>

5001 result in abnormal triple helical coiling and decreased function, which causes increased skin fragility and blistering. In studies of Ras-driven carcinogenesis in RDEB-severe generalized keratinocytes, retention of the amino-terminal NC1, the first noncollagenous fragment of type VII collagen, is tumorigenic in mice.[<a href="#cit/section_4.148">

5002148</a>

5003] This retained sequence may mediate tumor-stroma interactions that promote carcinogenesis.</p>

5004</section>

5005<section id="_531">

5006<h5 id="_531_toc">

5007Junctional epidermolysis bullosa</h5>

5008<p id="_532" tabindex="-1">

5009Junctional epidermolysis bullosa (JEB) is an autosomal recessive type of EB with an estimated incidence of 2.68 per million live births and an estimated prevalence of 0.49 per million individuals in the United States.[<a href="#cit/section_4.137">

5010137</a>

5011] A Dutch EB registry study reported higher JEB prevalence estimates, with JEB occurring at a rate of 9.3 per million live births and 2.1 per million individuals in the Netherlands.[<a href="#cit/section_4.128">

5012128</a>

5013] In this study, approximately 19% of all EB diagnoses were JEB. JEB results in considerable mortality, with approximately 50% of cases dying within the first year of life.[<a href="#cit/section_4.149">

5014149</a>

5015] Pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

5016COL17A1</em>

5017 or in any of the genes encoding laminin 332 and its three subunits, previously known as laminin 5 (<em class="gene-name">

5018LAMA3</em>

5019, <em class="gene-name">

5020LAMB3</em>

5021, <em class="gene-name">

5022LAMC2</em>

5023) can result in JEB.[<a href="#cit/section_4.150">

5024150</a>

5025-<a href="#cit/section_4.152">

5026152</a>

5027] Individuals with a severe form of JEB, called the Herlitz type, have an 18% cumulative risk of developing SCC by age 25 years.[<a href="#cit/section_4.153">

5028153</a>

5029] A study of <em class="gene-name">

5030COL17A1</em>

5031 in individuals with a milder subtype of JEB, called JEB-other, identified 85 pathogenic variants in 86 alleles from 43 individuals.[<a href="#cit/section_4.154">

5032154</a>

5033] In this study, total loss of COL17A1 protein staining was associated with a severe JEB phenotype.</p>

5034</section>

5035</section>

5036<section id="_142">

5037<h4 id="_142_toc">

5038Epidermodysplasia verruciformis</h4>

5039<p id="_143" tabindex="-1">

5040Pathogenic variants in either of two adjacent genes on chromosome 17q25 can cause epidermodysplasia verruciformis, a rare heritable disorder associated with increased susceptibility to human papillomavirus (HPV). Infection with certain HPV subtypes can lead to development of generalized nonresolving verrucous lesions, which develop into <em>

5041in situ</em>

5042 and invasive SCCs in 30% to 60% of patients.[<a href="#cit/section_4.155">

5043155</a>

5044] Malignant transformation is thought to occur in about half of these lesions. Approximately 90% of these lesions are attributed to HPV types 5 and 8,[<a href="#cit/section_4.156">

5045156</a>

5046] although types 14, 17, 20, and 47 have occasionally been implicated. The association between HPV infection and increased risk of SCC has also been demonstrated in people without epidermodysplasia verruciformis; one case-control study found that HPV antibodies were found more frequently in the plasma of individuals with SCC (OR, 1.6; 95% CI, 1.2&#8211;2.3) than in plasma from cancer-free individuals.[<a href="#cit/section_4.157">

5047157</a>

5048]</p>

5049<p id="_144" tabindex="-1">

5050The genes associated with this disorder, <em class="gene-name">

5051EVER1</em>

5052 and <em class="gene-name">

5053EVER2</em>

5054, were identified in 2002.[<a href="#cit/section_4.158">

5055158</a>

5056] The inheritance pattern of these genes appears to be autosomal recessive; however, autosomal dominant inheritance has also been reported.[<a href="#cit/section_4.159">

5057159</a>

5058-<a href="#cit/section_4.161">

5059161</a>

5060] Both of these gene products are transmembrane proteins localized to the endoplasmic reticulum, and they likely function in signal transduction. This effect may be through regulation of zinc balance; it has been shown that these proteins form a complex with the zinc transporter 1 (ZnT-1), which is, in turn, blocked by certain HPV proteins.[<a href="#cit/section_4.162">

5061162</a>

5062]</p>

5063<p id="_242" tabindex="-1">

5064A recent case-control study examined the effect of a specific <em class="gene-name">

5065EVER2</em>

5066 <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44805&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000044805&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

5067polymorphism</a>

5068 (rs7208422) on the risk of cutaneous SCC in 239 individuals with prior SCC and 432 controls. This polymorphism is a (A &gt; T) coding single nucleotide variant in exon 8, <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460135&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460135&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

5069codon</a>

5070 306 of the <em class="gene-name">

5071EVER2</em>

5072 gene. The frequency of the T <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=339337&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000339337&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

5073allele</a>

5074 among controls was 0.45. <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=339342&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000339342&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

5075Homozygosity</a>

5076 for the polymorphism caused a modest increase in SCC risk, with an adjusted OR of 1.7 (95% CI, 1.1&#8211;2.7) relative to wild-type homozygotes. In this study, those with one or more of the T alleles were also found to have increased seropositivity for any HPV and for HPV types 5 and 8, as compared with the wild type.[<a href="#cit/section_4.163">

5077163</a>

5078]</p>

5079<p id="_243" tabindex="-1">

5080Some evidence suggests nonallelic heterogeneity in epidermodysplasia verruciformis. An individual born to consanguineous parents with epidermodysplasia verruciformis and additional bacterial and fungal infections was found to have homozygous R115X pathogenic variants in the <em class="gene-name">

5081MST1</em>

5082 gene.[<a href="#cit/section_4.164">

5083164</a>

5084] Another susceptibility locus associated with this disorder has been identified at chromosome regions 2p21-p24 through linkage analysis of an affected consanguineous family. Unlike those with pathogenic variants in the <em class="gene-name">

5085EVER1</em>

5086 and <em class="gene-name">

5087EVER2</em>

5088 genes, affected individuals linked to this genomic region were infected with HPV 20 rather than the usual HPV subtypes associated with this disorder, and this family did not have a history of cutaneous SCC.[<a href="#cit/section_4.165">

5089165</a>

5090]</p>

5091</section>

5092<section id="_146">

5093<h4 id="_146_toc">

5094Fanconi anemia</h4>

5095<p id="_147" tabindex="-1">

5096Fanconi anemia is a complex disorder that is characterized by increased incidence of hematologic and solid tumors, including SCC of the skin. Fanconi anemia is inherited as an autosomal recessive disease. It is a relatively rare syndrome with an estimated carrier frequency of one in 181 individuals in the United States (range: 1 in 156 to 1 in 209) and a carrier frequency of up to 1 in 100 individuals of Ashkenazi Jewish ancestry.[<a href="#cit/section_4.166">

5097166</a>

5098] Leukemia is the most commonly reported cancer in this population, but increased rates of gastrointestinal, head and neck, and gynecologic cancers have also been seen.[<a href="#cit/section_4.167">

5099167</a>

5100] By age 40 years, individuals affected with Fanconi anemia have an 8% risk per year of developing a solid tumor;[<a href="#cit/section_4.167">

5101167</a>

5102] the median age of diagnosis for solid tumors is 26 years.[<a href="#cit/section_4.168">

5103168</a>

5104] Multiple cases of cancers of the brain, breast, lung, and kidney (Wilms tumor) have been reported in this population.[<a href="#cit/section_4.168">

5105168</a>

5106] Data on the incidence of NMSCs in this population are sparse; however, review of the literature suggests that the age of diagnosis is between the mid-20s and early 30s and that women seem to be affected more often than men.[<a href="#cit/section_4.168">

5107168</a>

5108-<a href="#cit/section_4.172">

5109172</a>

5110]</p>

5111<p id="_418" tabindex="-1">

5112Individuals with this disease have increased susceptibility to DNA cross-linking agents (e.g., mitomycin-C or diepoxybutane) and ionizing and UV radiation. The diagnosis of this disease is made by observing increased chromosomal breakage, rearrangements, or exchanges in cells after exposure to carcinogens such as diepoxybutane.</p>

5113<p id="_148" tabindex="-1">

5114Seventeen complementation groups have been identified for Fanconi anemia; details regarding the genes associated with these groups are listed in <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_415">

5115Table 7</a>

5116 below.[<a href="#cit/section_4.173">

5117173</a>

5118] Exome sequencing has revealed that a subset of individuals can carry multiple heterozygous pathogenic variants in Fanconi anemia genes,[<a href="#cit/section_4.174">

5119174</a>

5120] which may impact phenotypic presentation.</p>

5121<table id="_415" class="table-default expandable-container">

5122<caption>

5123Table 7. Genes Associated with Fanconi Anemia (FA)</caption>

5124<colgroup>

5125<col width="34.52%">

5126<col width="15.47%">

5127<col width="24.92%">

5128<col width="25.07%">

5129</colgroup>

5130<THead>

5131<tr>

5132<th>

5133Gene</th>

5134<th>

5135Locus</th>

5136<th>

5137Approximate Incidence Among FA Patients (%)</th>

5138<th>

5139Pattern of Disease Transmission</th>

5140</tr>

5141</THead>

5142<TFoot class="pdq-footer">

5143<tr>

5144<td colspan="4">

5145AR = autosomal recessive; XLR = <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=339348&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000339348&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

5146X-linked recessive</a>

5147.

5148</td>

5149</tr>

5150</TFoot>

5151<tbody>

5152<tr>

5153<td>

5154<em class="gene-name">

5155FANCA</em>

5156</td>

5157<td>

515816q24.3 </td>

5159<td>

516070</td>

5161<td>

5162AR</td>

5163</tr>

5164<tr>

5165<td>

5166<em class="gene-name">

5167FANCB</em>

5168</td>

5169<td>

5170Xp22.31 </td>

5171<td>

5172Rare</td>

5173<td>

5174 XLR</td>

5175</tr>

5180 </td>

51829q22.3</td>

5183<td>

518410</td>

5187</tr>

5188<tr>

5192 (<em class="gene-name">

5193BRCA2</em>

5194)</td>

5195<td>

519613q12.3</td>

5197<td>

5198Rare</td>

5199<td>

5200 AR</td>

5201</tr>

52083p25.3</td>

5209<td>

5210Rare</td>

5211<td>

5212AR</td>

5213</tr>

5217FANCE</em>

5218 </td>

5219<td>

52206p21.3</td>

5221<td>

522210</td>

5223<td>

5224AR</td>

5225</tr>

5226<tr>

5227<td>

5228<em class="gene-name">

5229FANCF</em>

5230</td>

5231<td>

523211p15</td>

5233<td>

5234Rare</td>

5235<td>

5236AR</td>

5237</tr>

5238<tr>

5239<td>

5241FANCG</em>

5242 (<em class="gene-name">

5243XRCC9</em>

5244)</td>

5245<td>

52469p13</td>

5247<td>

524810</td>

5249<td>

5250AR</td>

5251</tr>

5252<tr>
