5255FANCI</em>

5256 (<em class="gene-name">

5257KIAA1794</em>

5258)</td>

5259<td>

526015q25-26</td>

5261<td>

5262Rare</td>

5263<td>

5264AR</td>

5265</tr>

5266<tr>

5267<td>

5268<em class="gene-name">

5269FANCJ</em>

5270 (<em class="gene-name">

5271BACH1/BRIP1</em>

5272)</td>

5273<td>

527417q22.3</td>

5275<td>

5276Rare</td>

5277<td>

5278AR</td>

5279</tr>

5280<tr>

5281<td>

5282<em class="gene-name">

5283FANCL</em>

5284 (<em class="gene-name">

5285PHF9/POG</em>

5286)</td>

5287<td>

52882p16.1</td>

5289<td>

5290Rare</td>

5291<td>

5292AR</td>

5293</tr>

5294<tr>

5295<td>

5296<em class="gene-name">

5297FANCM</em>

5298 (<em class="gene-name">

5299Hef</em>

5300)

5301

5302</td>

5303<td>

530414q21.3</td>

5305<td>

5306Rare</td>

5307<td>

5308AR</td>

5309</tr>

5310<tr>

5311<td>

5312<em class="gene-name">

5313FANCN</em>

5314 (<em class="gene-name">

5315PALB2</em>

5316)</td>

5317<td>

531816p12.1</td>

5319<td>

5320Rare</td>

5321<td>

5322AR</td>

5323</tr>

5324<tr>

5325<td>

5326<em class="gene-name">

5327FANCO</em>

5328 (<em class="gene-name">

5329RAD51C</em>

5330)</td>

5331<td>

533217q22</td>

5333<td>

5334Rare</td>

5335<td>

5336AR</td>

5337</tr>

5338<tr>

5339<td>

5340<em class="gene-name">

5341FANCP</em>

5342 (<em class="gene-name">

5343SLX4/BTBD12</em>

5344)</td>

5345<td>

534616p13.3</td>

5347<td>

5348Rare</td>

5349<td>

5350AR</td>

5351</tr>

5352<tr>

5353<td>

5354<em class="gene-name">

5355FANCQ</em>

5356 (<em class="gene-name">

5357ERCC4/XPF</em>

5358)</td>

5359<td>

536016p13.12</td>

5361<td>

5362Rare</td>

5363<td>

5364AR</td>

5365</tr>

5366<tr>

5367<td>

5368<em class="gene-name">

5369FANCS</em>

5370 (<em class="gene-name">

5371BRCA1</em>

5372)</td>

5373<td>

537417q21.31</td>

5375<td>

5376Rare</td>

5377<td>

5378AR</td>

5379</tr>

5380</tbody>

5381</table>

5382<p id="_414" tabindex="-1">

5383The proteins involved with DNA crosslink repairs are called the FANC pathway because of their involvement in Fanconi anemia.[<a href="#cit/section_4.175">

5384175</a>

5385] They interact with several other proteins associated with hereditary cancer risk, including those in <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_155">

5386Bloom syndrome</a>

5387 and ataxia-telangiectasia. Further investigation has revealed that <em class="gene-name">

5388FANCD1</em>

5389 is the same gene as <em class="gene-name">

5390BRCA2</em>

5391, a gene that causes predisposition to breast and ovarian cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_4.176">

5392176</a>

5393] Other Fanconi anemia genes, <em class="gene-name">

5394FANCJ</em>

5395 (<em class="gene-name">

5396BRIP1</em>

5397) and <em class="gene-name">

5398FANCN</em>

5399 (<em class="gene-name">

5400PALB2</em>

5401), have also been identified as rare breast cancer <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460209&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460209&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

5402susceptibility genes</a>

5403.[<a href="#cit/section_4.177">

5404177</a>

5405] For more information, see the <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/brca-genes-hp-pdq#_3468">

5406Cancer Risks, Spectrum, and Characteristics</a>

5407 section in <em class="gene-name">

5408BRCA1</em>

5409 and <em class="gene-name">

5410BRCA2</em>

5411: Cancer Risks and Management, or see the <em class="gene-name">

5412<a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_2780">

5413BRIP1</a>

5414</em>

5415, <em class="gene-name">

5416<a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_3784">

5417PALB2</a>

5418</em>

5419, and <em class="gene-name">

5420<a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_2111">

5421RAD51</a>

5422</em>

5423 sections in Genetics of Breast and Gynecologic Cancers. Individuals who are heterozygous <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460132&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460132&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

5424carriers</a>

5425 of other Fanconi anemia&#8211;associated variants do not appear to have an increased cancer risk, with the possible exception of a twofold increase in breast cancer incidence in carriers of <em class="gene-name">

5426FANCC</em>

5427 pathogenic variants.[<a href="#cit/section_4.178">

5428178</a>

5429]</p>

5430<p id="_1135" tabindex="-1">

5431In 2018, a group reported a significant increase in SCC cases (OR, 1.69; 95% CI, 1.26&#8211;2.26) associated with a specific <em class="gene-name">

5432BRCA2</em>

5433 allele, which is relatively prevalent in the Icelandic population (K3326X; allele frequency, 1.1%).[<a href="#cit/section_4.179">

5434179</a>

5435] This allele results in normal production of an altered protein, and the authors hypothesized carriers have an increased sensitivity to environmental factors, which require DNA repair. This variant was also associated with an increased risk of small cell lung cancer, breast cancer, and ovarian cancer (but lower than the risk associated with the <em class="gene-name">

5436BRCA</em>

5437 pathogenic variants that decrease protein levels).</p>

5438</section>

5439<section id="_512">

5440<h4 id="_512_toc">

5441Dyskeratosis congenita (Zinsser-Cole-Engman syndrome)</h4>

5442<p id="_513" tabindex="-1">

5443Dyskeratosis congenita, like <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_160">

5444Werner syndrome</a>

5445, results in premature aging and is thus considered a progeroid disease. The classic clinical triad for diagnosis includes <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=800270&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000800270&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

5446nail dystrophy</a>

5447, reticular pigmentation of the chest and neck, and oral leukoplakia. In addition, individuals with this disorder are at markedly increased risk of myelodysplastic syndrome, acute leukemia, and bone marrow failure. Ocular, dental, neurologic, gastrointestinal, pulmonary, and skeletal abnormalities have also been described in conjunction with this disease, but clinical expressivity is variable.[<a href="#cit/section_4.180">

5448180</a>

5449] Developmental delay may also be present in variants of dyskeratosis congenita, such as Hoyeraal-Hreidarsson syndrome (HHS) and Revesz syndrome.</p>

5450<p id="_514" tabindex="-1">

5451Approximately 10% of individuals with dyskeratosis congenita will develop nonhematologic tumors, often before the third decade of life.[<a href="#cit/section_4.181">

5452181</a>

5453,<a href="#cit/section_4.182">

5454182</a>

5455] Solid tumors may be the first manifestation of this disorder. Head and neck cancers were the most commonly reported, accounting for nearly half of the cancers observed. Cutaneous SCC occurred in about 1.5% of the subjects, and the median age at diagnosis was 21 years. These cancers are generally managed as any other SCC of the skin.</p>

5456<p id="_515" tabindex="-1">

5457Several genes associated with telomere function (<em class="gene-name">

5458DKC1</em>

5459, <em class="gene-name">

5460TERC</em>

5461, <em class="gene-name">

5462TINF2</em>

5463, <em class="gene-name">

5464NHP2</em>

5465, <em class="gene-name">

5466NOP10</em>

5467, <em class="gene-name">

5468RTEL1</em>

5469 and <em class="gene-name">

5470TERT</em>

5471) have been implicated in dyskeratosis congenita; approximately one-half of the individuals with a clinical diagnosis of this disease have an identified pathogenic variant in one of these seven genes.[<a href="#cit/section_4.183">

5472183</a>

5473-<a href="#cit/section_4.190">

5474190</a>

5475] <em class="gene-name">

5476TERC</em>

5477 and <em class="gene-name">

5478TINF2</em>

5479 are inherited in an autosomal dominant manner, whereas <em class="gene-name">

5480NHP2</em>

5481 (<em class="gene-name">

5482NOLA2</em>

5483) and <em class="gene-name">

5484NOP10</em>

5485 (<em class="gene-name">

5486NOLA3</em>

5487) show autosomal recessive inheritance, and <em class="gene-name">

5488RTEL1</em>

5489 and <em class="gene-name">

5490TERT </em>

5491can be either autosomal dominant or autosomal recessive. Recessive pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

5492RTEL1</em>

5493 can also be associated with HHS.[<a href="#cit/section_4.191">

5494191</a>

5495] A study of more than 1,000 individuals of Ashkenazi Jewish ancestry identified a founder <em class="gene-name">

5496RTEL1</em>

5497 splice-site pathogenic variant, c.3791G&gt;A (p.R1264H), that had a carrier frequency of 1% in Orthodox Ashkenazi Jewish individuals and 0.45% in the general Ashkenazi Jewish population.[<a href="#cit/section_4.192">

5498192</a>

5499] <em class="gene-name">

5500DKC1</em>

5501 shows an X-linked recessive pattern. Alterations in these genes result in shortening of telomeres, which in turn leads to defects in proliferation and spontaneous chromosomal rearrangements.[<a href="#cit/section_4.193">

5502193</a>

5503] Levels of TERC, the RNA component of the telomerase complex, are reduced in all dyskeratosis congenita patients.[<a href="#cit/section_4.194">

5504194</a>

5505] Missense pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

5506WRAP53</em>

5507, a gene with a protein product that facilitates trafficking of telomerase, have also been associated with an autosomal recessive form of dyskeratosis congenita.[<a href="#cit/section_4.195">

5508195</a>

5509] Pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

5510C16orf57</em>

5511 were identified in 6 of 132 families who did not have a variant detected in other known genes.[<a href="#cit/section_4.196">

5512196</a>

5513] <em class="gene-name">

5514C16orf57</em>

5515 pathogenic variants are also associated with <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=796066&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000796066&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

5516poikiloderma</a>

5517 with neutropenia.[<a href="#cit/section_4.197">

5518197</a>

5519] For more information about poikiloderma congenitale, see the <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_151">

5520Rothmund-Thomson syndrome</a>

5521 section.</p>

5522<p id="_516" tabindex="-1">

5523The recommended approach for diagnosis begins with a six-cell panel assay for leukocyte telomere length testing. If telomere length is in the lowest 1% for three or more cell types, molecular genetic testing is indicated.[<a href="#cit/section_4.198">

5524198</a>

5525] Testing of <em class="gene-name">

5526DKC1</em>

5527 may be performed first in male probands, as pathogenic variants in this gene account for up to 36% of those identified in dyskeratosis congenita to date. Pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

5528TINF2</em>

5529 and <em class="gene-name">

5530TERT</em>

5531 are responsible for 11% to 24% and 6% to 10% of cases, respectively.[<a href="#cit/section_4.180">

5532180</a>

5533,<a href="#cit/section_4.187">

5534187</a>

5535,<a href="#cit/section_4.188">

5536188</a>

5537,<a href="#cit/section_4.199">

5538199</a>

5539,<a href="#cit/section_4.200">

5540200</a>

5541] </p>

5542</section>

5543<section id="_151">

5544<h4 id="_151_toc">

5545Rothmund-Thomson syndrome</h4>

5546<p id="_152" tabindex="-1">

5547Rothmund-Thomson syndrome, also known as poikiloderma congenitale, is a heritable disorder characterized by <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=796062&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000796062&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

5548chromosomal instability</a>

5549. The cutaneous presentation of this condition is an <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44589&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000044589&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

5550erythematous</a>

5551, blistering rash appearing on the face, buttocks, and extremities in early infancy. Other characteristics of this syndrome include <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44352&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000044352&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

5552telangiectasias</a>

5553, skeletal abnormalities, short stature, cataracts, and increased risk of osteosarcoma. Areas of hyperpigmentation and hypopigmentation of the skin develop later in life, and BCC or SCC can develop at an early age.[<a href="#cit/section_4.201">

5554201</a>

5555] Reports of multiple SCCs <em>

5556in situ</em>

5557 have been reported in individuals as young as 16 years.[<a href="#cit/section_4.202">

5558202</a>

5559] The precise increased risk of skin cancer is not well characterized, but the point prevalence of keratinocyte carcinomas, including both BCC and SCC, is 2% to 5% in young individuals affected by this syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_4.203">

5560203</a>

5561] This prevalence is clearly greater than that found in individuals in the same age group in the general population. Although increased UV sensitivity has been described, SCCs are also found in areas of the skin that are not exposed to the sun.[<a href="#cit/section_4.204">

5562204</a>

5563]</p>

5564<p id="_153" tabindex="-1">

5565A pathogenic variant in the gene <em class="gene-name">

5566RECQL4</em>

5567 is present in 66% of clinically affected individuals with Rothmund-Thomson syndrome type 2. This gene is located at 8q24.3, and inheritance is believed to be autosomal recessive. <em class="gene-name">

5568RECQL4</em>

5569 encodes the ATP-dependent DNA helicase Q4, which promotes DNA unwinding to allow for cellular processes such as replication, transcription, and repair. A role for this protein in repair of DNA double-strand breaks has also been suggested.[<a href="#cit/section_4.205">

5570205</a>

5571] Pathogenic variants in similar DNA helicases lead to the inherited disorders of Bloom syndrome and Werner syndrome.</p>

5572<p id="_154" tabindex="-1">

5573At least 19 different truncating pathogenic variants in this gene have been identified as <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=556486&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000556486&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

5574deleterious</a>

5575.[<a href="#cit/section_4.206">

5576206</a>

5577] These pathogenic variants cause severe down-regulation of RECQL4 transcripts in this subset of individuals with Rothmund-Thomson syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_4.207">

5578207</a>

5579] Cells deficient in RECQL4 have been found to be hypersensitive to oxidative stress, resulting in decreased DNA synthesis.[<a href="#cit/section_4.208">

5580208</a>

5581] Deficiencies in the RecQ helicases permit hyper-recombination, thereby leading to loss of heterozygosity. Loss of heterozygosity associated with deficiencies of this protein suggests that the helicases are caretaker-type tumor suppressor proteins.[<a href="#cit/section_4.209">

5582209</a>

5583]</p>

5584<p id="_627" tabindex="-1">

5585Three of six families with Rothmund-Thomson syndrome type 2 were found to have homozygous pathogenic variants in the <em class="gene-name">

5586C16orf57</em>

5587 gene. Pathogenic variants in this gene have also been identified in individuals with dyskeratosis congenita and poikiloderma with neutropenia, suggesting that these syndromes are related;[<a href="#cit/section_4.196">

5588196</a>

5589,<a href="#cit/section_4.197">

5590197</a>

5591] however, skin cancer risk in these conditions is not well characterized. For more information, see the <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_512">

5592Dyskeratosis congenita (Zinsser-Cole-Engman syndrome)</a>

5593 section.</p>

5594<p id="_1233" tabindex="-1">

5595The clinical presentation of Rothmund-Thomson syndrome type 1 is similar to that of type 2, except that individuals present with bilateral juvenile cataracts, and they do not develop osteosarcoma. A study of seven families with ten children who have features of Rothmund-Thomson syndrome type 1 identified a deep intronic <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460220&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460220&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

5596splicing</a>

5597 variant in the <em class="gene-name">

5598ANAPC1</em>

5599 gene.[<a href="#cit/section_4.210">

5600210</a>

5601] Five individuals were homozygous for this variant, and three individuals had a second predicted pathogenic variant in ANAPC1 in trans. The splicing variant led to the introduction of a new exon, which caused premature termination codons with subsequent nonsense-mediated decay of <em class="gene-name">

5602ANAPC1</em>

5603 transcripts and reduced protein levels. ANAPC1 is a member of the anaphase-promoting complex/cyclosome. </p>

5604</section>

5605<section id="_155">

5606<h4 id="_155_toc">

5607Bloom syndrome</h4>

5608<p id="_156" tabindex="-1">

5609Loss of genomic stability is a major cause of Bloom syndrome. This disorder shows increased chromosomal breakage and is diagnosed by increased sister chromatid exchanges on chromosomal analysis. Clinical manifestations of Bloom syndrome include severe growth retardation, recurrent infections, diabetes, chronic pulmonary disease, and an increased susceptibility to cancers of many types. A study of 290 individuals from the Bloom Syndrome Registry (enrolled from 1960 to 2021) found that 155 participants (53%) developed one or more malignancies, with an 83% cumulative incidence of any cancer type by age 40 years.[<a href="#cit/section_4.211">

5610211</a>

5611] Median survival was 36.2 years. Median survival varied for those diagnosed with a hematologic malignancy (25.4 y) and those diagnosed with a solid tumor (37.7 y). Median survival was not adjusted by year of cancer diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_4.211">

5612211</a>

5613]</p>

5614<p id="_1337" tabindex="-1">

5615Skin cancer accounts for approximately 9% of tumors in the Bloom Syndrome Registry.[<a href="#cit/section_4.212">

5616212</a>

5617] Skin cancers occur at an early age in this population, with individuals diagnosed at a mean age of 31 years to 33 years.[<a href="#cit/section_4.211">

5618211</a>

5619,<a href="#cit/section_4.212">

5620212</a>

5621] Almost 12% of registry participants developed a skin cancer, with BCC occurring most often.[<a href="#cit/section_4.211">

5622211</a>

5623] The mean age of skin cancer diagnosis was 33 years. The typical skin lesion seen in this disorder is a photosensitive erythematous telangiectatic rash that occurs in the first or second year of life.[<a href="#cit/section_4.212">

5624212</a>

5625] Although this rash is most commonly found on the face, it can also be present on the dorsa of the hands or forearms. SCC of the skin is the third most common malignancy associated with this disorder.</p>

5626<p id="_157" tabindex="-1">

5627The <em class="gene-name">

5628BLM</em>

5629 gene, located on the short arm of chromosome 15, is the only gene known to be associated with Bloom syndrome. This gene encodes a 1,417-amino acid protein that is regulated by the cell cycle and demonstrates DNA-dependent ATPase and DNA duplex-unwinding activities. Its helicase <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460145&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460145&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

5630domain</a>

5631 shows considerable similarity to the RecQ subfamily of DNA helicases. Absence of this gene product is thought to destabilize other enzymes that participate in DNA replication and repair.[<a href="#cit/section_4.213">

5632213</a>

5633,<a href="#cit/section_4.214">

5634214</a>

5635]</p>

5636<p id="_158" tabindex="-1">

5637This rare chromosomal breakage syndrome is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner and is characterized by loss of genomic stability. Sixty-four pathogenic variants described in the <em class="gene-name">

5638BLM</em>

5639 gene include nucleotide <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=781204&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000781204&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

5640insertions</a>

5641 and deletions (41%), nonsense variants (30%), variants resulting in mis-splicing (14%), and missense variants (16%).[<a href="#cit/section_4.215">

5642215</a>

5643,<a href="#cit/section_4.216">

5644216</a>

5645] A specific pathogenic variant identified in the Ashkenazi Jewish population is a 6-bp deletion/7-bp insertion at nucleotide 2,281, designated as <em class="gene-name">

5646BLMASH</em>

5647.[<a href="#cit/section_4.217">

5648217</a>

5649] Many of these variants result in truncation of the C-terminus, which prevents normal localization of this protein to the nucleus. Absence of functional BLM protein can cause increased rates of pathogenic variants and recombination. This somatic hypermutability leads to an increased risk of cancer at an early age in virtually every organ, including the skin.</p>

5650<p id="_159" tabindex="-1">

5651Cells from people with Bloom syndrome have been found to have abnormal responses to UV radiation. Normal nuclear accumulation of TP53 after UV radiation was absent in 2 of 11 primary cultures from individuals with Bloom syndrome; in contrast, responses in cultures from people who have XP and ataxia-telangiectasia were normal.[<a href="#cit/section_4.218">

5652218</a>

5653] The gene product of the <em class="gene-name">

5654BLM</em>

5655 gene has also been found to complex with Fanconi proteins, raising the possibility of connections between the BLM and Fanconi anemia pathways for DNA stability.[<a href="#cit/section_4.219">

5656219</a>

5657]</p>

5658</section>

5659<section id="_160">

5660<h4 id="_160_toc">

5661Werner syndrome</h4>

5662<p id="_161" tabindex="-1">

5663Like Bloom syndrome, Werner syndrome is characterized by spontaneous chromosomal instability, resulting in increased susceptibility to cancer and premature aging. Diagnostic criteria, often in the setting of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460138&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460138&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

5664consanguinity</a>

5665, include cataracts, short stature, premature graying or thinning of hair, and a positive 24-hour urinary hyaluronic acid test. Cardinal cutaneous manifestations of this disorder consist of sclerodermatous skin changes, ulcerations, atrophy, and pigmentation changes. Individuals with this syndrome have an average life expectancy of fewer than 50 years.[<a href="#cit/section_4.220">

5666220</a>

5667] Cancers have an early onset and occur in up to 43% of these patients.[<a href="#cit/section_4.221">

5668221</a>

5669] The spectrum of tumors associated with this disorder has primarily been described in the Japanese population and includes an increased incidence of sarcoma, thyroid cancers, and skin cancers.[<a href="#cit/section_4.222">

5670222</a>

5671] Approximately 20% of the cancers reported in this syndrome are cutaneous, with melanoma and SCC of the skin accounting for 14% and 5%, respectively.[<a href="#cit/section_4.223">

5672223</a>

5673] A study of 189 individuals with Werner syndrome estimated melanoma risk to be elevated 53-fold in these individuals.[<a href="#cit/section_4.224">

5674224</a>

5675] SCC was less frequently diagnosed. Acral lentiginous melanomas are overrepresented, and SCCs may exhibit more aggressive behavior, with metastasis to lymph nodes and internal organs.[<a href="#cit/section_4.222">

5676222</a>

5677,<a href="#cit/section_4.225">

5678225</a>

5679]</p>

5680<p id="_162" tabindex="-1">

5681Pathogenic variants in the <em class="gene-name">

5682WRN</em>

5683 gene on chromosome 8p12-p11.2 have been identified in approximately 90% of individuals with this syndrome; no other genes are known to be associated with Werner syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_4.221">

5684221</a>

5685,<a href="#cit/section_4.226">

5686226</a>

5687-<a href="#cit/section_4.229">

5688229</a>

5689] Inheritance of this gene is believed to be autosomal recessive. The product of the <em class="gene-name">

5690WRN</em>

5691 gene is a multifunctional protein including a DNA exonuclease and an ATP-dependent DNA helicase belonging to the RecQ subfamily. This protein may play a role in processes such as DNA repair, recombination, replication, transcription, and combined DNA functions.[<a href="#cit/section_4.230">

5692230</a>

5693-<a href="#cit/section_4.238">

5694238</a>

5695] Telomere dysfunction has been associated with premature aging and cancer susceptibility.[<a href="#cit/section_4.239">

5696239</a>

5697] Other helicases with similar function are altered in other chromosomal instability syndromes, such as BLM in <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_155">

5698Bloom syndrome</a>

5699 and RecQL4 in <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_151">

5700Rothmund-Thomson syndrome</a>

5701.</p>

5702<p id="_163" tabindex="-1">

5703Pathogenic variants described in the <em class="gene-name">

5704WRN</em>

5705 gene include all types of variants, including missense, splice-site, and large rearrangements.[<a href="#cit/section_4.240">

5706240</a>

5707] A few founder pathogenic variants have been reported, which include a splice-site variant (previously known as IVS 25-1G&#8594;C; now known as c.3139-1G&gt;C) found in over 50% of affected Japanese individuals.[<a href="#cit/section_4.241">

5708241</a>

5709,<a href="#cit/section_4.242">

5710242</a>

5711]</p>

5712<p id="_164" tabindex="-1">

5713Pathogenic variants in the <em class="gene-name">

5714WRN</em>

5715 gene causes loss of nuclear localization of the gene product. Intracellular levels of the mRNA and protein associated with the variant are also markedly decreased, compared with those of the wild type. Half-lives of the mRNA and protein associated with the variant are also shorter than those associated with the wild-type mRNA and protein.[<a href="#cit/section_4.243">

5716243</a>

5717,<a href="#cit/section_4.244">

5718244</a>

5719]</p>

5720</section>

5721</section>

5722<section id="_1284">

5723<h3 id="_1284_toc">

5724<em class="gene-name">

5725MC1R</em>

5726</h3>

5727<p id="_1306" tabindex="-1">

5728A meta-analysis showed that the more <em class="gene-name">

5729MC1R</em>

5730 pathogenic variants an individual carried, the higher his/her risk was to develop SCC and BCC. Individuals with two or more <em class="gene-name">

5731MC1R</em>

5732 pathogenic variants had a summary OR of 2.48 (95% CI, 1.96&#8211;3.15) for BCC and a summary OR of 2.80 (95% CI, 1.71&#8211;4.57) for SCC; these risks increased when individuals had red hair.[<a href="#cit/section_4.245">

5733245</a>

5734] A study of individuals diagnosed with BCC before age 40 years also found a stronger association between BCC and <em class="gene-name">

5735MC1R</em>

5736 pathogenic variants in those with phenotypic characteristics that are not traditionally considered high risk. For more information, see the section on <em class="gene-name">

5737<a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_359">

5738MC1R</a>

5739</em>

5740 in the Melanoma section.[<a href="#cit/section_4.246">

5741246</a>

5742] </p>

5743</section>

5744<section id="_253">

5745<h3 id="_253_toc">

5746Interventions</h3>

5747<section id="_254">

5748<h4 id="_254_toc">

5749Prevention and treatment of skin cancers</h4>

5750<p id="_959" tabindex="-1">

5751A phase III, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial in Australia evaluated the effects of oral nicotinamide (vitamin B<sub>

57523</sub>

5753) in 386 individuals with a history of at least two NMSCs within 5 years before study enrollment.[<a href="#cit/section_4.247">

5754247</a>

5755] The mean age of the study participants was 66.4 years, and 63% were male. After 12 months of treatment, those taking nicotinamide 500 mg twice daily had a 30% reduction in the incidence of new SCCs (95% CI, 0%&#8211;51%; <em>

5756P</em>

5757 = .05). A statistically significant reduction was also seen in actinic keratoses, the precursor skin lesions to SCCs. The rate of new NMSCs was 23% lower in the nicotinamide group (95% CI, 4%&#8211;38%, <em>

5758P</em>

5759 = .02) than in the placebo group. No clinically significant differences in adverse events were observed between the two groups, and there was no evidence of benefit after discontinuation of nicotinamide. Of note, this study was not conducted in a population with an identified genetic predisposition to SCC, but it was conducted in a part of the world with a high incidence of sunlight-induced skin cancer.</p>

5760<p id="_960" tabindex="-1">

5761<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=531810&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000531810&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5762Level of evidence (nicotinamide): 1aii</a>

5763</p>

5764<p id="_255" tabindex="-1">

5765Because many of the syndromes described above are rare, few clinical trials have been conducted in these specific populations. However, valuable information has been developed from the clinical management experience related to skin cancer risk and treatment in the XP population. Strict sun avoidance beginning in infancy, use of protective clothing, and close clinical monitoring of the skin are key components to management of XP. Full-body photography of the skin, conjunctivae, and eyelids is recommended to aid in follow-up.[<a href="#cit/section_4.248">

5766248</a>

5767] Although few studies on treatment of SCC in the XP population have been done, in most cases treatment is similar to what would be recommended for the general population. Actinic keratoses are treated with topical therapies such as fluorouracil (5-FU), cryotherapy with liquid nitrogen, or dermabrasion, whereas cutaneous cancers are generally managed surgically.[<a href="#cit/section_4.249">

5768249</a>

5769]</p>

5770<p id="_1136" tabindex="-1">

5771<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=531846&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000531846&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5772Level of evidence: 5</a>

5773</p>

5774<p id="_257" tabindex="-1">

5775Oral isotretinoin has been used as chemoprevention in XP patients with promising results. A small study of daily use of isotretinoin (13-cis retinoic acid; given as 2 mg/kg/day) reduced NMSC incidence by 63% in a small number of people with XP. Toxicities associated with this treatment included mucocutaneous symptoms, abnormalities in liver function tests and triglyceride levels, and musculoskeletal symptoms such as arthralgias, calcifications of tendons and ligaments, and osteoporosis.[<a href="#cit/section_4.250">

5776250</a>

5777,<a href="#cit/section_4.251">

5778251</a>

5779] Dose reduction to 0.5 mg/kg/day reduced toxicity and decreased skin cancer frequency in three of seven subjects (43%); increasing the dose to 1 mg/kg/day resulted in decreased skin cancer frequency in three of the four subjects who did not respond at the lower dose.[<a href="#cit/section_4.252">

5780252</a>

5781] Oral isotretinoin use may be useful as a chemopreventive agent in other hereditary skin cancer syndromes, including basal cell nevus syndrome (BCNS), Rombo syndrome, EB, and epidermodysplasia verruciformis.[<a href="#cit/section_4.253">

5782253</a>

5783,<a href="#cit/section_4.254">

5784254</a>

5785]</p>

5786<p id="_258" tabindex="-1">

5787<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=531815&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000531815&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5788Level of evidence (oral isotretinoin for XP): 3aii</a>

5789</p>

5790<p id="_790" tabindex="-1">

5791<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=531821&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000531821&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5792Level of evidence (oral isotretinoin for BCNS, Rombo syndrome, epidermodysplasia verruciformis): 5</a>

5793</p>

5794<p id="_389" tabindex="-1">

5795Topical T4N5 liposome lotion, containing the bacterial enzyme T4 endonuclease V, was also investigated as a chemopreventive agent in a randomized, placebo-controlled trial of 30 XP patients.[<a href="#cit/section_4.255">

5796255</a>

5797] Although no effect was seen on incidence of SCC, 17.7 fewer actinic keratoses per year were seen in the treatment group. Additionally, 1.6 fewer BCCs per year were observed in patients being treated with this therapy. Both of these results were statistically significant. The risk of BCC was reduced by 47%, which was of borderline statistical significance. No significant adverse effects of this agent were reported. To date, this agent has not been approved for use by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration.</p>

5798<p id="_412" tabindex="-1">

5799<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=526277&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000526277&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5800Level of evidence: 1aii</a>

5801</p>

5802<p id="_259" tabindex="-1">

5803For patients with XP and unresectable SCC, therapy with 5-FU has been investigated. Several treatment methods were used in this prospective study, including topical therapy to the lesions, short systemic infusion with folic acid, and continuous systemic infusion in combination with cisplatin. Topical 5-FU demonstrated some efficacy, but in some cases viable tumor remained in the deeper dermis. The systemic chemotherapy resulted in one complete response and three partial responses in a total of five patients, suggesting that this therapy may be an option for treatment of extensive lesions.[<a href="#cit/section_4.256">

5804256</a>

5805] A dose reduction of 30% to 50% has been recommended for systemic chemotherapeutic agents in this population because of the increased sensitivity of XP cells.[<a href="#cit/section_4.257">

5806257</a>

5807]</p>

5808<p id="_260" tabindex="-1">

5809<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=531844&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000531844&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5810Level of evidence: 3diii</a>

5811</p>

5812<p id="_1130" tabindex="-1">

5813For patients with EB, wide local excision of SCC with 2 cm margins remains the treatment of choice. Because the extent of SCC may be difficult to assess in these patients, clearance of SCC tumors may require continuous margin control surgery (Mohs excision) or generous clinical margins. Multiple surgical sessions may be required. Closure of the subsequent defects may require tissue rearrangement or dermal substitutes.[<a href="#cit/section_4.258">

5814258</a>

5815] Amputation may be considered as an option to reduce disease recurrence, although it is not clear that this has an impact on survival. The role of sentinel lymph node biopsy remains unclear in this population.[<a href="#cit/section_4.254">

5816254</a>

5817]</p>

5818<p id="_1131" tabindex="-1">

5819Current guidelines recommend that individuals with EB and unresectable SCC be treated with radiation therapy, but the dose may need to be given in smaller fractions in order to decrease the risk of skin desquamation. Systemic therapy with epidermal growth factor receptor antagonists or tyrosine kinase inhibitors may also be considered for individuals with advanced SCC.[<a href="#cit/section_4.254">

5820254</a>

5821]</p>

5822<p id="_1132" tabindex="-1">

5823<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=531846&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000531846&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5824Level of evidence: 5</a>

5825</p>

5826<p id="_261" tabindex="-1">

5827For people who have genetic disorders other than XP, data are lacking, but general sun-safety measures remain important. Careful protection of the skin and eyes is the mainstay of prevention in all patients with increased susceptibility to skin cancer. Key points include avoidance of sun exposure at peak hours, protective clothing and lenses, and vigilant use of sunscreen. Avoidance of x-ray therapy has also been advocated for some groups with hereditary skin cancer syndromes, such as those with epidermodysplasia verruciformis.[<a href="#cit/section_4.155">

5828155</a>

5829] However, XP patients with unresectable skin cancers or internal cancers, such as spinal cord astrocytoma or glioblastomas of the brain, have been treated successfully with standard therapeutic doses of x-ray radiation.[<a href="#cit/section_4.53">

583053</a>

5831] Some experts recommend dermatologic evaluation every 6 months and ophthalmologic evaluation at least annually in these high-risk populations. Guidelines for the management of patients with EB recommend skin examinations every 3 to 6 months starting at age 10 years for individuals with the RDEB-sev gen subtype of the disease.[<a href="#cit/section_4.254">

5832254</a>

5833] For individuals with other subtypes of EB, skin examination every 6 to 12 months starting at age 20 years is recommended in the absence of an established SCC diagnosis. Dental examination every 6 months is also recommended in this population.[<a href="#cit/section_4.254">

5834254</a>

5835]</p>

5836<p id="_278" tabindex="-1">

5837<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=531821&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000531821&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5838Level of evidence: 5</a>

5839</p>

5840<p id="_464" tabindex="-1">

5841For individuals with DEB, wound care is paramount. Use of silver sulfadiazine cream, medical grade honey, and soft silicone dressings can be helpful in these settings. Attention to nutritional status, which may be compromised because of esophageal strictures, iron-deficiency anemia, infection, and inflammation, is another critical consideration for wound healing for these patients. Multivitamin supplementation, often at higher doses than those routinely recommended for the general population, may be warranted.[<a href="#cit/section_4.259">

5842259</a>

5843]

5844</p>

5845<p id="_465" tabindex="-1">

5846<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=531821&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000531821&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5847Level of evidence: 5</a>

5848 </p>

5849<p id="_1206" tabindex="-1">

5850

5851Maintenance of skin integrity is a key factor for management of patients with JEB. A small study of five infants with severe generalized JEB with at least one premature truncating pathogenic variant in <em class="gene-name">

5852LAMB3</em>

5853 evaluated the clinical effects of treatment with gentamicin (7.5 mg/kg/day for 3 weeks) on skin fragility and other clinical features. Treatment did not impact overall mortality, but there was decreased skin fragility in four of the five patients; improved perceived quality of life as reported by caregivers, including increased physical activity without blistering; and increased laminin 332 expression in the skin.[<a href="#cit/section_4.260">

5854260</a>

5855]</p>

5856<p id="_1207" tabindex="-1">

5857<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=531838&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000531838&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5858Level of evidence: 3c</a>

5859

5860

5861</p>

5862<p id="_1062" tabindex="-1">

5863Bone marrow transplantation has been explored in patients with DEB; however, there is no evidence that this intervention results in a reduction of skin cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_4.261">

5864261</a>

5865] A double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled trial of infusion of nonhematopoietic bone marrow stem cells with or without cyclosporine was conducted in 14 patients with recessive DEB. The rationale for this study was that mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) have the potential to differentiate into dermal fibroblasts, the main expressor of type VII collagen. Seven subjects were randomly assigned to receive MSCs with 5 mg/kg/day of cyclosporine and an additional seven subjects received only MSCs. The number of new blisters and the rate of blister healing were significantly improved in both groups (<em>

5866P</em>

5867 = .003 for the number of new blisters in the combination therapy group and <em>

5868P</em>

5869 = .004 in the group receiving MSCs only; <em>

5870P</em>

5871 &lt; .001 for the rate of blister healing in both groups). However, no difference was seen between the groups.[<a href="#cit/section_4.262">

5872262</a>

5873]</p>

5874<p id="_1063" tabindex="-1">

5875<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=538265&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000538265&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5876Level of evidence (MSCs for blister prevention): 1b</a>

5877</p>

5878<p id="_1064" tabindex="-1">

5879<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=531829&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000531829&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5880Level of evidence (MSCs for blister treatment): 1</a>

5881</p>

5882</section>

5883<section id="_1110">

5884<h4 id="_1110_toc">

5885Future therapies for epidermolysis bullosa</h4>

5886<p id="_1111" tabindex="-1">

5887Researchers are taking advantage of recent technological advances to study new strategies for the treatment of dominant and recessive EB.[<a href="#cit/section_4.263">

5888263</a>

5889-<a href="#cit/section_4.266">

5890266</a>

5891] Clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats (CRISPR)-associated protein 9 (Cas9) is a technology that can be used to edit DNA. One research group used CRISPR/Cas9 to correct an inherited pathogenic variant in <em class="gene-name">

5892COL7A1</em>

5893 in keratinocytes isolated from a patient with RDEB.[<a href="#cit/section_4.263">

5894263</a>

5895] Keratinocytes that contained the corrected version of <em class="gene-name">

5896COL7A1</em>

5897 were successfully transplanted onto mice and staining of skin grafts after transplant showed normal skin. Another study used a different approach, retrovirus infection, to introduce normal <em class="gene-name">

5898COL7A1</em>

5899 into keratinocytes from four RDEB patients.[<a href="#cit/section_4.265">

5900265</a>

5901] The corrected keratinocytes were then assembled into epidermal graft sheets and transplanted onto six wound areas of each of the four patients. The grafts were well tolerated and showed greater healing capabilities than did noncorrected skin after further study. A small prospective trial of intravenous gentamicin in pediatric patients with junctional EB showed that patients had increased wound healing and improved quality of life after treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_4.267">

5902267</a>

5903] All of these therapies are still in early research stages and have not yet been evaluated in randomized, controlled clinical trials.</p>

5904<p id="_1112" tabindex="-1">

5905Level of evidence: None assigned</p>

5906</section>

5907</section>

5908<h6 do-not-show="toc">

5909References</h6>

5922</li>

5923<li id="section_4.4">

5925[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5926</li>

5927<li id="section_4.5">

5928Armstrong BK, Kricker A: The epidemiology of UV induced skin cancer. J Photochem Photobiol B 63 (1-3): 8-18, 2001.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11684447&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11684447&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5929[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5931<li id="section_4.6">

Br J Dermatol 174 (1): 56-67, 2016.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26302137&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26302137&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6909[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6910</li>

6911<li id="section_4.255">

6912Yarosh D, Klein J, O'Connor A, et al.: Effect of topically applied T4 endonuclease V in liposomes on skin cancer in xeroderma pigmentosum: a randomised study. Xeroderma Pigmentosum Study Group. Lancet 357 (9260): 926-9, 2001.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11289350&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11289350&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6913[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6914</li>

6915<li id="section_4.256">

6916Boussen H, Zwik J, Mili-Boussen I, et al.: [Therapeutic results of 5-fluorouracil in multiple and unresectable facial carcinoma secondary to xeroderma pigmentosum] Therapie 56 (6): 751-4, 2001 Nov-Dec.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11878102&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11878102&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6917[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6918</li>

6919<li id="section_4.257">

6920Sarasin A: Progress and prospects of xeroderma pigmentosum therapy. Adv Exp Med Biol 637: 144-51, 2008.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19181120&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19181120&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6921[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6922</li>

6923<li id="section_4.258">

6924Paganelli A, Giordano E, Fiorentini C, et al.: Surgical management and oncological follow-up of cutaneous squamous cell carcinomas arising in epidermolysis bullosa patients. Int J Dermatol 61 (10): 1171-1174, 2022.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=35315931&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=35315931&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6925[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6926</li>

6927<li id="section_4.259">

6928Mellerio JE, Weiner M, Denyer JE, et al.: Medical management of epidermolysis bullosa: Proceedings of the IInd International Symposium on Epidermolysis Bullosa, Santiago, Chile, 2005. Int J Dermatol 46 (8): 795-800, 2007.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17651159&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17651159&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6929[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6930</li>

6931<li id="section_4.260">

6932Hammersen J, Neuner A, Wild F, et al.: Attenuation of Severe Generalized Junctional Epidermolysis Bullosa by Systemic Treatment with Gentamicin. Dermatology 235 (4): 315-322, 2019.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=31132778&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=31132778&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6933[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6934</li>

6935<li id="section_4.261">

6936Wagner JE, Ishida-Yamamoto A, McGrath JA, et al.: Bone marrow transplantation for recessive dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa. N Engl J Med 363 (7): 629-39, 2010.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20818854&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20818854&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6937[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6938</li>

6939<li id="section_4.262">

6940El-Darouti M, Fawzy M, Amin I, et al.: Treatment of dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa with bone marrow non-hematopoeitic stem cells: a randomized controlled trial. Dermatol Ther 29 (2): 96-100, 2016 Mar-Apr.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26439431&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26439431&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6941[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6942</li>

6943<li id="section_4.263">

6944Hainzl S, Peking P, Kocher T, et al.: COL7A1 Editing via CRISPR/Cas9 in Recessive Dystrophic Epidermolysis Bullosa. Mol Ther 25 (11): 2573-2584, 2017.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28800953&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28800953&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6945[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6946</li>

6947<li id="section_4.264">

6948Shinkuma S, Guo Z, Christiano AM: Site-specific genome editing for correction of induced pluripotent stem cells derived from dominant dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa. Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A 113 (20): 5676-81, 2016.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=27143720&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=27143720&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6949[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6950</li>

6951<li id="section_4.265">

6952Siprashvili Z, Nguyen NT, Gorell ES, et al.: Safety and Wound Outcomes Following Genetically Corrected Autologous Epidermal Grafts in Patients With Recessive Dystrophic Epidermolysis Bullosa. JAMA 316 (17): 1808-1817, 2016.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=27802546&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=27802546&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6953[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6954</li>

6955<li id="section_4.266">

6956Webber BR, Osborn MJ, McElroy AN, et al.: CRISPR/Cas9-based genetic correction for recessive dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa. NPJ Regen Med 1: , 2016.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28250968&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28250968&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6957[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6958</li>

6959<li id="section_4.267">

6960Mosallaei D, Hao M, Antaya RJ, et al.: Molecular and Clinical Outcomes After Intravenous Gentamicin Treatment for Patients With Junctional Epidermolysis Bullosa Caused by Nonsense Variants. JAMA Dermatol 158 (4): 366-374, 2022.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=35234826&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=35234826&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6961[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6962</li>

6963</ol>

6964</div>

6965

6966 </section>

6967

6968

6969

6970 <section id="_38">

6971

6972 <h2>

6973Melanoma</h2>

6974

6975 <div id="_section_38" class="pdq-sections">

6976<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

6977<h6>

7139</nav>

7140<section id="_39">

7141<h3 id="_39_toc">

7142Introduction</h3>

7143<p id="_40" tabindex="-1">

7144Rare, high-<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=339344&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000339344&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7145penetrance</a>

7146 and common, low-penetrance genetic factors for melanoma have been identified, and approximately 5% to 10% of all melanomas arise in multiple-case families. However, a significant fraction of these families do not have detectable <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=783960&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000783960&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7147pathogenic variants</a>

7148 in specific <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460209&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460209&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7149susceptibility genes</a>

7150. The frequency with which multiple-case families are ascertained and specific <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=776887&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000776887&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7151genetic variants</a>

7152 are identified differs substantially between populations and geographic regions. A major population-based study has concluded that the high-penetrance susceptibility <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45693&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045693&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7153gene</a>

7154 <em class="gene-name">

7155CDKN2A</em>

7156 does not make a large contribution to the incidence of melanoma.[<a href="#cit/section_5.1">

71571</a>

7158] </p>

7159<p id="_1185" tabindex="-1">

7160Melanoma can also occur in other parts of the body, such as the eye and brain. For more information about melanoma of the eye, see <a href="/types/eye/hp/intraocular-melanoma-treatment-pdq">

7161Intraocular (Uveal) Melanoma Treatment</a>

7162.</p>

7163</section>

7164<section id="_289">

7165<h3 id="_289_toc">

7166Risk Factors for Melanoma</h3>

7167<p id="_1002" tabindex="-1">

7168This section focuses on risk factors in individuals at increased hereditary risk of developing melanoma. For more information about melanoma risk factors in the general population, see <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-prevention-pdq">

7169Skin Cancer Prevention</a>

7170.</p>

7171<section id="_290">

7172<h4 id="_290_toc">

7173Sun exposure</h4>

7174<p id="_351" tabindex="-1">

7175Sun exposure is well established as a major etiologic factor in all forms of skin cancer, although its effects differ by cancer type. The relationship between sun exposure, sunscreen use, and the development of skin cancer is complex. It is complicated by <em>

7176negative confounding</em>

7177 (i.e., subjects who are extremely sun sensitive deliberately engage in fewer activities in direct sunlight, and they are more likely to wear sunscreen when they do). These subjects are <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=256553&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000256553&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7178genetically susceptible</a>

7179 to the development of skin cancer by virtue of their cutaneous <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460203&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460203&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7180phenotype</a>

7181 and thus may develop skin cancer regardless of the amount of sunlight exposure or the sun protection factor of the sunscreen.[<a href="#cit/section_5.2">

71822</a>

7183,<a href="#cit/section_5.3">

71843</a>

7185]</p>

7186</section>

7187<section id="_304">

7188<h4 id="_304_toc">

7189Pigmentary characteristics</h4>

7190<p id="_305" tabindex="-1">

7191Pigmentary characteristics are important determinants of melanoma susceptibility. There is an inverse correlation between melanoma risk and skin color that goes from lightest skin to darkest skin. Dark-skinned ethnic groups have a very low risk of melanoma on pigmented skin surfaces; however, individuals in these groups develop melanoma on less-pigmented acral surfaces (palms, soles, nail beds) at the same frequency as light-skinned individuals. Among relatively light-skinned individuals, skin color is modified by genetics and behavior. Melanocortin 1 receptor (<em class="gene-name">

7192MC1R</em>

7193) is one of the major genes controlling pigmentation. For more information, see the section on <em class="gene-name">

7194<a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_359">

7195MC1R</a>

7196</em>

7197 in the Melanoma section. Other pigmentation genes are under investigation.[<a href="#cit/section_5.4">

71984</a>

7199] A relatively new area of investigation is the evaluation of multiple variants together, often referred to as a <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=800513&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000800513&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7200polygenic risk score</a>

7201 (PRS).[<a href="#cit/section_5.5">

72025</a>

7203-<a href="#cit/section_5.7">

72047</a>

7205] PRSs for cutaneous melanoma contain many genetic variants that impact the expression of genes important in pigment-related phenotypes.[<a href="#cit/section_5.8">

72068</a>

7207] The integration of these models with known phenotype risk factors and their overall clinical utility in melanoma risk prediction have not been demonstrated.[<a href="#cit/section_5.9">

72089</a>

7209] PRSs for melanoma are not clinically available at this time.</p>

7210<p id="_409" tabindex="-1">

7211Clinically, several pigmentary characteristics are evaluated to assess the risk of melanoma and other types of skin cancer. These include the following:</p>

7212<div class="pdq-content-list">

7213<ul id="_315">

7214<li>

7215Fitzpatrick skin type. The following six skin phenotypes were defined on the basis of response to sun exposure at the beginning of summer.[<a href="#cit/section_5.10">

721610</a>

7217] <div class="pdq-content-list">

7218<ol id="_109">

7219<li>

7220Type I: Extremely fair skin, always burns, never tans.</li>

7221<li>

7222Type II: Fair skin, always burns, sometimes tans.</li>

7223<li>

7224Type III: Medium skin, sometimes burns, always tans.</li>

7225<li>

7226Type IV: Olive skin, rarely burns, always tans.</li>

7227<li>

7228Type V: Moderately pigmented brown skin, never burns, always tans.</li>

7229<li>

7230Type VI: Markedly pigmented black skin, never burns, always tans.</li>

7231</ol>

7232</div>

7233</li>

7234<li>

7235Number of nevi or nevus density. </li>

7236<li>

7237Abnormal or atypical nevi. </li>

7238<li>

7239Freckling.</li>

7240</ul>

7241</div>

7242</section>

7243<section id="_369">

7244<h4 id="_369_toc">

7245Nevi</h4>

7246<p id="_370" tabindex="-1">

7247Nevi (or moles) are sharply circumscribed benign pigmented lesions of the skin or mucosa composed of nest melanocytes. Patients with multiple nevi demonstrate increased risk of melanoma. While there is evidence that both the presence of multiple nevi and the presence of multiple clinically atypical nevi are associated with an increased risk of melanoma, most studies demonstrate a stronger risk of melanoma with the presence of atypical nevi.[<a href="#cit/section_5.11">

724811</a>

7249-<a href="#cit/section_5.14">

725014</a>

7251] In addition, patients with multiple atypical nevi, regardless of personal and/or family history of melanoma, are at significantly increased risk of developing melanoma than are patients without atypical nevi.[<a href="#cit/section_5.15">

725215</a>

7253] A population-based study in the United Kingdom that identified genetic risk factors for the development of nevi showed that some of the same <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=776887&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000776887&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7254variants</a>

7255 are modestly associated with melanoma risk.[<a href="#cit/section_5.16">

725616</a>

7257]</p>

7258<p id="_884" tabindex="-1">

7259The phenotype of multiple nevi has both <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460148&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460148&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7260familial</a>

7261 and environmental affecters. The number of nevi can increase with childhood sun exposure.[<a href="#cit/section_5.17">

726217</a>

7263,<a href="#cit/section_5.18">

726418</a>

7265] The analysis of this association is complex because the use of sun protection strongly correlates with sun exposure. Inheritance of the specific phenotype of a high number of nevi, including clinically atypical nevi, was initially reported as an <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=793860&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000793860&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7266autosomal dominant</a>

7267 trait under the names dysplastic nevus syndrome [<a href="#cit/section_5.19">

726819</a>

7269] and familial atypical multiple mole-melanoma syndrome.[<a href="#cit/section_5.20">

727020</a>

7271] A portion of this inherited phenotype is attributed to the major melanoma risk gene <em class="gene-name">

7272CDKN2A</em>

7273 <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_165">

7274discussed below</a>

7275. Even within gene <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460132&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460132&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7276carriers</a>

7277 in high-risk families, sun exposure seems to affect nevus number.[<a href="#cit/section_5.21">

727821</a>

7279]</p>

7280</section>

7281<section id="_318">

7282<h4 id="_318_toc">

7283Family history</h4>

7284<p id="_319" tabindex="-1">

7285Generally, a family history of melanoma appears to increase risk of melanoma by about twofold. A family cancer registry study assessed over 20,000 individuals with melanoma and found a standardized incidence ratio (SIR) of 2.62 for offspring of individuals with melanoma and 2.94 for siblings.[<a href="#cit/section_5.22">

728622</a>

7287] A larger study of more than 200,000 individuals from the Nurses&#8217; Health Study, the Nurses&#8217; Health Study 2, and the Health Professionals Follow-up Study found that individuals with a family history of melanoma had an increased risk of melanoma (hazard ratio [HR], 1.74; 95% confidence interval [CI], 1.45&#8211;2.09).[<a href="#cit/section_5.23">

728823</a>

7289] Slightly higher melanoma risks were found in a population-based study of 1,506,961 individuals in Western Australia; <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460150&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460150&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7290first-degree relatives</a>

7291 (FDRs) of 5,660 individuals with melanoma showed an HR for melanoma of 3.58 (95% CI, 2.43&#8211;5.43).[<a href="#cit/section_5.24">

729224</a>

7293] Another population-based study of more than 238,000 FDRs of 23,000 melanoma patients found a lifetime cumulative risk of melanoma of 2.5% to 3%, which is about double the risk of the general population.[<a href="#cit/section_5.25">

729425</a>

7295] Risk based on family history is dependent not only on the number of individuals in the family who have a melanoma but also on the number of melanomas in each family member.[<a href="#cit/section_5.25">

729625</a>

7297] For example, the familial risk of melanoma was found to increase 2.2-fold (95% CI, 2.2&#8211;2.3) with a single FDR who has one melanoma and up to 16.3-fold (95% CI, 9.5&#8211;26.1) with a single FDR who has five or more melanomas.[<a href="#cit/section_5.25">

729825</a>

7299] When two or more family members were diagnosed with melanoma before age 30 years, the lifetime cumulative risk for the family members rose to 14%.[<a href="#cit/section_5.26">

730026</a>

7301] </p>

7302<p id="_1031" tabindex="-1">

7303A study on the <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=781848&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000781848&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7304heritability</a>

7305 of cancer among 80,309 monozygotic and 123,382 dizygotic twins showed that melanoma has a heritability of 58% (95% CI, 43%&#8211;73%), suggesting that more than half of the risk of melanoma is caused by inherited factors.[<a href="#cit/section_5.27">

730627</a>

7307] A study looking at the contribution of family history to melanoma risk showed a population-attributable fraction ranging from less than 1% in northern Europe to 6.4% in Australia,[<a href="#cit/section_5.28">

730828</a>

7309] suggesting that only a small percentage of melanoma cases are caused by familial factors. Rarely, however, in some families many generations and multiple individuals develop melanoma and are at much higher risk. For individuals from these families, the incidence of melanoma is higher for sun-protected rather than sun-exposed skin.[<a href="#cit/section_5.29">

731029</a>

7311]</p>

7312<p id="_1032" tabindex="-1">

7313A major hereditary melanoma susceptibility gene, <em class="gene-name">

7314CDKN2A</em>

7315, is altered in approximately 14% to 43% of families with three or more melanoma cases. To date, pathogenic variants have not been identified in more than half of the families with multiple cases of melanoma.[<a href="#cit/section_5.30">

731630</a>

7317-<a href="#cit/section_5.33">

731833</a>

7319] <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=775581&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000775581&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7320Multigene panel testing</a>

7321 can be considered in families with multiple cases of melanoma. This type of testing can search for pathogenic variants in multiple melanoma genes. However, a large study of extended panel testing (30 genes) in melanoma families without <em class="gene-name">

7322CDKN2A</em>

7323 and <em class="gene-name">

7324CDK4</em>

7325 pathogenic variants had a diagnostic yield of 4%.[<a href="#cit/section_5.34">

732634</a>

7327] In a large Italian study of multigene panel testing in patients with melanoma, predictors of a pathogenic variant included the following: (1) the presence of pancreatic cancer and melanoma in the same family, and (2) individuals who have had more than three melanomas. When patients were diagnosed with melanoma after age 60 years, they were less likely to have a pathogenic variant in a melanoma gene.[<a href="#cit/section_5.33">

732833</a>

7329] </p>

7330<p id="_1186" tabindex="-1">

7331The definition of a familial cluster of melanoma varies by geographical region worldwide, because of the role played by ultraviolet (UV) radiation in melanoma pathogenesis. In heavily insulated regions (regions with high ambient sun exposure), three or more <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460124&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460124&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7332affected</a>

7333 family members are required for a familial cluster. In regions with lower levels of ambient sunlight, two or more affected family members are considered sufficient to define a familial cluster. For more information on reasons to consider genetic testing for melanoma, see the <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_393">

7334Genetic testing</a>

7335 section.</p>

7336</section>

7337<section id="_320">

7338<h4 id="_320_toc">

7339Personal history of melanoma</h4>

7340<p id="_321" tabindex="-1">

7341A previous melanoma places one at high risk of developing additional primary melanomas, particularly for people with the most common risk factors for melanoma, such as cutaneous phenotype, family history, a pathogenic variant in <em class="gene-name">

7342CDKN2A</em>

7343, a great deal of early-life sun exposure, and numerous or atypical nevi. In the <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=339347&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000339347&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7344sporadic</a>

7345 setting, approximately 5% of melanoma patients develop more than one primary cancer, while in the familial setting the corresponding estimate is 30%. This greater-than-expected rate of multiple primary cancers of the same organ is a common feature of hereditary cancer susceptibility syndromes; it represents a clinical finding that should raise the level of suspicion that a given patient&#8217;s melanoma may be related to an underlying <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460153&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460153&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7346genetic predisposition</a>

7347. Risk of a second primary melanoma after diagnosis of a first primary melanoma is approximately 5% and is greater for males and older patients.[<a href="#cit/section_5.35">

734835</a>

7349-<a href="#cit/section_5.38">

735038</a>

7351] A study in Sweden of more than 65,000 individuals with melanoma found a SIR of 2.8 (95% CI, 2.3&#8211;3.4) for a second melanoma in individuals with a family history of melanoma and a SIR of 2.5 (95% CI, 2.3&#8211;2.7) in individuals with no family history.[<a href="#cit/section_5.39">

735239</a>

7353] The risk of a second melanoma increased when the first melanoma was diagnosed before age 40 years (SIR, 4.7; 95% CI, 3.9&#8211;5.6%). The SIRs increased with increasing numbers of melanomas.</p>

7354</section>

7355<section id="_322">

7356<h4 id="_322_toc">

7357Personal history of BCC or SCC</h4>

7358<p id="_323" tabindex="-1">

7359Having a personal history of basal cell carcinoma (BCC) or squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is also associated with an increase in risk of a subsequent melanoma.[<a href="#cit/section_5.40">

736040</a>

7361-<a href="#cit/section_5.42">

736242</a>

7363] Depending on the study, this risk ranges from a nonsignificant increase for melanoma with a previous SCC of 1.04 (95% CI, 0.13&#8211;8.18) to a highly significant risk of 7.94 (95% CI, 4.11&#8211;15.35).[<a href="#cit/section_5.43">

736443</a>

7365,<a href="#cit/section_5.44">

736644</a>

7367] It is likely that this relationship is the result of shared risk factors (of which sun exposure is presumably one), rather than a specific genetic factor that increases risk of both. Pigmentary characteristics are critically important for the development of melanoma, and cutaneous phenotype (described above), in combination with excessive sun exposure, is associated with an increased risk of all three types of skin cancers.</p>

7368</section>

7369</section>

7370<section id="_41">

7371<h3 id="_41_toc">

7372Major Genes for Melanoma</h3>

7373<section id="_165">

7374<h4 id="_165_toc">

7375<em class="gene-name">

7376CDKN2A/p16</em>

7377 and <em class="gene-name">

7378p14/ARF</em>

7379</h4>

7380<p id="_166" tabindex="-1">

7381 The major gene associated with melanoma is <em class="gene-name">

7382CDKN2A/p16</em>

7383, cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor 2A, which is located on <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46470&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046470&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7384chromosome</a>

7385 9p21. This gene has multiple names (<em class="gene-name">

7386MTS1</em>

7387, <em class="gene-name">

7388INK4</em>

7389, and <em class="gene-name">

7390MLM</em>

7391) and is commonly called by the name of its protein, p16. It is an upstream regulator of the retinoblastoma gene pathway, acting through the cyclin D1/cyclin-dependent kinase 4 complex. This <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46657&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046657&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7392tumor suppressor gene</a>

7393 has been intensively studied in multiple-case families and in population-based series of melanoma cases. <em class="gene-name">

7394CDKN2A</em>

7395 controls the passage of cells through the cell cycle and provides a mechanism for holding damaged cells at the G1/S checkpoint to permit repair of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45671&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045671&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7396DNA</a>

7397 damage before cellular replication. Loss of function of tumor suppressor genes&#8212;a good example of which is <em class="gene-name">

7398CDKN2A</em>

7399&#8212;is a critical step in carcinogenesis for many tumor systems. </p>

7400<p id="_179" tabindex="-1">

7401<em class="gene-name">

7402CDKN2A</em>

7403 encodes two proteins, p16<span class="sup">

7404INK4a</span>

7405 and p14<span class="sup">

7406ARF</span>

7407, both inhibitors of cellular senescence. The protein produced when the alternate reading frame (ARF) for <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460146&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460146&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7408exon</a>

7409 1 is transcribed instead of the standard reading frame exerts its biological effects through the p53 pathway. It mediates cell cycle arrest at the G1 and G2/M checkpoints, complementing p16&#8217;s block of G1/S progression&#8212;thereby facilitating cellular repair of DNA damage.</p>

7410<p id="_180" tabindex="-1">

7411Pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

7412CDKN2A</em>

7413 account for 35% to 40% of familial melanomas [<a href="#cit/section_5.30">

741430</a>

7415] and fewer than 1% of unselected melanoma cases.[<a href="#cit/section_5.45">

741645</a>

7417] A study of more than 1,000 individuals in Spain showed that 6.6% of individuals with melanoma have a family history of two or more FDRs with melanoma, and up to 15% have a family history suggestive of familial melanoma that includes melanoma or pancreatic cancer diagnoses in FDRs or <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=485395&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000485395&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7418second-degree relatives</a>

7419 (SDRs).[<a href="#cit/section_5.46">

742046</a>

7421] A large case series from Britain found that <em class="gene-name">

7422CDKN2A</em>

7423 pathogenic variants were present in 100% of families with seven to ten individuals affected with melanoma, 60% to 71% of families with four to six cases, and 14% of families with two cases.[<a href="#cit/section_5.31">

742431</a>

7425] A similar study of Greek individuals with melanoma found <em class="gene-name">
