7426CDKN2A</em>

7427 pathogenic variants in 3.3% of single melanoma cases, 22% of familial melanoma cases, and 57% of individuals with multiple primary melanomas (MPM).[<a href="#cit/section_5.47">

742847</a>

7429] A study of 92 sequential cases of Italian individuals with familial atypical multiple mole-melanoma syndrome (defined as three or more individuals with primary cutaneous melanoma or one individual with MPM) found <em class="gene-name">

7430CDKN2A</em>

7431 pathogenic variants in 20% of individuals, including three unrelated individuals with a p.D84V variant.[<a href="#cit/section_5.48">

743248</a>

7433] <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=791164&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000791164&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7434Cascade testing</a>

7435 identified 14 of 40 <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460224&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460224&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7436unaffected</a>

7437 family members undergoing testing who carried their family&#8217;s <em class="gene-name">

7438CDKN2A</em>

7439 pathogenic variant. However, a second study of 106 familial melanoma cases (defined as at least two melanoma cases) only found <em class="gene-name">

7440CDKN2A</em>

7441 pathogenic variants in 8.3% of cases.[<a href="#cit/section_5.49">

744249</a>

7443] The frequency of <em class="gene-name">

7444CDKN2A</em>

7445 pathogenic variants is as high as 22% in families with two cases of melanoma who have other features of hereditary melanoma, such as an age at diagnosis younger than 50 years or one or more individuals diagnosed with MPM.[<a href="#cit/section_5.50">

744650</a>

7447] Many of the pathogenic variants reported among families are <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=783962&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000783962&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7448founder variants</a>

7449, which are unique to specific populations and geographic areas.[<a href="#cit/section_5.51">

745051</a>

7451-<a href="#cit/section_5.58">

745258</a>

7453]</p>

7454<p id="_1285" tabindex="-1">

7455A study of 587 individuals with a single primary melanoma or MPM found <em class="gene-name">

7456CDKN2A</em>

7457 pathogenic variants in 19% of individuals with MPM relative to 4.4% of individuals with a single primary melanoma.[<a href="#cit/section_5.59">

745859</a>

7459] <em class="gene-name">

7460CDKN2A</em>

7461 pathogenic variants were found in 29.6% of individuals with three or more primary melanomas. Fifty-eight percent of individuals with more than three primary melanomas and family histories of melanoma (undefined) had a <em class="gene-name">

7462CDKN2A</em>

7463 pathogenic variant. A second, smaller study of 46 patients with three or more primary melanomas found <em class="gene-name">

7464CDKN2A</em>

7465 pathogenic variants in 24% of participants.[<a href="#cit/section_5.60">

746660</a>

7467]</p>

7468<p id="_167" tabindex="-1">

7469Depending on the study design and target population, melanoma penetrance related to <em class="gene-name">

7470CDKN2A</em>

7471 pathogenic variants differs widely. One study of 80 multiple-case families demonstrated that the penetrance varied by country, an observation that was attributed to major differences in sun exposure.[<a href="#cit/section_5.61">

747261</a>

7473] For example, in Australia, the penetrance was 30% by age 50 years and 91% by age 80 years; in the United States, the penetrance was 50% by age 50 years and 76% by age 80 years; in Europe, the penetrance was 13% by age 50 years and 58% by age 80 years. In contrast, a comparison of families with the <em class="gene-name">

7474CDKN2A</em>

7475 pathogenic variant in the United Kingdom and Australia demonstrated the same cumulative risk of melanoma; for <em class="gene-name">

7476CDKN2A</em>

7477 carriers, the risk of developing melanoma seemed independent of ambient UV radiation.[<a href="#cit/section_5.62">

747862</a>

7479] Another study of individuals with melanoma identified in eight population-based cancer registries and one hospital-based sample obtained a self-reported family history and sequenced <em class="gene-name">

7480CDKN2A</em>

7481 in all individuals. The penetrance was estimated as 14% by age 50 years and 28% by age 80 years.[<a href="#cit/section_5.38">

748238</a>

7483] The explanation for these differences lies in the method of identifying the individuals tested, with penetrance estimates increasing with the number of affected family members. The method of family ascertainment in the latter study made it much less likely that &#8220;heavily loaded&#8221; melanoma families would be identified. Coinheritance of <em class="gene-name">

7484MC1R</em>

7485 variants also increases <em class="gene-name">

7486CDKN2A</em>

7487 penetrance; this genetic variant, described in further detail below, is therefore both a low-penetrance susceptibility gene and a modifier gene.[<a href="#cit/section_5.63">

748863</a>

7489] For more information, see the section on <em class="gene-name">

7490<a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_359">

7491MC1R</a>

7492</em>

7493 in the Melanoma section. Other modifier <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460162&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460162&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7494loci</a>

7495 have also been assessed in <em class="gene-name">

7496CDKN2A</em>

7497 carriers; interleukin-9 (<em class="gene-name">

7498IL9</em>

7499) and <em class="gene-name">

7500GSTT1</em>

7501 were the only loci with effects that reached statistical significance, suggesting that other minor risk factors may interact with major risk loci.[<a href="#cit/section_5.64">

750264</a>

7503,<a href="#cit/section_5.65">

750465</a>

7505]</p>

7506<p id="_858" tabindex="-1">

7507One study reported a melanoma incidence rate of 9.9 per 1,000 person years among 354 FDRs and 2.1 per 1,000 person years among 391 SDRs of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460211&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460211&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7508probands</a>

7509 with a p16-Leiden (c.225-243del19) <em class="gene-name">

7510CDKN2A</em>

7511 pathogenic variant (95% CIs of 7.4&#8211;13.3 and 1.2&#8211;3.8, respectively). These data indicate a melanoma rate that is much higher than that of the general population (12.9-fold increased incidence) for SDRs in untested relatives of carriers of <em class="gene-name">

7512CDKN2A</em>

7513 pathogenic variants.[<a href="#cit/section_5.66">

751466</a>

7515]</p>

7516<p id="_644" tabindex="-1">

7517A study compared the clinical features of 7,695 individuals with melanoma (182 individuals had a <em class="gene-name">

7518CDKN2A</em>

7519 pathogenic variant and 7,513 did not have a <em class="gene-name">

7520CDKN2A</em>

7521 pathogenic variant). Results showed that individuals with a<em class="gene-name">

7522 CDKN2A</em>

7523 pathogenic variant were significantly younger when they were diagnosed with melanoma (mean age at diagnosis for individuals with a <em class="gene-name">

7524CDKN2A</em>

7525 pathogenic variant vs. individuals without a <em class="gene-name">

7526CDKN2A</em>

7527 pathogenic variant, 39.0 y vs. 54.3 y; <em>

7528P</em>

7529 &lt; .001). Individuals with a <em class="gene-name">

7530CDKN2A</em>

7531 pathogenic variant also had an increased chance of developing a second melanoma after 5 years when compared with the control group (5-year cumulative incidence rate for <em class="gene-name">

7532CDKN2A</em>

7533 carriers, 23%; 5-year cumulative incidence rate for individuals in the control group, 2.3%).[<a href="#cit/section_5.67">

753467</a>

7535] A study of pediatric patients with melanoma (ages 9&#8211;19 y) in melanoma-prone families also reported a significant increase in melanoma prevalence (6-fold to 28-fold) relative to the general population. In this series, 7 of 21 patients (33%) with <em class="gene-name">

7536CDKN2A</em>

7537 pathogenic variants were diagnosed with MPMs before age 20 years.[<a href="#cit/section_5.68">

753868</a>

7539] An Italian study performed genotype-phenotype correlations in 100 families with familial melanoma to determine clinical features that are predictive of <em class="gene-name">

7540CDKN2A</em>

7541 pathogenic variants. Probands with MPMs, at least one melanoma with a Breslow thickness greater than 0.4 mm, and more than three affected family members had a greater than 90% likelihood of having a <em class="gene-name">

7542CDKN2A</em>

7543 pathogenic variant; probands with none of these features had less than a 1% likelihood of having a <em class="gene-name">

7544CDKN2A</em>

7545 pathogenic variant. Overall, the presence of MPMs was the most predictive feature in this study.[<a href="#cit/section_5.69">

754669</a>

7547] </p>

7548<p id="_1033" tabindex="-1">

7549Carriers of <em class="gene-name">

7550CDKN2A</em>

7551 pathogenic variants have melanomas that resemble sporadic melanomas. A large study that compared melanoma pathology between <em class="gene-name">

7552CDKN2A</em>

7553 carriers and individuals with sporadic melanoma found few significant differences, with a minor trend of increased pigmentation among pathogenic variant carriers.[<a href="#cit/section_5.70">

755470</a>

7555] Another study of more than 670 carriers of <em class="gene-name">

7556CDKN2A</em>

7557 pathogenic variants and 1,258 carriers of wild-type or benign <em class="gene-name">

7558CDKN2A</em>

7559 variants found that participants with pathogenic variants were more likely to be diagnosed at an earlier age (median age, 38 y vs. 46 y) and have MPM (average number of melanomas, 2.3 vs. 1.4).[<a href="#cit/section_5.71">

756071</a>

7561] A small study compared the overall survival (OS) rates of 106 carriers of <em class="gene-name">

7562CDKN2A</em>

7563 pathogenic variants and 199 <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=556483&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000556483&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7564noncarriers</a>

7565 who did not have family histories of melanoma. <em class="gene-name">

7566CDKN2A</em>

7567 carriers were more likely to have MPMs. However, there was no significant difference in OS or disease-specific survival rates between carriers and noncarriers.[<a href="#cit/section_5.72">

756872</a>

7569] However, two pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

7570CDKN2A</em>

7571 (p.Arg112dup, p.Pro48Leu) may be prognostic factors in patients with melanoma. After adjusting for age, sex, and tumor classification, carriers of these <em class="gene-name">

7572CDKN2A</em>

7573 pathogenic variants had poorer melanoma-specific survival than did non-<em class="gene-name">

7574CDKN2A</em>

7575 carriers (HR, 2.5; 95% CI, 1.49&#8211;2.21).[<a href="#cit/section_5.73">

757673</a>

7577] An early study suggested that somatic <em class="gene-name">

7578NRAS</em>

7579 mutations occurred at a higher rate in melanomas diagnosed in Swedish families who carry <em class="gene-name">

7580CDKN2A</em>

7581 pathogenic variants when compared with those who had sporadic melanomas.[<a href="#cit/section_5.74">

758274</a>

7583] However, subsequent studies found that the rates of common somatic mutations (<em class="gene-name">

7584BRAF</em>

7585, <em class="gene-name">

7586NRAS</em>

7587) were lower in the melanomas of <em class="gene-name">

7588CDKN2A</em>

7589 carriers than in the sporadic melanomas found in the control group.[<a href="#cit/section_5.75">

759075</a>

7591,<a href="#cit/section_5.76">

759276</a>

7593] Several patients with <em class="gene-name">

7594CDKN2A</em>

7595 variants had melanomas with coexisting <em class="gene-name">

7596BRAF</em>

7597 and <em class="gene-name">

7598NRAS</em>

7599 mutations; this is an uncommon occurrence in sporadic melanomas.[<a href="#cit/section_5.76">

760076</a>

7601] Data from a small series of patients suggests that melanoma patients with <em class="gene-name">

7602CDKN2A</em>

7603 pathogenic variants may have improved response rates to immunotherapy when compared with noncarriers; however, further data are needed in this area. [<a href="#cit/section_5.77">

760477</a>

7605]</p>

7606<p id="_552" tabindex="-1">

7607<em class="gene-name">

7608CDKN2A</em>

7609 exon 1&#223; pathogenic variants (<em class="gene-name">

7610p14<span class="sup">

7611ARF</span>

7612</em>

7613) have been identified in a small percentage of families negative for <em class="gene-name">

7614p16<span class="sup">

7615INK4a</span>

7616</em>

7617 pathogenic variants. In a study of 94 Italian families with two or more cases of melanoma, 3.2% of families had variants in <em class="gene-name">

7618p14<span class="sup">

7619ARF</span>

7620</em>

7621.[<a href="#cit/section_5.78">

762278</a>

7623] A patient with a balanced translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22 that disrupted <em class="gene-name">

7624p14<span class="sup">

7625ARF</span>

7626</em>

7627 had melanoma, DNA repair deficiency, and features of DiGeorge syndrome, including deafness and malformed inner ears.[<a href="#cit/section_5.79">

762879</a>

7629] </p>

7630<p id="_1232" tabindex="-1">

7631There are models that can predict whether an individual has a pathogenic variant in <em class="gene-name">

7632CDKN2A</em>

7633.[<a href="#cit/section_5.80">

763480</a>

7635,<a href="#cit/section_5.81">

763681</a>

7637] However, in the era of widely available and inexpensive multigene (panel) testing, these models are not widely utilized clinically.</p>

7638<section id="_885">

7639<h5 id="_885_toc">

7640<em class="gene-name">

7641CDKN2A</em>

7642, cutaneous phenotypes, and cancers other than melanoma</h5>

7643<p id="_1113" tabindex="-1">

7644In a Melanoma Genetics Consortium (GenoMEL) study of 1,641 family members of melanoma probands, family members with a <em class="gene-name">

7645CDKN2A</em>

7646 pathogenic variant were more likely to have atypical nevi than were family members of <em class="gene-name">

7647CDKN2A</em>

7648 noncarriers (odds ratio [OR], 1.65; 95% CI, 1.18&#8211;2.28).[<a href="#cit/section_5.82">

764982</a>

7650] Another study of individuals in Sweden with MPM and two or more cases of melanoma in their first-, second-, or third-degree relatives found <em class="gene-name">

7651CDKN2A</em>

7652 pathogenic variants in 43 of 100 cases. Familial MPM cases with <em class="gene-name">

7653CDKN2A</em>

7654 variants, familial MPM cases wild-type for <em class="gene-name">

7655CDKN2A</em>

7656, and nonfamilial MPM cases all showed increased risks of future cutaneous SCCs compared with controls (relative risk [RR], 4.8; 95% CI, 1.5&#8211;15.1).[<a href="#cit/section_5.83">

765783</a>

7658] </p>

7659<p id="_886" tabindex="-1">

7660Results from the Genes, Environment, and Melanoma (GEM) study showed that FDRs of carriers of <em class="gene-name">

7661CDKN2A</em>

7662 pathogenic variants with melanoma had an approximately 50% increased risk of cancers other than melanoma, compared with FDRs of other melanoma patients.[<a href="#cit/section_5.84">

766384</a>

7664] Cancers with increased risk in this population included gastrointestinal cancers (RR, 2.4; 95% CI, 1.4&#8211;3.7), pancreatic cancers (RR, 7.4; 95% CI, 2.3&#8211;18.7), and Wilms tumor (RR, 40.4; 95% CI, 3.4&#8211;352.7). A Spanish study of the FDRs of 66 melanoma patients with known <em class="gene-name">

7665CDKN2A</em>

7666 pathogenic variants also showed an increase in prevalence of other cancers, including pancreatic (prevalence ratio [PR], 2.97; 95% CI, 1.72&#8211;5.15), lung (PR, 3.04; 95% CI, 1.93&#8211;4.80), and breast cancers (PR, 2.19; 95% CI, 1.36&#8211;3.55).[<a href="#cit/section_5.85">

766785</a>

7668] A large registry study from Sweden that included 27 families carrying the Arg112dup pathogenic variant in <em class="gene-name">

7669CDKN2A</em>

7670 observed excess nonmelanoma cancers in both carriers (n = 120) and FDRs (n = 275). For carriers of <em class="gene-name">

7671CDKN2A</em>

7672 pathogenic variants, increased risks relative to a control population were seen for pancreatic (RR, 43.8; 95% CI, 13.8&#8211;139), upper digestive (RR, 17.1; 95% CI, 6.3&#8211;46.5), respiratory (RR, 15.6; 95% CI, 5.4&#8211;46.0), and breast cancers (RR 3.0; 95% CI, 0.9&#8211;9.9), among others (all cancers: RR, 5.0; 95% CI, 3.7&#8211;7.3). The RRs in FDRs were 20.6 (95% CI, 11.6&#8211;36.7) for pancreatic cancers, 6.0 (95% CI, 2.8&#8211;13.1) for respiratory cancers, 3.3 (95% CI, 1.5&#8211;7.6) for upper digestive cancers, and 1.9 (95% CI, 0.9&#8211;4.0) for breast cancers, with a RR of all cancers of 2.1 (95% CI, 1.6&#8211;2.7). A lesser-increased cancer risk was seen among SDRs. They also observed a significant association between smoking and risk of pancreatic, respiratory, and upper digestive cancers, with an OR of 9.3 (95% CI, 1.9&#8211;44.7) for ever-smoking carriers compared with never-smoking carriers.[<a href="#cit/section_5.86">

767386</a>

7674] One study of individuals with <em class="gene-name">

7675CDKN2A</em>

7676 pathogenic variants that affected both p16 and p14ARF transcripts found an increased incidence of esophageal cancers and malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors, although the reported incidence for both of these tumors was very small.[<a href="#cit/section_5.87">

767787</a>

7678]</p>

7679<p id="_1133" tabindex="-1">

7680A few studies have identified individuals with sarcoma who have germline pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

7681CDKN2A</em>

7682, but the number of cases is too small to determine the risk of sarcoma associated with this gene.[<a href="#cit/section_5.88">

768388</a>

7684,<a href="#cit/section_5.89">

768589</a>

7686] One patient with features of Li-Fraumeni syndrome did not carry a <em class="gene-name">

7687TP53</em>

7688 pathogenic variant, but a deletion of <em class="gene-name">

7689CDKN2A</em>

7690 and <em class="gene-name">

7691CDKN2B</em>

7692.[<a href="#cit/section_5.89">

769389</a>

7694] A <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=740459&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000740459&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7695whole-exome sequencing</a>

7696 study of a Li-Fraumeni&#8211;like family with three individuals with soft tissue sarcoma identified a shared pathogenic <em class="gene-name">

7697CDKN2A</em>

7698 variant.[<a href="#cit/section_5.88">

769988</a>

7700] An evaluation of 474 melanoma families with cases of sarcoma and 190 <em class="gene-name">

7701TP53</em>

7702 variant&#8211;negative Li-Fraumeni&#8211;like families found eight additional individuals with sarcoma and pathogenic <em class="gene-name">

7703CDKN2A</em>

7704 variants.</p>

7705<section id="_181">

7706<h6 id="_181_toc">

7707Pancreatic cancer</h6>

7708<p id="_347" tabindex="-1">

7709A subset of families carrying a <em class="gene-name">

7710CDKN2A</em>

7711 pathogenic variant also displays an increased risk of pancreatic cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_5.90">

771290</a>

7713,<a href="#cit/section_5.91">

771491</a>

7715] The overall lifetime risk of pancreatic cancer in these families ranges from 11% to 17%.[<a href="#cit/section_5.92">

771692</a>

7717] The RR has been reported as high as 47.8.[<a href="#cit/section_5.93">

771893</a>

7719] Although at least 18 different variants in <em class="gene-name">

7720p16</em>

7721 have been identified in such families, specific pathogenic variants appear to have a particularly elevated risk of pancreatic cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_5.30">

772230</a>

7723,<a href="#cit/section_5.94">

772494</a>

7725] Pathogenic variants affecting splice sites or Ankyrin repeats were found more commonly in families with both pancreatic cancer and melanoma than in those with melanoma alone. The <em class="gene-name">

7726p16</em>

7727 Leiden variant is a 19-<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460130&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460130&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7728base pair</a>

7729 <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460141&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460141&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7730deletion</a>

7731 in <em class="gene-name">

7732CDKN2A</em>

7733 exon 2 and is a founder pathogenic variant originating in the Netherlands. In one major Dutch study, 19 families with 86 members who had melanoma also had 19 members with pancreatic cancer in their families, a cumulative risk of 17% by age 75 years. In this study, the median age of pancreatic cancer onset was 58 years, similar to the median age at onset for sporadic pancreatic cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_5.95">

773495</a>

7735] However, other reports indicate that the average age at diagnosis is 5.8 years earlier for these carriers of pathogenic variants than for those with sporadic pancreatic cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_5.96">

773696</a>

7737] Geographic variation may play a role in determining pancreatic risk in these families carrying known pathogenic variants. In a multicontinent study of the features of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460154&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460154&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7738germline</a>

7739 <em class="gene-name">

7740CDKN2A</em>

7741 pathogenic variants, Australian families carrying these variants did not have an increased risk of pancreatic cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_5.97">

774297</a>

7743] It was also reported that similar <em class="gene-name">

7744CDKN2A</em>

7745 variants were involved in families with and without pancreatic cancer;[<a href="#cit/section_5.98">

774698</a>

7747] therefore, there are additional factors involved in the development of melanoma and pancreatic cancer. Some families with <em class="gene-name">

7748CDKN2A</em>

7749 pathogenic variants may have a pattern of site-specific pancreatic cancer only.[<a href="#cit/section_5.99">

775099</a>

7751-<a href="#cit/section_5.101">

7752101</a>

7753] Conversely, melanoma-prone families that do not have a <em class="gene-name">

7754CDKN2A</em>

7755 pathogenic variant have not been shown to have an increased risk of pancreatic cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_5.95">

775695</a>

7757]</p>

7758<p id="_544" tabindex="-1">

7759In a review of 110 families with multiple cases of pancreatic cancer, 18 showed an association between pancreatic cancer and melanoma.[<a href="#cit/section_5.102">

7760102</a>

7761] Only 5 of the 18 families with cases of both pancreatic cancer and melanoma had individuals with multiple dysplastic nevi. These 18 families were assessed for pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

7762CDKN2A</em>

7763; variants were identified in only 2 of the 18 families, neither of which had a dysplastic nevi phenotype. </p>

7764</section>

7765</section>

7766<section id="_183">

7767<h5 id="_183_toc">

7768Melanoma-astrocytoma syndrome</h5>

7769<p id="_184" tabindex="-1">

7770The melanoma-astrocytoma syndrome is another phenotype caused by pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

7771CDKN2A</em>

7772. The possible existence of this disorder was first described in 1993.[<a href="#cit/section_5.103">

7773103</a>

7774] A study of 904 individuals with melanoma and their families found 15 families with 17 members who had both melanoma and multiple types of tumors of the nervous system.[<a href="#cit/section_5.104">

7775104</a>

7776] Another study found a family with multiple melanoma and neural cell tumors that appeared to be caused by loss of p14<span class="sup">

7777ARF</span>

7778 function or to disruption of expression of p16.[<a href="#cit/section_5.105">

7779105</a>

7780] Plexiform neurofibromas have also been reported in individuals with <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=556486&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000556486&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7781deleterious</a>

7782 <em class="gene-name">

7783CDKN2A</em>

7784 variants.[<a href="#cit/section_5.106">

7785106</a>

7786-<a href="#cit/section_5.109">

7787109</a>

7788]</p>

7789</section>

7790</section>

7791<section id="_168">

7792<h4 id="_168_toc">

7793<em class="gene-name">

7794CDK4 and CDK6</em>

7795</h4>

7796<p id="_169" tabindex="-1">

7797Cyclin-dependent kinases have important roles in progression of cells from G1 to S phase. CDK4 and CDK6 partner with the cyclin&#8211;D associated kinases to accelerate the function of the cell cycle. Phosphorylation of the retinoblastoma (Rb) protein in G1 by cyclin-dependent kinases releases <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=390290&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000390290&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7798transcription</a>

7799 factors, inducing gene expression and metabolic changes that precede DNA replication, thus allowing the cell to progress through the cell cycle. These genes are of conceptual significance because they are in the same signaling pathway as <em class="gene-name">

7800CDKN2A</em>

7801.</p>

7802<p id="_371" tabindex="-1">

7803Germline <em class="gene-name">

7804CDK4</em>

7805 pathogenic variants are very rare, being found in only a handful of melanoma <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460158&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460158&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7806kindreds</a>

7807.[<a href="#cit/section_5.110">

7808110</a>

7809-<a href="#cit/section_5.112">

7810112</a>

7811] All described families demonstrated a substitution of amino acid 24, suggesting this position as a variant hotspot within the <em class="gene-name">

7812CDK4</em>

7813 gene. Three Latvian families with melanoma have a R24H substitution arising on the same <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=485392&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000485392&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7814haplotype</a>

7815, which suggests that it could be a founder pathogenic variant in this population.[<a href="#cit/section_5.113">

7816113</a>

7817] A <em class="gene-name">

7818CDK4</em>

7819 pathogenic variant affects binding of p16 with its subsequent inhibition of <em class="gene-name">

7820CDK4</em>

7821 functionality. With constitutive activation of germline <em class="gene-name">

7822CDK4</em>

7823, <em class="gene-name">

7824CDK4</em>

7825 acts as a dominant oncogene.

7826A small study showed that the melanoma cancer risk in 17 families with <em class="gene-name">

7827CDK4</em>

7828 pathogenic variants was similar to the risk seen in families with <em class="gene-name">

7829CDKN2A</em>

7830 variants.[<a href="#cit/section_5.114">

7831114</a>

7832] In addition, the melanomas found in <em class="gene-name">

7833CDK4</em>

7834 families appear to have similar rates of somatic <em class="gene-name">

7835BRAF</em>

7836 mutations to those found in sporadic populations, although because of the rare nature of <em class="gene-name">

7837CDK4</em>

7838 germline variants, the data are necessarily limited.[<a href="#cit/section_5.115">

7839115</a>

7840] Despite many similarities, one study of 54 melanomas from 15 <em class="gene-name">

7841CDK4</em>

7842 pathogenic variant carriers, 348 melanomas from 141 <em class="gene-name">

7843CDKN2A</em>

7844 pathogenic variant carriers, and 157 melanomas from 104 noncarriers found that tumors in <em class="gene-name">

7845CDK4</em>

7846 carriers were far more likely to arise on nontruncal areas (87% versus 45% in noncarriers [<em>

7847P</em>

7848 &lt; .0001] and 62% in <em class="gene-name">

7849CDKN2A</em>

7850 carriers).[<a href="#cit/section_5.116">

7851116</a>

7852] For more information, see the <em class="gene-name">

7853<a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_165">

7854CDKN2A/p16 and p14/ARF</a>

7855</em>

7856 section.</p>

7857<p id="_372" tabindex="-1">

7858Despite its functional similarity to <em class="gene-name">

7859CDK4</em>

7860, <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=781852&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000781852&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7861germline variants</a>

7862 in <em class="gene-name">

7863CDK6</em>

7864 have not been identified in any melanoma kindreds.[<a href="#cit/section_5.117">

7865117</a>

7866]</p>

7867</section>

7868<section id="_834">

7869<h4 id="_834_toc">

7870Telomere maintenance genes</h4>

7871<section id="_741">

7872<h5 id="_741_toc">

7873Telomerase reverse transcriptase (<em class="gene-name">

7874TERT</em>

7875)</h5>

7876<p id="_742" tabindex="-1">

7877While somatic activating variants in <em class="gene-name">

7878TERT </em>

7879are seen often in multiple cancer types, including sporadic melanoma, germline pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

7880TERT</em>

7881 are found rarely in melanoma families.[<a href="#cit/section_5.118">

7882118</a>

7883] A pathogenic variant in the promoter region of a <em class="gene-name">

7884TERT</em>

7885 subunit was found in a single, large German kindred with multiple melanomas and other cancers (ovarian, renal, bladder, and lung). This pathogenic variant had increased promoter activity in construct assays.[<a href="#cit/section_5.119">

7886119</a>

7887] A detailed analysis of family members from this kindred was performed in 2022, and it emphasized the young ages at which melanoma was diagnosed in this kindred (median age at diagnosis, 30 y).[<a href="#cit/section_5.120">

7888120</a>

7889]</p>

7890<p id="_1338" tabindex="-1">

7891The frequency of <em class="gene-name">

7892TERT</em>

7893 promoter variants in melanoma families has not been fully investigated, but one study of 273 families with three or more cases of melanoma identified only one family (with 7 melanoma cases) that carried a c.-57 T&gt;G <em class="gene-name">

7894TERT</em>

7895 promoter variant.[<a href="#cit/section_5.121">

7896121</a>

7897] Another study observed 202 Spanish families with two or more melanomas in which a <em class="gene-name">

7898TERT</em>

7899 germline pathogenic variant was not identified.[<a href="#cit/section_5.122">

7900122</a>

7901] </p>

7902<p id="_1286" tabindex="-1">

7903The pathogenicity of rs2853669, a specific <em class="gene-name">

7904TERT</em>

7905 variant, is up for interpretation since it has a high prevalence in the general population. The prevalence of this variant in the general population is estimated to be between 25% and 29%. A study of 106 familial melanoma cases (defined as at least two melanoma cases or MPM in the proband) found that 47% of MPM cases and 58% of familial melanoma cases carried this <em class="gene-name">

7906TERT</em>

7907 promoter variant.[<a href="#cit/section_5.49">

790849</a>

7909,<a href="#cit/section_5.123">

7910123</a>

7911]</p>

7912</section>

7913<section id="_835">

7914<h5 id="_835_toc">

7915<em class="gene-name">

7916POT1</em>

7917</h5>

7918<p id="_836" tabindex="-1">

7919Exome and genome-sequencing in individuals from hereditary melanoma families led to the identification of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=783964&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000783964&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7920missense pathogenic variants</a>

7921 in <em class="gene-name">

7922POT1</em>

7923 that segregate with disease in numerous studies.[<a href="#cit/section_5.124">

7924124</a>

7925,<a href="#cit/section_5.125">

7926125</a>

7927] A <em class="gene-name">

7928POT1</em>

7929 Ser270Asn missense pathogenic variant was found in 5 of 56 unrelated melanoma families from Italy.[<a href="#cit/section_5.124">

7930124</a>

7931] This variant was not observed in over 2,000 Italian controls. Ser270Asn is thought to be a founder pathogenic variant, as all families with the variant shared a haplotype. Additional <em class="gene-name">

7932POT1</em>

7933 missense pathogenic variants, including Tyr89Cys, Arg137His, and Gln623His, were identified in other melanoma families and were not seen in unaffected controls.[<a href="#cit/section_5.124">

7934124</a>

7935,<a href="#cit/section_5.125">

7936125</a>

7937]</p>

7938<p id="_1308" tabindex="-1">

7939A study of 290 familial melanoma cases (defined as families with at least two melanomas) from the United States, Italy, and Spain identified 16 <em class="gene-name">

7940POT1</em>

7941 carriers in 10 families. Melanomas in <em class="gene-name">

7942POT1</em>

7943 carriers were more likely to have spitzoid morphology (<em>

7944P</em>

7945 &lt; .001) when compared with melanomas in the <em class="gene-name">

7946CDKN2A</em>

7947, <em class="gene-name">

7948CDK4</em>

7949, and non-carrier cohorts. This occurred even though melanomas were diagnosed at similar ages in the <em class="gene-name">

7950CDK4</em>

7951, <em class="gene-name">

7952CDKN2A</em>

7953, and <em class="gene-name">

7954POT1 </em>

7955cohorts. Additionally, melanomas in <em class="gene-name">

7956POT1</em>

7957 carriers were more likely to have moderate- to high-tumor&#8211;infiltrating lymphocytes (<em>

7958P</em>

7959 &lt; .001).[<a href="#cit/section_5.126">

7960126</a>

7961] <em class="gene-name">

7962POT1</em>

7963 pathogenic variants were found in approximately 1.7% to 13.5% of melanoma families who lacked <em class="gene-name">

7964CDKN2A</em>

7965 or <em class="gene-name">

7966CDK4</em>

7967 pathogenic variants; therefore, <em class="gene-name">

7968POT1</em>

7969 may also be associated with hereditary melanoma.[<a href="#cit/section_5.122">

7970122</a>

7971,<a href="#cit/section_5.126">

7972126</a>

7973] <em class="gene-name">

7974POT1</em>

7975 binds to single-stranded telomeric repeat regions and is thought to aid in maintenance of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=643091&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000643091&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7976telomere</a>

7977 length. Most of the variants segregating in families occur in the two oligonucleotide/oligosaccharide-binding <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460145&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460145&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

7978domains</a>

7979 of the protein, which are the portion of the protein critical for binding DNA. Individuals carrying <em class="gene-name">

7980POT1</em>

7981 pathogenic variants showed longer telomere lengths than melanoma cases without the <em class="gene-name">

7982POT1</em>

7983 variants, suggesting a link between disruption in normal telomere length and melanoma.[<a href="#cit/section_5.124">

7984124</a>

7985,<a href="#cit/section_5.125">

7986125</a>

7987] The clinical utility of testing this gene has not yet been established. </p>

7988</section>

7989<section id="_893">

7990<h5 id="_893_toc">

7991<em class="gene-name">

7992ACD</em>

7993 and <em class="gene-name">

7994TERF2IP</em>

7995</h5>

7996<p id="_894" tabindex="-1">

7997In one study, 510 melanoma families were screened by next-generation sequencing for pathogenic variants in genes in the shelterin complex, which protects chromosomal ends. Six families were found to have variants in <em class="gene-name">

7998ACD</em>

7999, and four families had variants in <em class="gene-name">

8000TERF2IP</em>

8001.[<a href="#cit/section_5.127">

8002127</a>

8003] The <em class="gene-name">

8004ACD</em>

8005 variants clustered in the POT1 binding domain. Because some of these variants did not lead to a truncated protein, the functional significance is not confirmed.</p>

8006</section>

8007</section>

8008<section id="_648">

8009<h4 id="_648_toc">

8010

8011

8012 DNA repair genes</h4>

8013<p id="_649" tabindex="-1">

8014Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP) patients with defective DNA repair have a more than 1,000-fold increase in melanoma risk. These patients are diagnosed with melanoma at a significantly younger age than individuals in the general population; on average, melanoma diagnosis occurs at age 22 years in XP patients.[<a href="#cit/section_5.128">

8015128</a>

8016] The anatomic site distribution of melanomas in XP patients is similar to that of the general population.[<a href="#cit/section_5.129">

8017129</a>

8018,<a href="#cit/section_5.130">

8019130</a>

8020]</p>

8021<p id="_650" tabindex="-1">

8022Genetic <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44805&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000044805&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

8023polymorphisms</a>

8024 associated with DNA repair genes have been associated with mildly increased melanoma risk in the general population.[<a href="#cit/section_5.131">

8025131</a>

8026] A meta-analysis of eight case-control studies comprising more than 5,000 cases and 7,000 controls found that individuals carrying the Asp1104His polymorphism in <em class="gene-name">

8027XPG</em>

8028 had an increased risk of melanoma (OR, 2.42; 95% CI, 2.26&#8211;2.60).[<a href="#cit/section_5.132">

8029132</a>

8030] For more information, see the section on <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_126">

8031Xeroderma pigmentosum</a>

8032 in the Squamous Cell Carcinoma section.</p>

8033</section>

8034<section id="_786">

8035<h4 id="_786_toc">

8036BRCA1-associated protein 1 (<em class="gene-name">

8037BAP1</em>

8038)</h4>

8039<p id="_787" tabindex="-1">

8040<em class="gene-name">

8041BAP1</em>

8042 has recently emerged as a gene implicated both in sporadic and hereditary melanomas.[<a href="#cit/section_5.133">

8043133</a>

8044] Originally described in a cohort of uveal melanoma patients, <em class="gene-name">

8045BAP1</em>

8046 is a tumor suppressor gene that was found to be inactivated in 84% of uveal melanoma patients with metastases.[<a href="#cit/section_5.134">

8047134</a>

8048] Although the majority of these variants were somatic, one patient was found to have a germline <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=783963&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000783963&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

8049frameshift variant</a>

8050. A phenotype associated with <em class="gene-name">

8051BAP1</em>

8052 pathogenic variants was subsequently described.[<a href="#cit/section_5.135">

8053135</a>

8054] Two families with multiple, elevated melanocytic tumors that were clinically and histopathologically distinct from other melanocytic neoplasms were found to have inactivating germline pathogenic variants of <em class="gene-name">

8055BAP1</em>

8056. These tumors, which have been termed melanocytic <em class="gene-name">

8057BAP1</em>

8058-mutated atypical intradermal tumors, or MBAITs, are found throughout the body, generally measure approximately 5 mm, and begin to appear in the second decade of life. MBAITs are 2 mm to 10 mm in diameter, and affected individuals (about 67% of <em class="gene-name">

8059BAP1</em>

8060 pathogenic variant carriers) can have 5 to more than 50 skin lesions.[<a href="#cit/section_5.135">

8061135</a>

8062,<a href="#cit/section_5.136">

8063136</a>

8064] Cases of cutaneous melanoma were present in these families, but the rate of malignant progression is thought to be low due to the relative lack of melanomas in comparison with the number of more papular tumors. This syndrome has been called <em class="gene-name">

8065BAP1</em>

8066 tumor syndrome or the COMMON (<strong>

8067c</strong>

8068utaneous and <strong>

8069o</strong>

8070cular <strong>

8071m</strong>

8072elanoma and atypical <strong>

8073m</strong>

8074elanocytic proliferation with <strong>

8075o</strong>

8076ther internal <strong>

8077n</strong>

8078eoplasms) syndrome, and it is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern.[<a href="#cit/section_5.137">

8079137</a>

8080] Further investigation has supported the association between familial cutaneous melanoma and uveal melanoma in <em class="gene-name">

8081BAP1</em>

8082 carriers.[<a href="#cit/section_5.138">

8083138</a>

8084-<a href="#cit/section_5.142">

8085142</a>

8086] However, potentially pathogenic <em class="gene-name">

8087BAP1</em>

8088 germline variants occur in a low percentage of melanoma cases. One targeted sequencing study of 1,109 unselected cutaneous melanoma cases found only seven germline missense pathogenic variants (&lt;1%).[<a href="#cit/section_5.45">

808945</a>

8090] A second series of 1,977 melanoma cases and 754 controls identified 22 rare variants in <em class="gene-name">

8091BAP1</em>

8092 among cases and 5 rare variants among controls; three of the variants found only among cases were confirmed to disrupt BAP1 function and were associated with family histories of other <em class="gene-name">

8093BAP1</em>

8094-associated cancers.[<a href="#cit/section_5.143">

8095143</a>

8096] In support of a link between melanoma risk and <em class="gene-name">

8097BAP1</em>

8098, in one series, about 18% of individuals with a <em class="gene-name">

8099BAP1</em>

8100 pathogenic variant developed melanoma.[<a href="#cit/section_5.139">

8101139</a>

8102] In addition, although data are currently limited, patients with germline pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

8103BAP1</em>

8104 may be at increased risk of lung adenocarcinoma, mesothelioma, BCC, and clear cell carcinoma of the kidney.[<a href="#cit/section_5.136">

8105136</a>

8106,<a href="#cit/section_5.138">

8107138</a>

8108,<a href="#cit/section_5.140">

8109140</a>

8110,<a href="#cit/section_5.141">

8111141</a>

8112,<a href="#cit/section_5.144">

8113144</a>

8114,<a href="#cit/section_5.145">

8115145</a>

8116]</p>

8117<p id="_815" tabindex="-1">

8118Other studies have reported pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

8119BAP1</em>

8120. A missense <em class="gene-name">

8121BAP1</em>

8122 pathogenic variant (p.Leu570Val) was described in a family with multiple cases of melanoma. This missense variant affected splicing and resulted in a truncated protein. This family also reported cases of uveal melanoma and paraganglioma.[<a href="#cit/section_5.144">

8123144</a>

8124] Another family with a Y646X <em class="gene-name">

8125BAP1</em>

8126 pathogenic variant reported multiple cancers including multiple cutaneous melanomas, BCCs, uveal melanomas, and mesotheliomas.[<a href="#cit/section_5.146">

8127146</a>

8128] The authors hypothesized that a genetic-environmental interaction between <em class="gene-name">

8129BAP1</em>

8130 pathogenic variants, UV radiation, and asbestos exposure contributed to the high incidence of cancers in this family.</p>

8131<p id="_1293" tabindex="-1">

8132A Markov simulation study estimated the survival and economic impacts of screening <em class="gene-name">

8133BAP1</em>

8134 pathogenic variant carriers for the four most common cancers associated with <em class="gene-name">

8135BAP1</em>

8136&#8211;predisposition syndrome (renal cancer, uveal melanoma, cutaneous melanoma, and mesothelioma). The researchers found that surveillance was cost-effective, costing approximately $1,265 per life-year gained. Survival also improved with <em class="gene-name">

8137BAP1</em>

8138-associated surveillance (50.2% of <em class="gene-name">

8139BAP1</em>

8140-related deaths occurred in the group that did not receive surveillance, whereas only 35.4% of <em class="gene-name">

8141BAP1</em>

8142-related deaths occurred in the group that received surveillance). The study estimated that only 171 deaths out of 10,000 individuals in the screened group were due to cutaneous melanoma, whereas 768 deaths out of 10,000 individuals in the nonscreened group were due to cutaneous melanoma.[<a href="#cit/section_5.147">

8143147</a>

8144]</p>

8145</section>

8146<section id="_697">

8147<h4 id="_697_toc">

8148Additional candidate regions for familial melanoma susceptibility</h4>

8149<p id="_698" tabindex="-1">

8150Several additional loci for familial melanoma have been identified through <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=636779&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000636779&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

8151genome-wide studies</a>

8152. A melanoma susceptibility <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460162&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460162&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

8153locus</a>

8154 on 1p22 was identified through a <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=425374&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000425374&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

8155linkage analysis</a>

8156 of 49 Australian families who had at least three melanoma cases and who were negative for <em class="gene-name">

8157CDKN2A</em>

8158 and <em class="gene-name">

8159CDK4</em>

8160 pathogenic variants.[<a href="#cit/section_5.148">

8161148</a>

8162] Deletion mapping in tumors shows a minimal region of loss of a 9-Mb interval within the peak linkage region, but none of the linkage families have pathogenic variants in the genes tested thus far.[<a href="#cit/section_5.149">

8163149</a>

8164] A genome-wide association study (GWAS) of individuals from 34 high-risk melanoma families revealed three single nucleotide variants (SNVs) on 10q25.1 associated with melanoma risk.[<a href="#cit/section_5.150">

8165150</a>

8166] The ORs for risk for the SNVs ranged from 6.8 to 8.4. Subsequent parametric linkage analysis in one family showed <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=415709&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000415709&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

8167logarithm of the odd scores</a>

8168 of 1.5, whereas the other two families assessed did not show linkage. No obvious candidate gene was identified in the genomic region of interest. Two genome-wide linkage studies of 35 and 42 Swedish families identified evidence of linkage on chromosomal regions 3q29, 17p11-12, and 18q22.[<a href="#cit/section_5.151">

8169151</a>

8170,<a href="#cit/section_5.152">

8171152</a>

8172] An Italian linkage study showed a suggestive linkage to the same 3q29 locus.[<a href="#cit/section_5.153">

8173153</a>

8174] No causative genes have been confirmed, but candidates map to all of the loci. None of these loci have been confirmed in independent studies.</p>

8175<p id="_801" tabindex="-1">

8176Several GWAS have suggested that a risk locus for melanoma may exist on chromosome 20q11 (OR, 1.27).[<a href="#cit/section_5.154">

8177154</a>

8178,<a href="#cit/section_5.155">

8179155</a>

8180] This is the location of the <em class="gene-name">

8181ASIP</em>

8182 locus that encodes the agouti signaling protein,

8183which controls hair color during the hair growth cycle in some mammals. It acts as an antagonist to <em class="gene-name">

8184MC1R</em>

8185. While <em class="gene-name">

8186ASIP</em>

8187 variation has been associated with differences in human pigmentation,[<a href="#cit/section_5.156">

8188156</a>

8189] initial studies did not find an association between <em class="gene-name">

8190ASIP</em>

8191 variants and melanoma.[<a href="#cit/section_5.157">

8192157</a>

8193] However, other studies have shown that the <em class="gene-name">

8194ASIP</em>

8195 rs56238684 variant is associated with MPM risk (OR, 2.5; 95% CI, 1.7&#8211;3.3).[<a href="#cit/section_5.158">

8196158</a>

8197] Additionally, variants in an <em class="gene-name">

8198ASIP</em>

8199 transcription factor, <em class="gene-name">

8200NCOA6</em>

8201 (which is also on chromosome 20), had a maximum OR of 1.82 for melanoma risk.[<a href="#cit/section_5.155">

8202155</a>

8203] However, no interactions were seen between <em class="gene-name">

8204NCOA6</em>

8205 variants, <em class="gene-name">

8206MC1R</em>

8207 variants, and melanoma risk. The mechanism by which variants at 20q11 cause increased melanoma risk remains unclear.</p>

8208<p id="_887" tabindex="-1">

8209Other risk loci have been reported on chromosomes 2, 5, 6, 7, 9, 10, 11, 15, 16, and 22.[<a href="#cit/section_5.153">

8210153</a>

8211,<a href="#cit/section_5.159">

8212159</a>

8213-<a href="#cit/section_5.164">

8214164</a>

8215]

8216 A GWAS of melanoma published in 2014 examined eight of the loci with a previous significant association with melanoma, but without a confirmed causal gene.[<a href="#cit/section_5.163">

8217163</a>

8218]

8219Researchers were able to confirm seven of eight loci and found some evidence supporting the eighth. These included the chromosome 20 locus discussed above and a 9p21 locus distinct from <em class="gene-name">

8220CDKN2A</em>

8221. Candidate genes at these loci seem to be clustered in functional groups associated with skin pigmentation and nevus development, both traits with a known melanoma association.[<a href="#cit/section_5.165">

8222165</a>

8223] For more information about these traits, see the <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_289">

8224Risk Factors for Melanoma</a>

8225 section. A multicenter meta-analysis of 11 GWAS and two data sets included 15,990 cutaneous melanoma cases and 26,409 controls. They reported five melanoma susceptibility loci that involved putative melanocyte regulatory elements, telomere biology, and DNA repair.[<a href="#cit/section_5.164">

8226164</a>

8227]</p>

8228<p id="_907" tabindex="-1">

8229A publicly available database, MelGene, maintains lists of variants that have been associated with melanoma risk through GWAS. MelGene also includes network and potential functional relationships between these genes and variants.[<a href="#cit/section_5.166">

8230166</a>

8231] </p>

8232</section>

8233<section id="_1127">

8234<h4 id="_1127_toc">

82359q21 and <em class="gene-name">

8236GOLM1</em>

8237</h4>

8238<p id="_1128" tabindex="-1">

8239When the first data linking <em class="gene-name">

8240CDKN2A</em>

8241 pathogenic variants to melanoma risk became available, it was clear that these variants did not account for all the melanoma tumors in which 9p21 <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=464169&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000464169&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

8242loss of heterozygosity</a>

8243 could be demonstrated. In fact, 51% of <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460156&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460156&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

8244informative</a>

8245 cases had deletions that did not involve somatic mutations in <em class="gene-name">

8246CDKN2A</em>

8247.[<a href="#cit/section_5.167">

8248167</a>

8249] There are data that the golgi membrane protein 1 (<em class="gene-name">

8250GOLM1</em>

8251) gene, mapping to 9q21, may be involved in melanoma risk. Exome sequencing of DNA from 12 sets of cousins with cutaneous melanoma who were negative for known high-risk melanoma genes led to the identification of a rare <em class="gene-name">

8252GOLM1</em>

8253 variant (rs149739829) in three affected individuals in one <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44868&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000044868&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

8254pedigree</a>

8255.[<a href="#cit/section_5.168">

8256168</a>

8257] Two additional pairs of related melanoma cases with the putative risk allele were identified. Family-based case-control studies showed association with melanoma risk (OR, 9.81; <em>

8258P</em>

8259 &lt; .001). In a population-based case-control study of 1,534 melanoma cases, unselected for family history, and 1,146 controls, there was an increased risk of melanoma in individuals that carried the <em class="gene-name">

8260GOLM1</em>

8261 rs149739829 risk allele (OR, 2.45; <em>

8262P</em>

8263 = .02).[<a href="#cit/section_5.168">

8264168</a>

8265]</p>

8266</section>

8267</section>

8268<section id="_358">

8269<h3 id="_358_toc">

8270Minor Genes (Genetic Modifiers) for Melanoma</h3>

8271<section id="_359">

8272<h4 id="_359_toc">

8273<em class="gene-name">

8274MC1R</em>

8275</h4>

8276<p id="_360" tabindex="-1">

8277The <em class="gene-name">

8278MC1R</em>

8279 gene, otherwise known as the alpha melanocyte-stimulating hormone receptor, is located on chromosome 8. Partial loss-of-function pathogenic variants, of which there are at least ten, are associated not only with red hair, fair skin, and poor tanning, but also with increased skin cancer risk independent of cutaneous pigmentation.[<a href="#cit/section_5.169">

8280169</a>

8281-<a href="#cit/section_5.172">

8282172</a>

8283] A comprehensive meta-analysis of more than 8,000 cases and 50,000 controls showed the highest risk of melanoma in individuals with <em class="gene-name">

8284MC1R</em>

8285 variants associated with red hair; however, alleles not associated with red hair have also been linked to increased melanoma risk.[<a href="#cit/section_5.173">

8286173</a>

8287] Additional phenotypic associations have been found. In different studies, <em class="gene-name">

8288MC1R</em>

8289 variants were found to be associated with lentigo maligna melanoma (OR, 2.16; 95% CI, 1.07&#8211;4.37; <em>

8290P</em>

8291&#160;=&#160;.044) [<a href="#cit/section_5.174">

8292174</a>

8293] and increased risk of melanoma for individuals with no red hair, no freckles, and Fitzpatrick type III or IV skin (summary OR, 3.14; 95% CI, 2.06&#8211;4.80).[<a href="#cit/section_5.175">

8294175</a>

8295] Pooled studies of 5,160 cases and 12,119 controls from 17 sites calculated that melanoma risk attributable to <em class="gene-name">

8296MC1R</em>

8297 variants is 28%, suggesting that these variants may be an important contributor to melanoma risk in the general population.[<a href="#cit/section_5.175">

8298175</a>

8299] In addition, individuals with MPMs have a high likelihood of carrying an <em class="gene-name">

8300MC1R</em>

8301 pathogenic variant. In one study of 46 individuals with 3 or more primary melanomas, 43 individuals (93%) had an <em class="gene-name">

8302MC1R</em>

8303 pathogenic variant.[<a href="#cit/section_5.60">

830460</a>

8305]</p>

8306<p id="_1069" tabindex="-1">

8307A scoring system has been proposed for <em class="gene-name">

8308MC1R</em>

8309 polymorphisms to identify associations between the degree of functional impairments in the melanogenesis pathway, clinical characteristics of patients, and melanoma presentations. The initial classification system designated <em class="gene-name">

8310MC1R</em>

8311 variants that were strongly associated with red hair and fair skin as strong (R) variants (OR, 63.3; 95% CI, 31.9&#8211;139.6) and <em class="gene-name">

8312MC1R</em>

8313 variants that were weakly associated with red hair and fair skin as weak (r) variants (OR, 5.1; 95% CI, 2.5&#8211;11.3).[<a href="#cit/section_5.176">

8314176</a>

8315] This work was expanded to evaluate additional <em class="gene-name">

8316MC1R</em>

8317 variants, which were scored as follows: a consensus sequence allele was given a value of zero, an r allele was given a value of one, and an R allele was given a value of two. The summary score could range from zero to four.[<a href="#cit/section_5.177">

8318177</a>

8319] A study of 1,044 melanoma patients showed that individuals with a score of three or more were more likely to develop melanoma before age 50 years (OR, 1.47; 95% CI, 1.01&#8211;2.14).[<a href="#cit/section_5.178">

8320178</a>

8321] The <em class="gene-name">

8322MC1R</em>

8323 score has been subsequently found to have implications for a survival benefit in melanoma patients. At least three studies have found a lower risk of death in melanoma patients without consensus <em class="gene-name">

8324MC1R</em>

8325 alleles (HR, 0.78; 95% CI, 0.65&#8211;0.94) when compared with those with at least one <em class="gene-name">

8326MC1R </em>

8327consensus allele (HR, 0.57&#8211;0.78).[<a href="#cit/section_5.177">

8328177</a>

8329,<a href="#cit/section_5.179">

8330179</a>

8331,<a href="#cit/section_5.180">

8332180</a>

8333] However, the survival benefits associated with <em class="gene-name">

8334MC1R</em>

8335 R alleles may only pertain to women.[<a href="#cit/section_5.180">

8336180</a>

8337]</p>

8338<p id="_1035" tabindex="-1">

8339<em class="gene-name">

8340MC1R</em>

8341 variants are associated with an increased risk of all three types of skin cancer. However, adding <em class="gene-name">

8342MC1R</em>

8343 genotype information to skin cancer risk predictions (which are based on age, sex, and cutaneous melanin density), only slightly improved them.[<a href="#cit/section_5.181">

8344181</a>

8345,<a href="#cit/section_5.182">

8346182</a>

8347] In contrast, one study that examined predictors of early-onset melanoma in both population- and family-based studies showed that adding <em class="gene-name">

8348MC1R</em>

8349 genotypes improved the area under the receiver operator curve (AUC) by 6% when compared with demographic information alone (<em>

8350P</em>

8351 &lt; .001). When <em class="gene-name">

8352MC1R</em>

8353 genotypes were combined with an individual's nevi count and history of keratinocyte carcinoma (BCC or SCC), the AUC was 0.78 (95% CI, 0.75&#8211;0.82) for self-reported nevi and 0.83 (95% CI, 0.80&#8211;0.86) for physician-described nevi.[<a href="#cit/section_5.183">

8354183</a>

8355]</p>

8356<p id="_1287" tabindex="-1">

8357Several studies have tried to quantify the increased melanoma incidence seen in individuals with <em class="gene-name">

8358MC1R</em>

8359 variants. An Australian study of 1,267 individuals found that those with an <em class="gene-name">

8360MC1R</em>

8361 R/R genotype and greater than 20 nevi had a 25-fold increased risk of melanoma when compared with those who had a wildtype <em class="gene-name">

8362MC1R</em>

8363 variant and had 0 to 4 nevi. Absolute melanoma risk (to age 75 years) was 23.3% in men with <em class="gene-name">

8364MC1R</em>

8365 R/R genotypes and more than 20 nevi. Similarly, absolute melanoma risk (to age 75 years) was 19.3% in women with <em class="gene-name">

8366MC1R</em>

8367 R/R genotypes and more than 20 nevi.[<a href="#cit/section_5.184">

8368184</a>

8369] A study of 233 young individuals with melanoma, 932 adults with melanoma, and 932 controls found that <em class="gene-name">

8370MC1R</em>

8371 r variants were more common in young melanoma cases (&#8804;20 years) when compared with adult patients aged 35 years and older (OR, 1.54; 95% CI, 1.02&#8211;2.33). The association was more pronounced in individuals aged 18 years and younger (OR, 1.80; 95% CI, 1.06&#8211;3.07).[<a href="#cit/section_5.185">

8372185</a>

8373]</p>

8374<p id="_1204" tabindex="-1">

8375A study of 1,791 individuals assessed if <em class="gene-name">

8376MC1R</em>

8377 variants affect melanoma risk differently in men and women. Carrying two or more <em class="gene-name">

8378MC1R</em>

8379 variants was associated with an increased risk in both women (OR, 2.65; 95% CI, 1.86&#8211;3.79; <em>

8380P</em>

8381 = .001) and men (OR, 1.65; 95% CI, 1.14&#8211;2.38; <em>

8382P</em>

8383 = .007). In a multivariate analysis (which included other risk factors like freckling, wrinkling, sunburns, and solar lentigines), the association between melanoma risk and <em class="gene-name">

8384MC1R</em>

8385 variants was significant in women but not in men.[<a href="#cit/section_5.186">

8386186</a>

8387] A study in 203 individuals without skin cancer found that the <em class="gene-name">

8388MC1R</em>

8389 r variant (p.Val60Leu) was associated with a high nevus count in women (&gt;50 nevi; <em>

8390P</em>

8391 &lt; .001) but not in men. However, the number of individuals in the high-risk group was small.[<a href="#cit/section_5.187">

8392187</a>

8393]</p>

8394<p id="_545" tabindex="-1">

8395<em class="gene-name">

8396MC1R</em>

8397 variants can also modify melanoma risk in individuals with <em class="gene-name">

8398CDKN2A</em>

8399 pathogenic variants. A study consisting of 815 carriers of <em class="gene-name">

8400CDKN2A</em>

8401 pathogenic variants looked at four common non-synonymous <em class="gene-name">

8402MC1R</em>

8403 variants and found that having one variant increased the melanoma risk twofold, but having two or more variants increased melanoma risk nearly sixfold.[<a href="#cit/section_5.188">

8404188</a>

8405] After stratification for hair color, the increased risk of melanoma appeared to be limited to subjects with brown or black hair. These data suggest that <em class="gene-name">

8406MC1R</em>

8407 variants increase melanoma risk in a manner independent of their effect on pigmentation. A meta-analysis of individuals with <em class="gene-name">

8408CDKN2A</em>

8409 pathogenic variants showed that those with greater than one variant in <em class="gene-name">

8410MC1R</em>

8411 had approximately fourfold increased risk of melanoma. Individuals with one or more variants in <em class="gene-name">

8412MC1R</em>

8413 showed an average 10-year decrease in age of onset from 47 to 37 years.[<a href="#cit/section_5.189">

8414189</a>

8415] In contrast, a large consortium study did not show as large a decrease in age at onset of melanoma.[<a href="#cit/section_5.188">

8416188</a>

8417] Another study of Norwegian melanoma cases and controls showed that carriers of <em class="gene-name">

8418CDKN2A</em>

8419 pathogenic variants had an increased risk of melanoma when they carried either the Arg160Trp or Asp84Glu <em class="gene-name">

8420MC1R</em>

8421 variants (R alleles).[<a href="#cit/section_5.190">

8422190</a>

8423] </p>

8424<p id="_1166" tabindex="-1">

8425In addition to studies evaluating the relationship between germline variants and <em class="gene-name">

8426MC1R</em>

8427 variants, multiple groups have assessed whether <em class="gene-name">

8428MC1R</em>

8429 variants are associated with somatic <em class="gene-name">

8430BRAF</em>

8431 mutations. Studies indicate that there may be an association between <em class="gene-name">

8432MC1R</em>

8433 variants and <em class="gene-name">

8434BRAF</em>

8435 V600E somatic mutations.[<a href="#cit/section_5.191">

8436191</a>

8437-<a href="#cit/section_5.194">

8438194</a>

8439] However, it is difficult to determine the impact of pigmentary influences on <em class="gene-name">

8440BRAF</em>

8441 somatic mutations versus genetic effects.

8442</p>

8443</section>

8444<section id="_1070">

8445<h4 id="_1070_toc">

8446Other pigmentary genes</h4>

8447<p id="_1071" tabindex="-1">

8448 Pathogenic variants in albinism genes may also account for a small proportion of familial melanoma. For example, variants in <em class="gene-name">

8449TYRP1</em>

8450, <em class="gene-name">

8451TYR</em>

8452, and <em class="gene-name">

8453OCA2</em>

8454 were observed at an increased frequency in one study of individuals with familial cutaneous melanoma compared with population controls.[<a href="#cit/section_5.195">

8455195</a>

8456] Further studies are needed to confirm these findings. For more information about pigmentary genes that can increase melanoma risk, see the <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_131">

8457Oculocutaneous albinism</a>

8458 section.</p>

8459</section>

8460<section id="_645">

8461<h4 id="_645_toc">

8462<em class="gene-name">

8463MITF</em>

8464</h4>

8465<p id="_646" tabindex="-1">

8466<a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=740456&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000740456&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

8467Whole-genome sequencing</a>

8468 led to the identification of the E318K variant in the microphthalmia&#8211;associated transcription factor (<em class="gene-name">

8469MITF</em>

8470) gene in a family with seven cases of melanoma.[<a href="#cit/section_5.196">

8471196</a>

8472] MITF is a transcription factor that regulates multiple genes that are pertinent to melanocyte function. The <em class="gene-name">

8473MITF</em>

8474 E318K variant impairs normal SUMOylation of MITF. Individuals with the <em class="gene-name">

8475MITF </em>

8476E318K variant are more likely to have fair skin, high nevus counts, high freckling scores, and dark hair.[<a href="#cit/section_5.197">

8477197</a>

8478,<a href="#cit/section_5.198">

8479198</a>

8480] Individuals with the <em class="gene-name">

8481MITF</em>

8482 E318K variant are also more likely to develop clinically amelanotic melanomas, melanomas with nodular subtypes, and multiple primary melanomas.[<a href="#cit/section_5.158">

8483158</a>

8484,<a href="#cit/section_5.197">

8485197</a>

8486-<a href="#cit/section_5.199">

8487199</a>

8488] The <em class="gene-name">

8489MITF</em>

8490 E318K variant is considered a moderate-risk melanoma allele with an OR ranging from 1.7 to 3.0 in cohorts from Australia, the United Kingdom, and Italy.[<a href="#cit/section_5.196">

8491196</a>

8492,<a href="#cit/section_5.200">

8493200</a>

8494,<a href="#cit/section_5.201">

8495201</a>

8496] However, <em class="gene-name">

8497MITF</em>

8498&#8217;s association with increased melanoma risk remains controversial, since not all studies have reproduced similar results. For example, a study in a Polish population of 4,266 cancer patients and 2,114 controls did not find an association between <em class="gene-name">

8499MITF</em>

8500 pathogenic variants and melanoma.[<a href="#cit/section_5.202">

8501202</a>

8502]</p>

8503</section>

8504</section>

8505<section id="_1288">

8506<h3 id="_1288_toc">

8507Other Cancer Susceptibility Genes</h3>

8508<section id="_1289">

8509<h4 id="_1289_toc">

8510<em class="gene-name">

8511BRCA1</em>

8512 and <em class="gene-name">

8513BRCA2</em>

8514</h4>

8515<p id="_759" tabindex="-1">

8516The Breast Cancer Linkage Consortium found that pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

8517BRCA2</em>

8518 were associated with increased melanoma risk (RR, 2.58; 95% CI, 1.3&#8211;5.2).[<a href="#cit/section_5.203">

8519203</a>

8520] A second study reported that <em class="gene-name">

8521BRCA2 </em>

8522pathogenic variant carriers had a similar increase in melanoma risk, although the result fell short of statistical significance.[<a href="#cit/section_5.204">

8523204</a>

8524] In contrast, a large cohort study in the Netherlands showed that <em class="gene-name">

8525BRCA2</em>

8526 pathogenic variant carriers did not have increased melanoma risk; however, the expected incidence of melanoma was rare in this population, and this result reflects a difference of only two melanoma cases.[<a href="#cit/section_5.205">

8527205</a>

8528] Ashkenazi Jewish patients with melanoma do not have increased prevalence of the three common pathogenic founder variants in <em class="gene-name">

8529BRCA1</em>

8530 and <em class="gene-name">

8531BRCA2</em>

8532.[<a href="#cit/section_5.206">

8533206</a>

8534] It is unclear if <em class="gene-name">

8535BRCA1</em>

8536 and <em class="gene-name">

8537BRCA2</em>

8538 pathogenic variants increase melanoma risk based on the current evidence.[<a href="#cit/section_5.207">

8539207</a>

8540,<a href="#cit/section_5.208">

8541208</a>

8542] For more information about the <em class="gene-name">

8543BRCA1</em>

8544 and <em class="gene-name">

8545BRCA2</em>

8546 genes, see <a href="/about-cancer/causes-prevention/genetics/brca-genes-hp-pdq">

8547BRCA1 and BRCA2: Cancer Risks and Management</a>

8548.</p>

8549</section>

8550<section id="_1290">

8551<h4 id="_1290_toc">

8552<em class="gene-name">

8553CHEK2</em>

8554</h4>

8555<p id="_1282" tabindex="-1">

8556Studies have evaluated if other cancer susceptibility genes can increase an individual's risk of developing melanoma. A review of six mostly small retrospective studies of <em class="gene-name">

8557CHEK2</em>

8558, a gene that moderately increases risk for breast cancer and other cancers, did not show a consistent association with increased melanoma risk.[<a href="#cit/section_5.209">

8559209</a>

8560] The largest of these studies evaluated the <em class="gene-name">

8561CHEK2</em>

8562 c.1100delC pathogenic variant in Danish and German patients. This study included 1,905 melanoma cases and 12,860 controls. Data showed that individuals with the <em class="gene-name">

8563CHEK2</em>

8564 c.1100delC pathogenic variant had an increased risk of developing melanoma (OR, 1.7; 95% CI, 1.02&#8211;3.17). The researchers followed up with a meta-analysis of 2,619 cases and 17,481 controls. Similarly, <em class="gene-name">

8565CHEK2</em>

8566 c.1100delC pathogenic variant carriers had an increased risk of developing melanoma (OR, 1.81; 95% CI, 1.07&#8211;3.05).[<a href="#cit/section_5.210">

8567210</a>

8568] The other five studies did not find differences in <em class="gene-name">

8569CHEK2</em>

8570 pathogenic variant frequencies between cases and controls, had too few melanoma cases to make conclusions, and/or did not evaluate the <em class="gene-name">

8571CHEK2 </em>

8572c.1100delC pathogenic variant separately.[<a href="#cit/section_5.209">

8573209</a>

8574] For more information, see the <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_1309">

8575<em class="gene-name">

8576CHEK2</em>

8577</a>

8578 section in Genetics of Breast and Gynecologic Cancers and the <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_651">

8579<em class="gene-name">

8580CHEK2</em>

8581</a>

8582 section in Genetics of Colorectal Cancer.</p>

8583</section>

8584<section id="_1334">

8585<h4 id="_1334_toc">

8586<em class="gene-name">

8587TP53</em>

8588 (Li-Fraumeni syndrome)</h4>

8589<p id="_1335" tabindex="-1">

8590A longitudinal cohort study of 483 individuals with Li-Fraumeni syndrome identified 113 cutaneous malignancies including 42 BCCs, 26 SCCs, 21 melanomas, and 13 cutaneous sarcomas.[<a href="#cit/section_5.211">

8591211</a>

8592] In this cohort, the cumulative incidence of any skin cancer diagnosis was 36.3% by age 70 years. This corresponds to a 7.28-fold increased incidence of melanoma in individuals with Li-Fraumeni syndrome when compared with individuals in the general population. The median age of a melanoma diagnosis was age 42 years in this study (range, 21 y to 68 y), and for 7 of the 17 individuals with melanoma, it was their first cancer. SCC and BCC incidences were similar to those seen in the general population. For more information, see the <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_3755">

8593Li-Fraumeni Syndrome</a>

8594 section in Genetics of Breast and Gynecologic Cancers.</p>

8595</section>

8596<section id="_1291">

8597<h4 id="_1291_toc">

8598<em class="gene-name">

8599PTEN</em>

8600 hamartoma tumor syndromes (including Cowden syndrome)</h4>

8601<p id="_1292" tabindex="-1">

8602Cowden syndrome and Bannayan-Riley-Ruvalcaba syndrome (BRRS) are part of a spectrum of conditions known collectively as <em class="gene-name">

8603PTEN</em>

8604 hamartoma tumor syndromes (PHTS). The term PHTS refers to any patient with a <em class="gene-name">

8605PTEN</em>

8606 pathogenic variant, irrespective of clinical presentation.[<a href="#cit/section_5.212">

8607212</a>

8608] <em class="gene-name">

8609PTEN</em>

8610 functions as a dual-specificity phosphatase that removes phosphate groups from tyrosine, serine, and threonine. Operational criteria for the diagnosis of Cowden syndrome have been published and subsequently updated.[<a href="#cit/section_5.213">

8611213</a>

8612,<a href="#cit/section_5.214">

8613214</a>

8614] These include major, minor, and <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=454769&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000454769&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

8615pathognomonic</a>

8616 criteria, which consist of certain mucocutaneous manifestations such as trichilemmoma and adult-onset dysplastic gangliocytoma of the cerebellum (Lhermitte-Duclos disease). An updated set of criteria based on a systematic literature review has been suggested [<a href="#cit/section_5.215">

8617215</a>

8618] and is currently used in the National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) guidelines.[<a href="#cit/section_5.216">

8619216</a>

8620] For more information about <em class="gene-name">

8621PTEN</em>

8622 hamartoma tumor syndromes (including Cowden syndrome), see <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_2559">

8623Genetics of Colorectal Cancer</a>

8624 and <a href="/types/breast/hp/breast-ovarian-genetics-pdq#_3778">

8625Genetics of Breast and Gynecologic Cancers.</a>

8626</p>

8627<p id="_789" tabindex="-1">

8628The risk of melanoma in <em class="gene-name">

8629PTEN</em>

8630 carriers is controversial. In an International Cowden Consortium (ICC) study of 100 patients, four women and four men were diagnosed with melanoma when less than one case of melanoma was expected; results showed a SIR of 28.3 for women (95% CI, 7.6&#8211;35.4) and 39.4 for men (95% CI, 10.6&#8211;100.9) (<em>

8631P</em>

8632 &lt; .001).[<a href="#cit/section_5.217">

8633217</a>

8634] In this ICC study, an elevated SIR of 8.5 (95% CI, 4.1&#8211;15.6) was reported in 368 <em class="gene-name">

8635PTEN</em>

8636 pathogenic variant carriers.[<a href="#cit/section_5.218">

8637218</a>

8638] In this cohort, the estimated lifetime risk of melanoma in <em class="gene-name">

8639PTEN</em>

8640 pathogenic variant carriers was 6% (range, 1.6%&#8211;9.4%). Notably, a subsequent prospective study did not observe an elevated melanoma risk in the same population.[<a href="#cit/section_5.219">

8641219</a>

8642] In this study, only 1 of 180 carriers was diagnosed with melanoma. </p>

8643</section>

8644</section>

8645<section id="_390">

8646<h3 id="_390_toc">

8647Melanoma Risk Assessment</h3>

8648<p id="_391" tabindex="-1">

8649Patients with a personal history of melanoma or dysplastic nevi should be asked to provide information regarding a family history of melanoma and other cancers to detect the presence of familial melanoma. Age at diagnosis in family members and pathologic confirmation, if available, should also be sought. The presence of MPM in the same individual may also provide a clue to an underlying genetic susceptibility. Approximately 30% of affected individuals in hereditary melanoma kindreds have more than one primary melanoma, versus 4% of sporadic melanoma patients.[<a href="#cit/section_5.220">

8650220</a>

8651] Family histories should be updated regularly; an annual review is often recommended.</p>

8652<p id="_392" tabindex="-1">

8653For individuals without a personal history of melanoma, several models have been suggested for prediction of melanoma risk.[<a href="#cit/section_5.221">

8654221</a>
