8655] The models differ in performance with respect to <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=322883&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000322883&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

8656sensitivity</a>

8657 and <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=322884&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000322884&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

8658specificity</a>

8659, including differences by sex in some models. Data from the Nurses' Health Study were used to create a model that included gender, age, family history of melanoma, number of severe sunburns, number of moles larger than 3 mm on the limbs, and hair color.[<a href="#cit/section_5.222">

8660222</a>

8661] The concordance statistic for this model was 0.62 (95% CI, 0.58&#8211;0.65). Another measure of baseline melanoma risk was derived from a case-control study of individuals with and without melanoma in the Philadelphia and San Francisco areas.[<a href="#cit/section_5.223">

8662223</a>

8663] This model focused on gender, history of blistering sunburn, color of the complexion, number and size of moles, presence of freckling, presence of solar damage to the skin, absence of a tan, age, and geographic area of the United States. <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=485393&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000485393&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

8664Attributable risk</a>

8665 with this model was 86% for men and 89% for women. This predictive tool, the <a href="https://mrisktool.cancer.gov/" title="https://mrisktool.cancer.gov/">

8666Melanoma Risk Assessment Tool</a>

8667, is available online. However, this tool was developed using a cohort of primarily White individuals without a personal or family history of melanoma or NMSC. It is designed for use by health professionals, and patients are encouraged to discuss results with their physicians. Additional external validation is appropriate before this tool can be adopted for widespread clinical use. Professional organizations have published <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44961&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000044961&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

8668genetic counseling</a>

8669 referral guidelines for individuals with a history of melanoma.[<a href="#cit/section_5.224">

8670224</a>

8671] For more information, see the <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_318">

8672Family history</a>

8673 section.</p>

8674<section id="_393">

8675<h4 id="_393_toc">

8676Genetic testing</h4>

8677<p id="_394" tabindex="-1">

8678Clinical testing is available to identify germline pathogenic variants in genes associated with hereditary melanoma such as <em class="gene-name">

8679MC1R</em>

8680, <em class="gene-name">

8681BAP1</em>

8682, <em class="gene-name">

8683BRCA2</em>

8684, <em class="gene-name">

8685CDK4</em>

8686, <em class="gene-name">

8687CDKN2A</em>

8688, <em class="gene-name">

8689MITF</em>

8690, <em class="gene-name">

8691TERT</em>

8692, and <em class="gene-name">

8693POT1</em>

8694. Multiple testing laboratories in the United States and overseas offer sequence analysis of the entire coding regions of these genes as well as deletion and duplication analysis. Unless there is a known pathogenic variant in a family, panel testing of multiple genes, rather than single gene sequencing, is often done. NCCN suggests considering genetic counseling and testing for <em class="gene-name">

8695CDKN2A</em>

8696 if an individual has a personal or family history of either of the following: 1) three or more invasive cutaneous melanomas or 2) a combination of invasive melanoma, pancreatic cancer, and/or astrocytoma. Multigene (panel) testing may also be warranted when an individual has a family history of melanoma, and other cancers, including the following: uveal melanoma, astrocytoma, mesothelioma, breast cancer, pancreatic cancer, and/or renal cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_5.225">

8697225</a>

8698] Experts suggest that genetic testing be performed after genetic counseling is provided by a qualified genetics professional who is knowledgeable about hereditary skin cancer syndromes. </p>

8699</section>

8700</section>

8701<section id="_43">

8702<h3 id="_43_toc">

8703Interventions</h3>

8704<section id="_397">

8705<h4 id="_397_toc">

8706High-risk population</h4>

8707<section id="_398">

8708<h5 id="_398_toc">

8709Management of members of melanoma-prone families</h5>

8710<p id="_399" tabindex="-1">

8711High-risk individuals, including first- and second-degree family members in melanoma-prone families, should be educated about sun safety and warning signs of melanoma.[<a href="#cit/section_5.66">

871266</a>

8713] Regular examination of the skin by a health care provider experienced in the evaluation of pigmented lesions is also recommended. One guideline suggests initiation of examination at age 10 years and conducting exams on a semiannual basis until nevi are considered stable, followed by annual examinations.[<a href="#cit/section_5.226">

8714226</a>

8715] These individuals should also be taught skin self-examination techniques, to be performed on a monthly basis. Observation of lesions may be aided by techniques such as full-body photography and dermoscopy.[<a href="#cit/section_5.227">

8716227</a>

8717,<a href="#cit/section_5.228">

8718228</a>

8719] A cost-utility analysis has demonstrated the benefits of screening in the high-risk population.[<a href="#cit/section_5.229">

8720229</a>

8721] </p>

8722<p id="_400" tabindex="-1">

8723Biopsies of skin lesions in the high-risk population should be performed using the same criteria as those used for lesions in the general population. Prophylactic removal of nevi without clinically worrisome characteristics is not recommended. The reasons for this are practical: many individuals in these families have a large number of nevi, and complete removal of them all is not feasible, since new atypical nevi continue to develop. In addition, individuals with increased susceptibility to melanoma may have cancer arise de novo, without a precursor lesion such as a nevus.[<a href="#cit/section_5.230">

8724230</a>

8725]</p>

8726<p id="_1036" tabindex="-1">

8727Standard recommendations for screening and management of patients with <em class="gene-name">

8728BAP1</em>

8729 germline pathogenic variants are not currently available, but one group of experts has recommended annual ocular examinations starting at age 16 years, full-body skin examinations starting at age 20 years, and consideration of annual renal ultrasound and/or abdominal magnetic resonance imaging every 2 years.[<a href="#cit/section_5.145">

8730145</a>

8731]</p>

8732<p id="_944" tabindex="-1">

8733<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=526280&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000526280&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8734Level of evidence: 5</a>

8735</p>

8736<p id="_401" tabindex="-1">

8737At present, chemoprevention of melanoma in high-risk individuals remains an area of active investigation; however, no medications are recommended for melanoma risk reduction at this time.</p>

8738<p id="_402" tabindex="-1">

8739<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=526280&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000526280&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8740Level of evidence: 5</a>

8741</p>

8742</section>

8743<section id="_403">

8744<h5 id="_403_toc">

8745Pancreatic cancer screening in <em class="gene-name">

8746CDKN2A</em>

8747 pathogenic variant carriers</h5>

8748<p id="_404" tabindex="-1">

8749Screening for pancreatic cancer remains an area of investigation and controversy for carriers of <em class="gene-name">

8750CDKN2A</em>

8751 pathogenic variants. At present, no effective means of pancreatic cancer screening is available for the general population; however, serum and radiographic screening measures are under study in high-risk populations. One proposed protocol [<a href="#cit/section_5.231">

8752231</a>

8753] suggested starting pancreatic screening in high-risk families at age 50 years or 10 years before the youngest age at diagnosis of pancreatic cancer in the family, whichever came first. In this algorithm, asymptomatic patients would be screened annually with serum cancer antigen 19-9 and endoscopic ultrasound, whereas symptomatic patients or those with abnormal test results would undergo endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) and/or spiral computed tomography (CT) scanning. A study evaluating use of endoscopic ultrasound and ERCP in high-risk families concluded that these procedures were cost-effective in this setting.[<a href="#cit/section_5.232">

8754232</a>

8755]</p>

8756<p id="_405" tabindex="-1">

8757The disadvantages of screening include the limitations of available noninvasive testing methods and the risks associated with invasive screening procedures. ERCP is the gold standard for identifying early cancers and precancerous lesions in the pancreas. However, serious complications such as bleeding, pancreatitis, and intestinal perforation can occur with this procedure. Implementation of pancreatic screening in carriers of <em class="gene-name">

8758CDKN2A</em>

8759 pathogenic variants is further complicated by the apparent lack of increased incidence of pancreatic cancer in many of these families.</p>

8760<p id="_406" tabindex="-1">

8761Most experts suggest that pancreatic cancer screening should be considered for carriers of <em class="gene-name">

8762CDKN2A</em>

8763 pathogenic variants only if there is a family history of pancreatic cancer and, even then, only in the context of a clinical trial. </p>

8764<p id="_407" tabindex="-1">

8765<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=531846&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000531846&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8766Level of evidence: 5</a>

8767</p>

8768</section>

8769</section>

8770<section id="_408">

8771<h4 id="_408_toc">

8772General population</h4>

8773<p id="_1234" tabindex="-1">

8774Prevention, screening, and treatment interventions for melanoma in the general population (i.e., those who do not have a genetic predisposition to developing melanoma) are addressed in the following PDQ summaries:</p>

8775<div class="pdq-content-list">

8776<ul id="_1235">

8777<li>

8778<a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-prevention-pdq">

8780</li>

8783Skin Cancer Screening</a>

8784</li>

8785<li>

9731 <section id="_58">

9732

9733 <h2>

9734Syndromes Associated With Rare Types of Skin Cancer</h2>

9735

9736 <div id="_section_58" class="pdq-sections">

9737<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

9738<h6>

9739In This Section</h6>

9740<ul>

9741<li>

9742<a href="#_65_toc">

9743Brooke-Spiegler Syndrome, Multiple Familial Trichoepithelioma, and Familial Cylindromatosis</a>

9744</li>

9745<li>

9746<a href="#_439_toc">

9747Sebaceous Carcinoma</a>

9748</li>

9749<li>

9750<a href="#_945_toc">

9751Hereditary Leiomyomatosis and Renal Cell Carcinoma (HLRCC)</a>

9752</li>

9753</ul>

9754</nav>

9755<section id="_65">

9756<h3 id="_65_toc">

9757Brooke-Spiegler Syndrome, Multiple Familial Trichoepithelioma, and Familial Cylindromatosis</h3>

9758<p id="_485" tabindex="-1">

9759Brooke-Spiegler Syndrome (BSS), <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460148&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460148&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

9760familial</a>

9761 cylindromatosis, and multiple familial trichoepithelioma (MFT) are all <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=793860&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000793860&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

9762autosomal dominant</a>

9763 syndromes with overlapping clinical characteristics with allelic variance.[<a href="#cit/section_6.1">

97641</a>

9765] Features of BSS include multiple skin appendage tumors such as cylindromas (tumors arising in the hair follicle stem cells), trichoepitheliomas (tumors arising in the hair follicle), and spiradenomas (benign tumors arising in the sweat gland). MFT is characterized by nonmalignant skin tumors, primarily trichoepitheliomas, and familial cylindromatosis manifests predominantly as cutaneous cylindromas. Onset of tumors for these syndromes is typically in late childhood or early adolescence, suggesting a hormonal influence.[<a href="#cit/section_6.2">

97662</a>

9767] There is some evidence of greater severity in females than in males. UV radiation appears to be a major initiating factor for cylindromas. Typical tumor sites for cylindromas in familial cylindromatosis are the scalp (81% of carriers), the trunk (69% of carriers), and the pubic area (42% of carriers).[<a href="#cit/section_6.3">

97683</a>

9769] Other tumors that can be associated with these syndromes include parotid gland tumors, basal cell adenomas, and basal cell carcinomas. For more information about BSS, see <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_276">

9770Table 3</a>

9771, Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC) Syndromes.</p>

9772<p id="_486" tabindex="-1">

9773Because <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=783960&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000783960&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

9774pathogenic variants</a>

9775 in <em class="gene-name">

9776CYLD</em>

9777 on16q12-q13 have been identified in individuals with each of these disorders, these syndromes are thought to represent different phenotypic manifestations of the same disease.[<a href="#cit/section_6.4">

97784</a>

9779] Penetrance of pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

9780CYLD</em>

9781 is reported to be 60% to 100%.[<a href="#cit/section_6.3">

97823</a>

9783,<a href="#cit/section_6.5">

97845</a>

9785] In one study, 85% of the BSS families, 100% of familial cylindromatosis families, and only 44% of MFT families were found to have pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

9786CYLD</em>

9787.[<a href="#cit/section_6.6">

97886</a>

9789] A second <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460162&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460162&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

9790locus</a>

9791 for MFT maps to 9p21, but the gene for this locus remains unknown.[<a href="#cit/section_6.7">

97927</a>

9793]</p>

9794<p id="_487" tabindex="-1">

9795Given the potential for progressive enlargement, the preferred approach for cylindromas is ablation while the tumors are small and easily managed. Electrosurgery or <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=442898&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000442898&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=Cancer.gov'); return(false);">

9796Mohs micrographic surgery</a>

9797 may be used for therapy, although excision of large lesions may require skin grafting for closure.[<a href="#cit/section_6.8">

97988</a>

9799] Trichoepitheliomas and spiradenomas typically remain smaller in size; thus, after the diagnosis is confirmed by skin biopsy, unless there is impingement on critical structures, further intervention is not required. If therapy is deemed necessary and appropriate, either electrosurgery or ablative laser therapy is a valid option.[<a href="#cit/section_6.8">

98008</a>

9801] Radiotherapy is not recommended for treatment of any of these tumors because a potential for increased tumor induction.</p>

9802<p id="_550" tabindex="-1">

9803<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=531845&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000531845&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9804Level of evidence: 4</a>

9805</p>

9806</section>

9807<section id="_439">

9808<h3 id="_439_toc">

9809Sebaceous Carcinoma</h3>

9810<p id="_510" tabindex="-1">

9811Cutaneous sebaceous neoplasms may be associated with Muir-Torre syndrome (MTS). Multiple types of sebaceous tumors including sebaceous adenomas, <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=800259&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000800259&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

9812epitheliomas</a>

9813, carcinomas, and keratoacanthomas or BCCs with sebaceous differentiation have been described. A variant of <a href="/types/colorectal/hp/colorectal-genetics-pdq#_2986">

9814Lynch syndrome</a>

9815/hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer syndrome, the MTS <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460203&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460203&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

9816phenotype</a>

9817 involves the synchronous or metachronous development of at least one cutaneous sebaceous neoplasm and at least one visceral malignancy. The visceral malignancies may be of gastrointestinal (colorectal, stomach, small bowel, liver, and bile duct) and/or genitourinary (endometrial and bladder) origin and typically demonstrate a less aggressive phenotype than non-MTS equivalent tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_6.9">

98189</a>

9819,<a href="#cit/section_6.10">

982010</a>

9821] MTS, inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion with high penetrance and variable expressivity, is associated with pathogenic variants in the mismatch repair genes <em class="gene-name">

9822MLH1</em>

9823, <em class="gene-name">

9824MSH2</em>

9825, and less commonly, <em class="gene-name">

9826MSH6</em>

9827.[<a href="#cit/section_6.11">

982811</a>

9829-<a href="#cit/section_6.16">

983016</a>

9831] In a study of 36 sebaceous lesions that included sebaceous carcinomas, sebaceous adenomas, and <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=800260&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000800260&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

9832sebaceomas</a>

9833, 38.9% of lesions were missing one or more mismatch repair proteins by immunohistochemistry (IHC).[<a href="#cit/section_6.17">

983417</a>

9835] Of the ten individuals with absent staining of one or more proteins, five had gene testing that confirmed a diagnosis of Lynch syndrome. This result suggests that routine screening of sebaceous lesions by IHC may be useful in identification of individuals with Lynch syndrome. One study of the incidence of skin cancer in Lynch syndrome suggests there is an increase in sebaceous carcinoma and squamous cell carcinoma in these patients.[<a href="#cit/section_6.18">

983618</a>

9837] </p>

9838<p id="_511" tabindex="-1">

9839While the commonly noted sebaceous hyperplasia has not been associated with MTS, any sebaceous lesion with atypical or difficult to classify histologic features should prompt further exploration of the patient&#8217;s family and personal medical history. Consideration should be given to referring patients with sebaceous neoplasms to medical geneticists or gastroenterologists to evaluate further for Lynch syndrome. While the diagnosis of visceral malignancy precedes that of cutaneous sebaceous neoplasms in the majority of patients, 22% of patients develop cutaneous sebaceous neoplasms first, offering an opportunity for visceral malignancy screening.[<a href="#cit/section_6.19">

984019</a>

9841] Current diagnosis of MTS is based upon clinical criteria but may be supported by immunohistochemical staining for <em class="gene-name">

9842MSH2</em>

9843, <em class="gene-name">

9844MLH1</em>

9845, and <em class="gene-name">

9846MSH6</em>

9847 as a screening mechanism before molecular genetic analysis.[<a href="#cit/section_6.12">

984812</a>

9849,<a href="#cit/section_6.14">

985014</a>

9851-<a href="#cit/section_6.16">

985216</a>

9853,<a href="#cit/section_6.20">

985420</a>

9855] Genetic counseling and testing for the patient and family members, with appropriate visceral malignancy screening regimens, should be pursued. </p>

9856<p id="_551" tabindex="-1">

9857<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=531825&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000531825&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9858Level of evidence: 3</a>

9859</p>

9860</section>

9861<section id="_945">

9862<h3 id="_945_toc">

9863Hereditary Leiomyomatosis and Renal Cell Carcinoma (HLRCC)</h3>

9864<p id="_961" tabindex="-1">

9865Although cutaneous smooth muscle tumors (leiomyomas) are not themselves a form of skin cancer, multiple <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=765494&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000765494&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

9866cutaneous leiomyomas</a>

9867 are associated with renal cell cancer (RCC) in an inherited syndrome known as hereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell cancer (HLRCC). HLRCC is associated with germline pathogenic variants in the <em class="gene-name">

9868FH</em>

9869 (fumarate hydratase) gene. Cutaneous leiomyomas present as firm, pink or reddish-brown papules and nodules distributed over the trunk and extremities and, occasionally, on the face. These lesions occur at a mean age of 25 years (age range, 10&#8211;47 y) and tend to increase in size and number with age. Lesions are sensitive to light touch and/or cold temperature and are, less commonly, painful. Pain is correlated with severity of cutaneous involvement.[<a href="#cit/section_6.21">

987021</a>

9871] The presence of multiple cutaneous leiomyomas is associated with HLRCC until proven otherwise and should prompt a genetic workup; a solitary leiomyoma requires careful analysis of family history. HLRCC is also associated with clinically significant uterine fibroids and aggressive renal cancers. For more information, see <a href="/types/kidney/hp/renal-cell-carcinoma-genetics/hlrcc-syndrome">

9872Hereditary Leiomyomatosis and Renal Cell Cancer</a>

9873.</p>

9874</section>

Am J Hum Genet 73 (1): 95-106, 2003.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=12772087&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=12772087&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9969 <section id="_423">

9970

9971 <h2>

9972Psychosocial Issues in Familial Melanoma</h2>

9973

9974 <div id="_section_423" class="pdq-sections">

9975<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

9976<h6>

9977In This Section</h6>

9978<ul>

9979<li>

9980<a href="#_888_toc">

9981Introduction</a>

9982</li>

9983<li>

9984<a href="#_425_toc">

9985Interest in and Uptake of Genetic Testing for Risk of Melanoma<ul>

9986<li>

9987<a href="#_661_toc">

9988Testing in children</a>

9989</li>

9990</ul>

9991</a>

9992</li>

9993<li>

9994<a href="#_432_toc">

9995Risk Awareness and Risk Reduction in Individuals at Increased Familial Risk of Melanoma<ul>

9996<li>

9997<a href="#_889_toc">

9998Intervention studies</a>

9999</li>

10000</ul>

10001</a>

10002</li>

10003<li>

10004<a href="#_756_toc">

10005Screening Behaviors in Individuals at Increased Familial Risk of Melanoma<ul>

10006<li>

10007<a href="#_890_toc">

10008Intervention studies</a>

10009</li>

10010</ul>

10011</a>

10012</li>

10013<li>

10014<a href="#_891_toc">

10015Psychosocial Outcomes of Genetic Counseling and Genetic Testing</a>

10016</li>

10017</ul>

10018</nav>

10019<section id="_888">

10020<h3 id="_888_toc">

10021Introduction</h3>

10022<p id="_424" tabindex="-1">

10023This section reviews the literature examining risk reduction and early-detection behaviors in individuals with heightened risk of melanoma resulting from their family history of the disease and in individuals from hereditary families who have been tested for melanoma high-risk <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=783960&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000783960&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

10024pathogenic variant</a>

10025 status. The review also addresses risk perception and communication in individuals at heightened risk of melanoma.</p>

10026</section>

10027<section id="_425">

10028<h3 id="_425_toc">

10029Interest in and Uptake of Genetic Testing for Risk of Melanoma</h3>

10030<p id="_437" tabindex="-1">

10031Currently, clinical testing for <em class="gene-name">

10032CDKN2A</em>

10033 is not recommended outside the research context because most individuals from multiple-case families will not be identified as having a pathogenic variant in this <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=45693&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000045693&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

10034gene</a>

10035, and because recommendations for those testing positive do not differ for multiple-case family members who test negative, or do not pursue testing.[<a href="#cit/section_7.1">

100361</a>

10037,<a href="#cit/section_7.2">

100382</a>

10039] Despite these cautions, <em class="gene-name">

10040CDKN2A</em>

10041 testing is commercially available, and thus demand for the test will likely increase.[<a href="#cit/section_7.3">

100423</a>

10043] Arguments for the availability of genetic testing include that the results of testing could provide psychological security and contribute to enhanced <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=46171&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000046171&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

10044screening</a>

10045 and prevention efforts for those testing positive for <em class="gene-name">

10046CDKN2A</em>

10047.[<a href="#cit/section_7.4">

100484</a>

10049] For more information about melanoma genetic testing, see the <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_390">

10050Melanoma Risk Assessment</a>

10051 section.</p>

10052<p id="_426" tabindex="-1">

10053Few studies have examined motivation and interest in genetic testing for melanoma risk. In summary, the findings include the following: </p>

10054<div class="pdq-content-list">

10055<ul id="_484">

10056<li>

10057High, but not universal interest in genetic testing.[<a href="#cit/section_7.5">

100585</a>

10059-<a href="#cit/section_7.7">

100607</a>

10061]</li>

10062<li>

10063Articulated benefits of testing among those at heightened risk.[<a href="#cit/section_7.5">

100645</a>

10065,<a href="#cit/section_7.6">

100666</a>

10067,<a href="#cit/section_7.8">

100688</a>

10069]</li>

10070<li>

10071A relative lack of examination of potential limitations of testing or reasons to forgo testing.[<a href="#cit/section_7.5">

100725</a>

10073-<a href="#cit/section_7.7">

100747</a>

10075]</li>

10076</ul>

10077</div>

10078<p id="_441" tabindex="-1">

10079In Australia, a qualitative study (N = 40) found that almost all participants with a strong family history of melanoma were interested in genetic testing.[<a href="#cit/section_7.6">

100806</a>

10081,<a href="#cit/section_7.9">

100829</a>

10083] Genetic testing was favored by the participants as a means to gain information about their children's susceptibility to melanoma, to increase their understanding of their own risk, to advance melanoma research, and to provide increased motivation for sun-protective behavior. </p>

10084<p id="_428" tabindex="-1">

10085A Dutch study examined interest in <em class="gene-name">

10086CDKN2A</em>

10087 testing (<em class="gene-name">

10088p16</em>

10089-Leiden pathogenic variant). Of 510 letters sent to members of 18 <em class="gene-name">

10090p16</em>

10091-Leiden-positive families recruited from the Pigmented Lesions Clinic at the Leiden University Medical Center in the Netherlands, 488 individuals responded by attending clinic for physical examination; an additional 15 family members also accompanied these individuals. Of these, 403 individuals were eligible for <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=44961&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000044961&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

10092genetic counseling</a>

10093. A total of 184 family members followed through with counseling, and 141 of them opted for genetic testing. After the counseling session, 94 individuals returned a completed questionnaire. Older age predicted higher interest in genetic testing; reasons for having genetic testing included learning personal risk (57%) and learning the risk of one's child carrying the pathogenic variant (69%). Most participants (88%) felt that genetic testing would contribute to diagnostics within their family. However, some individuals (40%) reported that they had not expected to receive risk information concerning pancreatic cancer, and half of the participants (49%) reported increased worry about the possibility of developing pancreatic cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_7.7">

100947</a>

10095] Finally, in an Arizona qualitative study of 22 individuals with a strong family history of melanoma, none elected genetic testing even though it was provided as an option for them.[<a href="#cit/section_7.8">

100968</a>

10097]</p>

10098<p id="_454" tabindex="-1">

10099In an Australian study of 121 individuals with a strong family history of melanoma, participants completed questionnaires before genetic counseling and testing.[<a href="#cit/section_7.9">

101009</a>

10101] Distress (melanoma-specific distress and general distress) levels were very low in this population. The most important predictors of distress included a personal history of melanoma, having concerns about the impact of melanoma on family, having a high information-seeking disposition (monitoring

10102style), a perceived importance of sun exposure in causing melanoma, and not having children.</p>

10103<section id="_661">

10104<h4 id="_661_toc">

10105Testing in children</h4>

10106<p id="_662" tabindex="-1">

10107A systematic review described three studies that examined participants' attitudes towards performing hereditary melanoma genetic testing in minors.[<a href="#cit/section_7.10">

1010810</a>

10109] Most participants were in favor of testing minors for familial melanoma risk. Many participants who supported testing minors believed that genetic testing could raise awareness about melanoma risk and promote sun-protective behaviors.</p>

10110</section>

10111</section>

10112<section id="_432">

10113<h3 id="_432_toc">

10114Risk Awareness and Risk Reduction in Individuals at Increased Familial Risk of Melanoma</h3>

10115<p id="_433" tabindex="-1">

10116A number of studies have been conducted examining risk reduction via adoption of sun protection (including the use of sunscreen and protective clothing and shade seeking behavior) in individuals with a family history of melanoma. Overall, these studies indicate inconsistent adoption and maintenance of these behaviors. Most of these studies have been conducted with clinic-based populations that might be more prone to risk reduction and screening behaviors than those with a similar risk profile in the general population.[<a href="#cit/section_7.11">

1011711</a>

10118]</p>

10119<p id="_434" tabindex="-1">

10120In terms of sun protection, in a Swedish population, 87 young adults with dysplastic nevi were surveyed, and 70% estimated their melanoma risk to be equal or lower than that of the Swedish population in general, and one third reported frequent sunbathing behavior.[<a href="#cit/section_7.12">

1012112</a>

10122] Another study examined 229 <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=460150&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000460150&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

10123first-degree relatives</a>

10124 (FDRs) referred by melanoma patients attending clinic appointments; those who were older, female, and had greater confidence in their ability to practice sun-protection were most likely to do so, but the utilization of sun-protective behavior was inconsistent.[<a href="#cit/section_7.13">

1012513</a>

10126] Another study in the United States examined sun-protective behavior in 100 FDRs of melanoma clinic patients and found that less than one-third of patients use sunscreen routinely when in the sun and that more regular usage was related to higher education levels, higher self-efficacy for sun protection, and higher perceived melanoma risk. Perceived severity of melanoma and response-efficacy were not related to adoption of sun-protective behaviors.[<a href="#cit/section_7.14">

1012714</a>

10128] </p>

10129<p id="_791" tabindex="-1">

10130A study that focused on 68 minor children (aged 17 years or younger) of melanoma survivors demonstrated that while overall rates of sun-protective behavior were high (near 80%), the rates of sunburn were also high (49%).[<a href="#cit/section_7.15">

1013115</a>

10132] The authors concluded that multiple methods of sun-protective behavior are warranted in these individuals. However, in the teenage years, there were significant reductions in sun protection indicating an even greater need for intervention in this group.</p>

10133<p id="_460" tabindex="-1">

10134Another study based in the United Kingdom examined sunburn rates in 170 individuals with a family history of melanoma compared with 140 controls matched to age, sex, and geographical location. Of those with a melanoma family history, 31% reported sunburn in the previous summer (compared with 41% of controls); melanoma families reported better sun-protection behaviors than controls overall. Across controls and those with a family history of melanoma, younger males were more likely to report recent sunburns; also, across controls and those with a family history of melanoma, those relatives with atypical mole syndrome and a belief in their ability to prevent melanoma showed better sun protection.[<a href="#cit/section_7.16">

1013516</a>

10136]</p>

10137<p id="_1316" tabindex="-1">

10138A large (547 families, 2,407 total individuals), retrospective, international study of a familial melanoma cohort (GenoMEL participants) examined longitudinal sun exposure and sun-protective behaviors in different birth cohorts. The researchers found that sun exposure was similar across all birth cohorts. Sunscreen use increased throughout a participant's life and was used more frequently in recent birth cohorts. There were no differences in histories of sun exposure, sunscreen use, or use of sunbeds between people who had melanoma and those who did not. However, sun-protective behaviors increased after participants were diagnosed with melanoma.[<a href="#cit/section_7.17">

1013917</a>

10140]</p>

10141<p id="_488" tabindex="-1">

10142One qualitative study of 20 FDRs of melanoma patients recruited from a high-risk clinic at the University of Arizona identified perceived unmet needs for physician communication of risk status, including greater consistency in communication, education for patients concerning the importance of family history to risk status, and needs and desire for more complex advice (e.g., reapplication of sunscreen and wearing clothing with ultraviolet protection factor).[<a href="#cit/section_7.18">

1014318</a>

10144]</p>

10145<p id="_663" tabindex="-1">

10146A prospective study examined interest in and 3-month behavioral and psychosocial outcomes associated with disclosure of melanoma high-risk pathogenic variant research results in 19 individuals (three <em class="gene-name">

10147CDKN2A</em>

10148 carriers).[<a href="#cit/section_7.19">

1014919</a>

10150] All of the variant carriers, but only four of the noncarriers, had a family history of melanoma. Carrier status did not affect risk perception, distress, or sun-protection behaviors. </p>

10151<section id="_889">

10152<h4 id="_889_toc">

10153Intervention studies</h4>

10154<p id="_438" tabindex="-1">

10155A few intervention studies have targeted knowledge about melanoma, sun protection, and screening in family members of melanoma patients. In one study among siblings, participants drawn from a clinic population were randomly assigned to an intervention that included telephone messages and tailored print materials about risk reduction and screening recommendations. The usual care group received a standard physician-practice recommendation that patients notify family members about their diagnosis. The intervention group showed improvements in knowledge about melanoma, confidence in seeing a dermatologist and having a screening examination, and greater improvements in skin self-examination practices compared with control participants after 12 months; both groups showed twofold increases in physician examinations after 12 months; there was no change in sunscreen behaviors in either group.[<a href="#cit/section_7.20">

1015620</a>

10157]</p>

10158<p id="_599" tabindex="-1">

10159In another study, 443 family members of melanoma patients were randomly assigned to either a generic or tailored intervention that consisted of three (untailored or tailored) print mailings and one (untailored or tailored) telephone counseling

10160session. Overall, the tailored intervention group showed an almost twofold increase in frequency of total cutaneous skin examinations by a health care provider compared with the generic intervention. However, no differences were observed for skin self-examinations between intervention arms. In contrast to the previous study, which did not show improvements in sun protection habits,[<a href="#cit/section_7.20">

1016120</a>

10162] participants in this study who received the tailored intervention were significantly more likely to report improvements in sun protection habits than were those who received the generic intervention.[<a href="#cit/section_7.21">

1016321</a>

10164]</p>

10165</section>

10166</section>

10167<section id="_756">

10168<h3 id="_756_toc">

10169Screening Behaviors in Individuals at Increased Familial Risk of Melanoma</h3>

10170<p id="_435" tabindex="-1">

10171A number of studies have examined early-detection behaviors in individuals at increased risk of melanoma. In a U.S. sample of 404 siblings drawn from a clinic population of melanoma patients, only 42% of individuals had ever seen a dermatologist; 62% had engaged in skin self-examination; 27% had received a physician skin examination; and only 54% routinely used sunscreen. Female gender was related to greater sunscreen use; those older than age 50 years were more likely to have received a physician skin examination. Having a dermatologist was strongly related to all three outcomes (skin self-examination, physician examination, and sunscreen use).[<a href="#cit/section_7.22">

1017222</a>

10173] In a U.S. study of 229 FDRs referred by patients attending clinic, about half (55%) reported ever having a total cutaneous examination, and slightly more (71%) reported ever performing skin self-examination. Common predictors of skin examination (physician and self-examinations) included physician recommendation and low perceived barriers of screening.[<a href="#cit/section_7.13">

1017413</a>

10175] Interestingly, 14% of the sample had not told their primary care doctor about their sibling&#8217;s melanoma diagnosis. One U.S. study showed that half (53%) of FDRs had never received a total cutaneous screening by a physician; only 27% had received a physician recommendation to have a screening. Early detection adherence was related to the following: higher education level, more melanoma risk factors, health care provider recommendation for screening, perceived risk of melanoma, and perceived severity of melanoma. Parents of melanoma patients were less likely to have pursued screening than siblings and children.[<a href="#cit/section_7.23">

1017623</a>

10177] A U.S. study examined intentions to receive a physician skin examination and to perform skin self-examination among FDRs of individuals diagnosed with melanoma who had not recently engaged in skin <a class="definition" type="GlossaryTermRefs" href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=496506&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000496506&amp;version=healthprofessional&amp;language=English&amp;dictionary=genetic'); return(false);">

10178surveillance</a>

10179. Predictors of intentions included both benefits and barriers to screening and family support for screening, but not knowledge of recommended screening frequency.[<a href="#cit/section_7.24">

1018024</a>

10181]</p>

10182<p id="_598" tabindex="-1">

10183A cross-sectional Australian study of 120 individuals from families with a known <em class="gene-name">

10184CDKN2A</em>

10185 pathogenic variant found that in the past 12 months, 50% reported engaging in skin self-examinations at least four times, and 43% had undergone at least one clinical skin examination. In contrast, 15% had not performed a skin self-examination in the past 12 months, and 27% had never had a clinical skin examination. Correlates of skin cancer screening behaviors included having a history of melanoma, a physician&#8217;s recommendation, and stronger behavioral intentions. Additional correlates for skin self-examination included self-efficacy, perceived efficacy of melanoma treatment, and melanoma-specific distress. Perceived risk of developing melanoma was not significantly associated with skin cancer screening behaviors.[<a href="#cit/section_7.25">

1018625</a>

10187]</p>

10188<p id="_1317" tabindex="-1">

10189A systematic review provided a narrative summary of behavioral outcomes (sun-protective behaviors, self-skin examination, and clinical skin examination) associated with genetic testing for inherited melanoma risk. With some differences between studies, more than one-half of studies found that an inherited pathogenic variant was associated with increased adherence (or intentions) to recommended melanoma prevention and screening. There were no decreases in sun-protective behaviors among noncarriers.[<a href="#cit/section_7.26">

1019026</a>

10191]</p>

10192<section id="_890">

10193<h4 id="_890_toc">

10194Intervention studies</h4>

10195<p id="_904" tabindex="-1">

10196A few intervention studies have targeted knowledge about melanoma, sun protection, and screening in family members of melanoma patients. In one study among siblings, participants drawn from a clinic population were randomly assigned to an intervention that included telephone messages and tailored print materials about risk reduction and screening recommendations. The usual care group received a standard physician-practice recommendation that patients notify family members about their diagnosis. The intervention group showed improvements in knowledge about melanoma, confidence in seeing a dermatologist and having a screening examination, and greater improvements in skin self-examination practices compared with control participants after 12 months; both groups showed twofold increases in physician examinations after 12 months; there was no change in sunscreen behaviors in either group.[<a href="#cit/section_7.20">

1019720</a>

10198]</p>

10199<p id="_905" tabindex="-1">

10200In another study, 443 family members of melanoma patients were randomly assigned to either a generic or tailored intervention that consisted of three (untailored or tailored) print mailings and one (untailored or tailored) telephone counseling

10201session. Overall, the tailored intervention group showed an almost twofold increase in frequency of total cutaneous skin examinations by a health care provider compared with the generic intervention. However, no differences were observed for skin self-examinations between intervention arms. In contrast to the previous study, which did not show improvements in sun protection habits,[<a href="#cit/section_7.20">

1020220</a>

10203] participants in this study who received the tailored intervention were significantly more likely to report improvements in sun protection habits than were those who received the generic intervention.[<a href="#cit/section_7.21">

1020421</a>

10205]</p>

10206</section>

10207</section>

10208<section id="_891">

10209<h3 id="_891_toc">

10210Psychosocial Outcomes of Genetic Counseling and Genetic Testing</h3>

10211<p id="_431" tabindex="-1">

10212A systematic review examined multiple psychosocial outcomes for high-risk people undergoing melanoma genetic testing from articles published between 1995 and 2020.[<a href="#cit/section_7.10">

1021310</a>

10214] Psychological outcomes included generalized anxiety and depression, melanoma-specific distress, worry about melanoma and/or pancreatic cancer, and regret about having genetic testing. Generally, distress levels (both general and melanoma-specific) were low and subclinical. Anxiety decreased over time, both for carriers and noncarriers. Cancer-specific worry had mixed results in different studies when comparing carriers with non-carriers, affected individuals with unaffected individuals, and worry over time. Studies showed that noncarriers overestimated perceived cancer risks when compared with objective estimates. Studies generally showed low levels of decisional regret about genetic testing. People tended to name more benefits of genetic testing than limitations.</p>

10215</section>

10216<h6 do-not-show="toc">

10271<li id="section_7.14">

Cancer Epidemiol Biomarkers Prev 15 (1): 142-5, 2006.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16434600&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16434600&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10273[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10274</li>

10275<li id="section_7.15">

10276Glenn BA, Bastani R, Chang LC, et al.: Sun protection practices among children with a family history of melanoma: a pilot study. J Cancer Educ 27 (4): 731-7, 2012.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=22610837&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=22610837&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10277[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10278</li>

10279<li id="section_7.16">

10280Newton Bishop JA, Gruis NA: Genetics: what advice for patients who present with a family history of melanoma? Semin Oncol 34 (6): 452-9, 2007.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=18083368&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=18083368&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10281[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10282</li>

10283<li id="section_7.17">

10284Lacson JCA, Zamani SA, Froes LAR, et al.: Birth cohort-specific trends of sun-related behaviors among individuals from an international consortium of melanoma-prone families. BMC Public Health 21 (1): 692, 2021.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=33888076&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=33888076&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10285[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10286</li>

10287<li id="section_7.18">

10288Loescher LJ, Crist JD, Cranmer L, et al.: Melanoma high-risk families' perceived health care provider risk communication. J Cancer Educ 24 (4): 301-7, 2009.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19838889&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19838889&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10289[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10290</li>

10291<li id="section_7.19">

10292Christensen KD, Roberts JS, Shalowitz DI, et al.: Disclosing individual CDKN2A research results to melanoma survivors: interest, impact, and demands on researchers. Cancer Epidemiol Biomarkers Prev 20 (3): 522-9, 2011.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21307304&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21307304&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10293[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10294</li>

10295<li id="section_7.20">

10296Geller AC, Emmons KM, Brooks DR, et al.: A randomized trial to improve early detection and prevention practices among siblings of melanoma patients. Cancer 107 (4): 806-14, 2006.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16832795&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16832795&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10297[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10298</li>

10299<li id="section_7.21">

10300Manne S, Jacobsen PB, Ming ME, et al.: Tailored versus generic interventions for skin cancer risk reduction for family members of melanoma patients. Health Psychol 29 (6): 583-93, 2010.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21090893&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21090893&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10301[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10302</li>

10303<li id="section_7.22">

10304Geller AC, Emmons K, Brooks DR, et al.: Skin cancer prevention and detection practices among siblings of patients with melanoma. J Am Acad Dermatol 49 (4): 631-8, 2003.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=14512908&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=14512908&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10305[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10306</li>

10307<li id="section_7.23">

10308Azzarello LM, Jacobsen PB: Factors influencing participation in cutaneous screening among individuals with a family history of melanoma. J Am Acad Dermatol 56 (3): 398-406, 2007.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17184873&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=17184873&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10309[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10310</li>

10311<li id="section_7.24">

10312Coups EJ, Manne SL, Jacobsen PB, et al.: Skin surveillance intentions among family members of patients with melanoma. BMC Public Health 11: 866, 2011.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=22082038&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=22082038&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10313[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10314</li>

10315<li id="section_7.25">

10316Kasparian NA, McLoone JK, Meiser B, et al.: Skin cancer screening behaviours among individuals with a strong family history of malignant melanoma. Br J Cancer 103 (10): 1502-9, 2010.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20978504&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20978504&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10317[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10318</li>

10319<li id="section_7.26">

10320Primiero CA, Yanes T, Finnane A, et al.: A Systematic Review on the Impact of Genetic Testing for Familial Melanoma I: Primary and Secondary Preventative Behaviours. Dermatology 237 (5): 806-815, 2021.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=33588421&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=33588421&amp;dopt=Abstract">

10321[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10322</li>

10323</ol>

10324</div>

10325

10326 </section>

10327

10328

10329

10330 <section id="_4">

10331

10332 <h2>

10333Changes to This Summary (08/23/2023)</h2>

10334

10335 <div id="_section_4" class="pdq-sections">

10336<p id="_628" tabindex="-1">

10337The PDQ cancer information summaries are reviewed regularly and updated as new information becomes available. This section describes the latest changes made to this summary as of the date above.</p>

10338<p id="_1340" tabindex="-1">

10339<strong>

10340<a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_9">

10341Basal Cell Carcinoma</a>

10342</strong>

10343</p>

10344<p id="_1341" tabindex="-1">

10345Added <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_214">

10346text</a>

10347 to state that the role of the <em class="gene-name">

10348PTCH2</em>

10349 gene in basal cell nevus syndrome has been contested (cited Smith et al. as reference 35).</p>

10350<p id="_1342" tabindex="-1">

10351Added <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_225">

10352text</a>

10353 about the results of a 2022 study that analyzed if certain clinical manifestations predicted disease severity in 428 patients with Gorlin syndrome. Genotype-phenotype analyses were also conducted in 40 patients (cited Betancourt et al. as reference 106).</p>

10354<p id="_1343" tabindex="-1">

10355Added <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_274">

10356text</a>

10357 to state that in the United States, isotretinoin can only be prescribed through the U.S. Food and Drug Administration&#8211;mandated iPledge program.</p>

10358<p id="_1344" tabindex="-1">

10359<strong>

10360<a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_20">

10361Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC)</a>

10362</strong>

10363</p>

10364<p id="_1365" tabindex="-1">

10365Updated American Cancer Society as <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_22">

10366reference 2</a>

10367.</p>

10368<p id="_1345" tabindex="-1">

10369Added <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_132">

10370text</a>

10371 to state that a 2.7 kb intragenic deletion in the <em class="gene-name">

10372OCA2</em>

10373 gene is a common founder pathogenic variant in sub-Saharan Africa and accounts for most <em class="gene-name">

10374OCA2</em>

10375-related albinism cases in this region (cited Laetitia et al. as reference 83).</p>

10376<p id="_1346" tabindex="-1">

10377Revised <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_857">

10378text</a>

10379 to state that while the type of epidermolysis bullosa (EB) can be difficult to determine clinically, next-generation sequencing can define the EB subtype in up to 90% of cases (cited Phillips et al. as reference 131). Also added text to state that diagnosis of EB may be accomplished by immunofluorescence or electron microscopy (cited Rossi et al. and Has et al. as references 132 and 133, respectively).</p>

10380<p id="_1347" tabindex="-1">

10381Added <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_156">

10382text</a>

10383 to state that a study of 290 individuals from the Bloom Syndrome Registry found that 155 participants developed one or more malignancies, with an 83% cumulative incidence of any cancer type by age 40 years. Median survival was 36.2 years. Median survival varied for those diagnosed with a hematologic malignancy and those diagnosed with a solid tumor. Median survival was not adjusted by year of cancer diagnosis (cited Sugra&#241;es et al. as reference 211).</p>

10384<p id="_1348" tabindex="-1">

10385Added <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_1337">

10386text</a>

10387 about the results of a 2022 study that used Bloom Syndrome Registry data to examine the ages at which individuals with Bloom syndrome first developed cancer and how long they survived.</p>

10388<p id="_1349" tabindex="-1">

10389Revised <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_163">

10390text</a>

10391 to state that pathogenic variants described in the <em class="gene-name">

10392WRN</em>

10393 gene include all types of variants, including missense, splice-site, and large rearrangements. Also added text to state that few founder pathogenic variants have been reported, which include a splice-site variant found in over 50% of affected Japanese individuals (cited Matsumoto et al. as reference 241).</p>

10394<p id="_1350" tabindex="-1">

10395Added <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_959">

10396text</a>

10397 to state that the mean age of the study participants was 66.4 years, and 63% were male in a phase III, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial in Australia. Also added text to state that this study was conducted in a part of the world with a high incidence of sunlight-induced skin cancer.</p>

10398<p id="_1351" tabindex="-1">

10399Added <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_1130">

10400text</a>

10401 to state that because the extent of SCC may be difficult to assess in patients with EB, clearance of SCC tumors may require continuous margin control surgery or generous clinical margins. Multiple surgical sessions may be required. Closure of the subsequent defects may require tissue rearrangement or dermal substitutes (cited Paganelli et al. as reference 258).</p>

10402<p id="_1352" tabindex="-1">

10403 Added <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_1111">

10404text</a>

10405 to state that a small prospective trial of intravenous gentamicin in pediatric patients with junctional EB showed that patients had increased wound healing and improved quality of life after treatment. Also revised text to state that all of these therapies are still in early research stages and have not yet been evaluated in randomized, controlled clinical trials (cited Mosallaei et al. as reference 267).</p>

10406<p id="_1353" tabindex="-1">

10407<strong>

10408<a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_38">

10409Melanoma</a>

10410</strong>

10411</p>

10412<p id="_1354" tabindex="-1">

10413Revised <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_1032">

10414text</a>

10415 to state that a major hereditary melanoma susceptibility gene, <em class="gene-name">

10416CDKN2A</em>

10417, is altered in approximately 14% to 43% of families with three or more melanoma cases (cited Bruno et al. as reference 33). Also added text to state that in a large Italian study of multigene panel testing in patients with melanoma, predictors of a pathogenic variant included the following: (1) the presence of pancreatic cancer and melanoma in the same family, and (2) individuals who have had more than three melanomas. When patients were diagnosed with melanoma after age 60 years, they were less likely to have a pathogenic variant in a melanoma gene.</p>

10418<p id="_1355" tabindex="-1">

10419Added <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_886">

10420text</a>

10421 to state that one study of individuals with <em class="gene-name">

10422CDKN2A</em>

10423 pathogenic variants that affected both p16 and p14ARF transcripts found an increased incidence of esophageal cancers and malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors, although the reported incidence for both of these tumors was very small (cited Sargen et al. as reference 87).</p>

10424<p id="_1356" tabindex="-1">

10425Added <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_742">

10426text</a>

10427 to state that while somatic activating variants in <em class="gene-name">

10428TERT</em>

10429 are seen often in multiple cancer types, including sporadic melanoma, germline pathogenic variants in <em class="gene-name">

10430TERT</em>

10431 are found rarely in melanoma families. A pathogenic variant in the promoter region of a <em class="gene-name">

10432TERT</em>

10433 subunit was found in a single, large German kindred with multiple melanomas and other cancers. This pathogenic variant had increased promoter activity in construct assays. Also added text to state that a detailed analysis of family members from this kindred was performed in 2022, and it emphasized the young ages at which melanoma was diagnosed in this kindred (cited Zaremba et al. as reference 120).</p>

10434<p id="_1357" tabindex="-1">

10435Added <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_1334">

10436<em class="gene-name">

10437TP53</em>

10438 (Li-Fraumeni syndrome)</a>

10439 as a new subsection.</p>

10440<p id="_1358" tabindex="-1">

10441<strong>

10442<a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_58">

10443Syndromes Associated With Rare Types of Skin Cancer</a>

10444</strong>

10445</p>

10446<p id="_1359" tabindex="-1">

10447Added <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_961">

10448text</a>

10449 to state that hereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell carcinoma (HLRCC) is associated with germline pathogenic variants in the <em class="gene-name">

10450FH</em>

10451 gene. Also added text to state that HLRCC is associated with clinically significant uterine fibroids and aggressive renal cancers.</p>

10452<p id="_1360" tabindex="-1">

10453<strong>

10454<a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_423">

10455Psychosocial Issues in Familial Melanoma</a>

10456</strong>

10457</p>

10458<p id="_1361" tabindex="-1">

10459Added <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_662">

10460text</a>

10461 to state that a systematic review described three studies that examined participants' attitudes towards performing hereditary melanoma genetic testing in minors. Most participants were in favor of testing minors for familial melanoma risk. Many participants who supported testing minors believed that genetic testing could raise awareness about melanoma risk and promote sun-protective behaviors (cited Primiero et al. [Dermatol, pp. 816-826] as reference 10).</p>

10462<p id="_1362" tabindex="-1">

10463Added <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_1316">

10464text</a>

10465 about the results of a 2021 international, retrospective study that analyzed sun exposure and sun-protective behaviors across birth cohorts in 2,047 individuals with increased susceptibility to melanoma (cited Lacson et al. as reference 17).</p>

10466<p id="_1363" tabindex="-1">

10467Added <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_1317">

10468text</a>

10469 to state that a systematic review provided a narrative summary of behavioral outcomes associated with genetic testing for inherited melanoma risk. With some differences between studies, more than one-half of studies found that an inherited pathogenic variant was associated with increased adherence to recommended melanoma prevention and screening. There were no decreases in sun-protective behaviors among noncarriers (cited Primiero et al. [Dermatol, pp. 806-815] as reference 26).</p>

10470<p id="_1364" tabindex="-1">

10471Added <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_431">

10472text</a>

10473 about a systematic review that examined multiple psychosocial outcomes in 1,137 high-risk people undergoing melanoma genetic testing from 21 articles published between 1995 and 2020. </p>

10474<p id="_disclaimerHP_3" tabindex="-1">

10475This summary is written and maintained by the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/editorial-boards/genetics" title="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/editorial-boards/genetics">

10476PDQ Cancer Genetics Editorial Board</a>

10477, which is

10478editorially independent of NCI. The summary reflects an independent review of

10479the literature and does not represent a policy statement of NCI or NIH. More

10480information about summary policies and the role of the PDQ Editorial Boards in

10481maintaining the PDQ summaries can be found on the <a href="/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq#_AboutThis_1">

10482About This PDQ Summary</a>

10483 and <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq" title="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq">

10484PDQ&#174; Cancer Information for Health Professionals</a>

10485 pages.

10486</p>

10487</div>

10488

10489 </section>

10490

10491

10492

10493 <section id="_AboutThis_1">

10494

10495 <h2>

10496About This PDQ Summary</h2>

10497

10498 <div id="_section_AboutThis_1" class="pdq-sections">

10499<section id="_AboutThis_2">

10500<h3 id="_AboutThis_2_toc">

10501Purpose of This Summary</h3>

10502<p id="_AboutThis_3" tabindex="-1">

10503This PDQ cancer information summary for health professionals provides comprehensive, peer-reviewed, evidence-based information about the genetics of skin cancer. It is intended as a resource to inform and assist clinicians in the care of their patients. It does not provide formal guidelines or recommendations for making health care decisions.</p>

10504</section>

10505<section id="_AboutThis_4">

10506<h3 id="_AboutThis_4_toc">

10507Reviewers and Updates</h3>

10508<p id="_AboutThis_5" tabindex="-1">

10509This summary is reviewed regularly and updated as necessary by the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/editorial-boards/genetics" title="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/editorial-boards/genetics">

10510PDQ Cancer Genetics Editorial Board</a>

10511, which is editorially independent of the National Cancer Institute (NCI). The summary reflects an independent review of the literature and does not represent a policy statement of NCI or the National Institutes of Health (NIH).</p>

10512<p id="_AboutThis_22" tabindex="-1">

10513 Board members review recently published articles each month to determine whether an article should:</p>

10514<div class="pdq-content-list">

10515<ul id="_AboutThis_6">

10516<li>

10517be discussed at a meeting,</li>

10518<li>

10519be cited with text, or</li>

10520<li>

10521replace or update an existing article that is already cited.</li>

10522</ul>

10523</div>

10524<p id="_AboutThis_7" tabindex="-1">

10525Changes to the summaries are made through a consensus process in which Board members evaluate the strength of the evidence in the published articles and determine how the article should be included in the summary.</p>

10526<p id="" tabindex="-1">

10527The lead reviewers for Genetics of Skin Cancer are:</p>

10528<div class="pdq-content-list">

10529<ul id="">

10530<li>

10531Kathleen A. Calzone, PhD, RN, AGN-BC, FAAN (National Cancer Institute)</li>

10532<li>

10533Joanne Marie Jeter, MD (Huntsman Cancer Institute at University of Utah)</li>

10534<li>

10535Kelly Carter Nelson, MD, FAAD (M.D. Anderson Cancer Center at University of Texas)</li>

10536<li>

10537Suzanne C. O'Neill, PhD (Georgetown University)</li>

10538<li>

10539Susan K. Peterson, PhD, MPH (University of Texas, M.D. Anderson Cancer Center)</li>

10540<li>

10541John M. Quillin, PhD, MPH, MS (Virginia Commonwealth University)</li>

10542<li>

10543Charite Ricker, MS, CGC (University of Southern California)</li>

10544<li>

10545Amanda Ewart Toland, PhD, FACMG (The Ohio State University)</li>

10546<li>

10547Catharine Wang, PhD, MSc (Boston University School of Public Health)</li>

10548</ul>

10549</div>

10550<p id="_AboutThis_9" tabindex="-1">

10551Any comments or questions about the summary content should be submitted to Cancer.gov through the NCI website's <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/contact/email-us" title="https://www.cancer.gov/contact/email-us">

10552Email Us</a>

10553. Do not contact the individual Board Members with questions or comments about the summaries. Board members will not respond to individual inquiries.</p>

10554</section>

10555<section id="_AboutThis_10">

10556<h3 id="_AboutThis_10_toc">

10557Levels of Evidence</h3>

10558<p id="_AboutThis_11" tabindex="-1">

10559Some of the reference citations in this summary are accompanied by a level-of-evidence designation. These designations are intended to help readers assess the strength of the evidence supporting the use of specific interventions or approaches. The PDQ Cancer Genetics Editorial Board uses a <a href="/publications/pdq/levels-evidence/genetics">

10560formal evidence ranking system</a>

10561 in developing its level-of-evidence designations.</p>

10562</section>

10563<section id="_AboutThis_12">

10564<h3 id="_AboutThis_12_toc">

10565Permission to Use This Summary</h3>

10566<p id="_AboutThis_13" tabindex="-1">

10567PDQ is a registered trademark. Although the content of PDQ documents can be used freely as text, it cannot be identified as an NCI PDQ cancer information summary unless it is presented in its entirety and is regularly updated. However, an author would be permitted to write a sentence such as &#8220;NCI&#8217;s PDQ cancer information summary about breast cancer prevention states the risks succinctly: [include excerpt from the summary].&#8221;</p>

10568<p id="_AboutThis_14" tabindex="-1">

10569The preferred citation for this PDQ summary is:</p>

10570<p id="_AboutThis_15" tabindex="-1">

10571PDQ&#174; Cancer Genetics Editorial Board. PDQ Genetics of Skin Cancer. Bethesda, MD: National Cancer Institute. Updated &lt;MM/DD/YYYY&gt;. Available at: <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq" title="https://www.cancer.gov/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq">

10572https://www.cancer.gov/types/skin/hp/skin-genetics-pdq</a>

10573. Accessed &lt;MM/DD/YYYY&gt;. [PMID: 26389333]</p>

10574<p id="_AboutThis_16" tabindex="-1">

10575Images in this summary are used with permission of the author(s), artist, and/or publisher for use within the PDQ summaries only. Permission to use images outside the context of PDQ information must be obtained from the owner(s) and cannot be granted by the National Cancer Institute. Information about using the illustrations in this summary, along with many other cancer-related images, is available in <a href="https://visualsonline.cancer.gov/" title="https://visualsonline.cancer.gov/">

10576Visuals Online</a>

10577, a collection of over 2,000 scientific images.

10578

10579</p>

10580</section>

10581<section id="_AboutThis_17">

10582<h3 id="_AboutThis_17_toc">

10583Disclaimer</h3>

10584<p id="_AboutThis_19" tabindex="-1">

10585The information in these summaries should not be used as a basis for insurance reimbursement determinations. More information on insurance coverage is available on Cancer.gov on the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/managing-care" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/managing-care">

10586Managing Cancer Care</a>

10587 page.</p>

10588</section>

10589<section id="_AboutThis_20">

10590<h3 id="_AboutThis_20_toc">

10591Contact Us</h3>

10592<p id="_AboutThis_21" tabindex="-1">

10593More information about contacting us or receiving help with the Cancer.gov website can be found on our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/contact" title="https://www.cancer.gov/contact">

10594Contact Us for Help</a>

10595 page. Questions can also be submitted to Cancer.gov through the website&#8217;s <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/contact/email-us" title="https://www.cancer.gov/contact/email-us">

10596Email Us</a>

10597.</p>

10598</section>

10636 <div class="slot-item only-SI">

10637

10638 <div class="public-use">

10639

10640 <div id="block-ncids-trans-public-use">

10641

10642

10643

10644 <p>

10645<em>

10646If you would like to reproduce some or all of this content, see <a href="/policies/copyright-reuse">

10647Reuse of NCI Information</a>

10648 for guidance about copyright and permissions. In the case of permitted digital reproduction, please credit the National Cancer Institute as the source and link to the original NCI product using the original product's title; e.g., Genetics of Skin Cancer (PDQ)Health Professional Version was originally published by the National Cancer Institute.</em>

10649</p>
